My father kept a second family in our basement. Last week, I found out the horrifying reason why. My dad has been feeding people in our basement for as long as I can remember. Every night at exactly 8:47, he would grab the leftover dinner, walk downstairs for 20 minutes, then come back up with an empty plate. I used to think this was completely normal until I realized how messed up it actually was. When I was 6, I asked my mom about the voices coming from downstairs. She just lit another cigarette and said, your father handles the basement handle upstairs. Her hands were shaking the whole time she said it. I could tell she was scared, but I didn't know why. The basement door was always locked with this huge deadbolt. I tried opening it once when I was eight, and my dad caught me. His face went completely white. He told me to never go down there because they weren't ready to meet me yet. But I could hear them. A little girl singing, A baby crying at three in the morning. Christmas was the weirdest time because my dad would bring two sets of presents. One pile for me and another armload that disappeared downstairs. I'd hear kids screaming with excitement while I opened my gifts alone upstairs. Mom would just chain smoke by the window, staring at nothing. When I turned 12, everything changed. The singing stopped. No more laughter, no more voices. Just Complete silence. But dad still brought food down every single night. He'd come back up faster, though, looking sick. Mom started drinking wine for breakfast. Convinced my best friend Trevor to sleep over that weekend. Maybe if someone else was there, dad would finally explain what was going on. But at 8:47, he grabbed the plate like always. Trevor followed me to the basement door. That's when we heard her. A woman's voice, desperate and hollow. Please let us out. Austin's getting older. He'll understand now. We've been good. We've been so good. Trevor's face went completely white. Dude, that's messed up. We should call someone. But dad was already coming back up. He saw us by the door and dropped the plate. It shattered everywhere. Boys, go to Austin's room now! That night, I heard my parents fighting for hours. Mom was sobbing, saying they couldn't keep doing this. Dad kept repeating, they need to stay down there. You know what happens if they don't. The next morning, Trevor's parents

I got upset at my wife's reason for marrying me. My wife Emma, is basically a robot when it comes to emotions. She's this data scientist who literally turns everything into spreadsheets and pros and cons lists. Like when we were picking what color to paint our bedroom, she made a whole Powerpoint about how blue affects sleep quality. I thought it was cute at first, you know, made me feel like she really thought things through. But Last Saturday, I asked her something that's been eating at me since. Why did you marry me? I was expecting some romantic answer about how much she loves me or how I make her laugh or whatever normal couple stuff. She looked at me dead serious and said, because you asked. I thought she was joking, so I laughed it off, but then I pushed a little more. Okay, but, like, what made you say yes, though? And this woman, my wife of three years, looks me straight in the eye and says, because I trust your judgment. I just stared at her. What the hell does that even mean? So I asked her to explain, and she went into full professor mode. She told me love isn't enough to marry someone. That when she was in college, she was head over heels for this guy named Tyler, who was basically a walking disaster. Good looking, charming, but had no goals, no t shirts and energy drinks. She said she would have Married him if he asked back then. Because she was young and

My siblings and I sat at dinner when our father smiled and asked, ready to compete for the upstairs bedroom? Again? I stared in shock. Again. I don't want to compete. Oh, sweetie, mom said, reaching across the table to pat my hand. The monthly room assignment builds character. Winners get the master suite. Losers get the basement. My younger brother, Marvin, pushed his food around his plate. My sister Bianca wouldn't even look up. We've been doing this for three months since we moved to this house. The basement had exposed pipes. heat. And spiders that dropped from the ceiling at night. Bianca won last month with her debate trophy. Dad continued, pulling out his notebook. So she keeps the room unless one of you beats her achievements this month. The chicken tasted like cardboard in my mouth. This is insane. Other families don't do this. Mom smile tightened. Other families raise weak children. We're raising winners. That night, Bianca came to my basement corner, where I'd hung sheets for privacy. I'm sorry, she whispered. Didn't wanna win, but sleeping down here made me sick last time. It's not your fault, I said, but the words felt hollow. Marvin had already stopped talking to both of us. The next morning, dad posted the point chart on the refrigerator. 10 points for A's, 20 for sports victories, 15 for volunteer hours, even five points for who said good morning first. I watched Marvin set his alarm for 4:00am. Just to beat us to the by week two, Bianca started hiding my homework. I found it crumpled in the trash after getting a zero. Marvin put a dead spider in my backpack during lunch, making me scream in front of everyone. We stopped eating together. Stop helping each other with assignments. Three kids living in the same house, acting like enemies. Look at that competitive spirit! Dad beamed one morning after Marvin and Bianca physically fought over who got to take out the trash for points. Mom took photos like it was something to be proud of. My grades started slipping from the stress. I couldn't sleep in the freezing basement constantly.

My neighbor kept stealing my packages, so I started ordering live bees. She opened one. For six months, Margaret from 4B took every package delivered to my door. Amazon, medications, even my mother's birthday gift. Had her on camera. But building management said it's a civil matter. And police said, talk to building management. So I got creative. Ordered 3,000 live honey bees from a bee farm. Completely legal. Left the package outside my door during my lunch break, when Margaret always struck. Twenty minutes later, screaming from the hallway. Margaret had opened the box in the elevator. Bees everywhere. The elevator automatically locked down. Safety feature during emergencies. Trapping her with thousands of confused bees for seven minutes. She wasn't allergic, just terrified and covered in bees. Building management suddenly cared about package theft. Elevator needed professional cleaning. $2,000. Three floors evacuated. Margaret sobbing in the lobby, bees in her hair. She tried to kill me. Margaret screamed at the police. You opened her package? The officer asked. It was delivered wrong. To her door? Yes, with her name, I thought. You thought what? That you'd steal it. I showed them six months of security footage I'd compiled. Margaret taking 47 packages, including my insulin, which she'd thrown away because it looked medical and gross. The officer looked at the bee invoice. Ma'am, she legally ordered live bees for her beekeeping hobby. You illegally opened her mail. That's a federal crime. What beekeeping hobby? I joined an urban beekeeping Group the week before had the membership card and everything. Margaret got charged with mail theft, 47 counts. The federal prosecutor was particularly interested in the insulin theft. Medical mail tampering is serious. She had to pay 4,008

I canceled our gender reveal party because I know my husband will be unhappy and possibly leave. So I'm 37 and pregnant with our second kid. My husband Jake is 43, and we already have a nine year old son named Connor. Jake absolutely worships this kid. I'm talking every new video game, basketball camp, you name it. They're like best friends. We had this whole gender reveal party planned for next week. Already paid for the venue at this fancy country club, put down deposits on a photographer, bought all these blue and pink decorations from target. The whole thing probably cost us, like $3,000. But here's the thing. Jake has been acting weird ever since I started showing. Not excited weird. More like stressed weird. He keeps making these comments about how it would be nice to have another boy and asking if I think the baby looks like a boy in the ultrasound pics. Last month, he actually said, and I quote, I just don't know what I'd do with a girl. When I asked him what he meant, he got all defensive and said he was just worried about teenage years and dating and stuff, but something felt off. We didn't do a gender reveal with Connor because Jake kept changing his mind about when he wanted to find out. We ended up learning it was a boy like three weeks before I gave birth, and Jake literally cried tears of joy in the doctor's office. So two weeks ago, Jake said maybe I should just go to my appointment alone and find out without him. He said he was too nervous and would rather wait for the party. I thought that was weird, but whatever. I went to Doctor Martinez's office by myself last Tuesday. She did the ultrasound and told me we're having a girl. I was honestly excited. I've been secretly hoping for a daughter. But when I got home,

I'm a teacher, and I've had the same student in my class for 10 years. He hasn't aged a single day. When I started teaching third grade at Rosewood Elementary, I thought I'd seen everything. But nothing prepared me for Ryan. He showed up on the second day of school clutching a class assignment sheet that said, Room 12, Mess Carter. Ryan Blackwood. I didn't remember his name on my roster, but kids get enrolled late all the time. Ryan was 8 years old. Blond hair, green eyes, small scar above his left eyebrow. Quiet kid who always sat in the back corner. Wore the same red hoodie every day. At the end of third grade, Ryan's parents apparently decided he needed to repeat the year. Academic struggles, they said. Weird, because Ryan was one of my brightest students. Fourth year of teaching, same thing. Ryan showed up again, clutching that assignment sheet. Same red hoodie, same corner seat. Still 8 years old. Fifth year, same Ryan. Same assignment sheet, same eight year old face. Sixth year, I started taking photos. Ryan in September looked identical to Ryan from five years ago. Same height, same baby teeth, same everything. Seventh year, I confronted the principal, showed her the photos. That's not the same child, she said. This year's student is Robert Blackwood, Ryan's younger brother. I looked at the photos again. Name on this year's assignment sheet had changed to Robert Blackwood in my hands. Eighth year, was Richard Blackwood. Same face, same scar. Same red hoodie that never faded. Ninth year brought Russell Blackwood. I started documenting everything. Every year, a new Blackwood boy who looked precisely like Ryan from five years ago. But in year 10, something changed. This year's assignment sheet read Ronald Blackwood. But when I looked at his face, his green eyes had no pupils, just solid green, like marbles. His skin had a waxy, artificial texture. During recess, he sat perfectly still for 30 minutes. Didn't move, didn't blink. Other kids played around him like he wasn't there. Ronald, are you okay? I asked. He turned his head toward me with a mechanical click. I'm fine, Miss Carter. His voice sounded hollow, like it was coming from inside a tunnel.

What made you realise that? Some bridges need burning. My sister demanded I sleep with her husband to give them a baby because she was infertile. Rachel had always been the golden child, who once faked a cancer scare to steal attention at my wedding and later sued her bridesmaid for getting pregnant before her big day. She got dad's business connections and mom's jewellery collection while I scraped by with community college loans, then married rich and spent her days posting filtered photos or telling my seven year old daughter she was too fat for dance class. When I miscarried last year, she posted about it on Facebook before I could tell anyone, adding prayer hands, emojis and everything happens for reason while collecting sympathy likes. But now, after five years of her trying to conceive a baby, family suddenly meant everything to her. Her obsession with natural conception had cost them hundreds of thousands of dollars on fertility crystals and moon ceremonies. She refused IVF, calling it artificial poison, and wouldn't consider adoption because she needed to know her child's genetics. During Sunday dinner, she stared at my kids with tears streaming down her face, gripping her husband's hand until her knuckles turned white. That's when mom leaned over and whispered, you know, you have such beautiful children, and you and Rachel share the same DNA. And then two weeks later, the spa day invitation. That should have been my first warning, but I thought maybe she wanted To reconnect. Instead, I walked into her living room to find mom already there, both of them wearing matching silk robes and expectant. We have the perfect solution, Rachel announced, gesturing for me to sit between them. You're going to sleep with Dave and give us a baby naturally, the way nature intended. She said it like she was asking to borrow a cup of sugar, while mom nodded along like this was discussing vacation plan. I couldn't believe I was actually considering it. And Rachel didn't spare a second in sending me ovulation tracking apps and insisting I take fertility tests at her private clinic. She wore me down with daily phone calls and surprise visits, always with mom as backup. But then I found myself sitting in her marble bathroom letting her inject me with hormones. She had me taking supplements that made my skin crawl and my emotions swing wildly. My husband slammed doors and accused me of being insane for even considering it. I moved to his parents house. Well, I just kept hoping she come to her senses. Everything changed the day I was holding laundry and heard her on the phone with her best friend laughing about something. Dave asked for an open marriage last year, she said. My hands froze on a tiny pink shirt. This kills two birds. He gets his variety.

meine kinder wussten nicht was weihnachten ist und das hat mir das herz gebrochen. kurz nach der hochzeit mit meiner frau haben wir unser erstes kind erwartet. ein kleines mädchen. wir hatten schon einen namen ausgesucht, aber einen monat vor dem errechneten termin kam dieser anruf. der schlimmste meines lebens. noch in derselben nacht hab ich sie beide verloren. fünf jahre hab ich gebraucht, um wieder klarzukommen, um überhaupt drüber nachzudenken, noch mal vater zu werden. dann hab ich von zwei kindern gehört, die aus einer richtig schlimmen familie kamen. ich hab sofort die papiere fürs adoptionszentrum ausgefüllt. die beiden hatten jahrelang mit ihrer mutter in einem alten lieferwagen gewohnt. kein richtiges zuhause, keine sicherheit. als sie das erste mal ein warmes bad nehmen konnten und neue klamotten bekommen haben, waren sie komplett aus dem häuschen. das hat mir echt das herz zerrissen. aber das was mich am meisten getroffen hat. als ich sie gefragt hab, was sie sich zu weihnachten wünschen, haben sie mich einfach nur komisch angeschaut. sie wussten nicht mal was weihnachten ist. keine ahnung von weihnachtsmann oder geschenken. als ich ihnen erzählt hab, dass ein mann mit einem roten anzug in der nacht kommt und ihnen was bringt, haben sie nur gelacht. ich mach witze. an heiligabend sind sie ständig ans fenster gerannt. ich dachte sie suchen nach dem weihnachtsmann. ich hab gesagt er kommt erst wenn sie schlafen. aber sie meinten nur, sie schauen nach der polizei, weil die sonst an weihnachten gekommen ist. um. sie mitzunehmen. ich hab versucht, mir nichts anmerken zu lassen, mich umgedreht, damit sie meine tränen nicht sehen. am nächsten morgen bin ich aufgewacht, weil sie so laut gelacht haben. die haben die fußspuren im teppich gesehen, die ich extra gemacht hatte. die milch war weg, die kekse auch. sie haben gestrahlt. die geschenke waren ihnen total egal, sie haben nur nach zehn minuten hat er dann alles zugegeben. seit monaten, meinte er, hatte er heimlich vorstellungsgespräche für einen job in hamburg. wir wohnen in nrw. er wollte den job unbedingt und mich verlassen. aber als ich schwanger wurde, hat er panik bekommen, einen schlussstrich.

mein mitbewohner wollte mich rausschmeißen, weil ich angeblich zu unordentlich bin, bis ich seine perfekte freundin entlarvt habe. mein mitbewohner leo war in letzter zeit irgendwie komisch. kühl drauf, kaum blickkontakt und überall lagen so schnippische zettel rum wie spül mal bitte ab. dabei hatte ich das schon längst gemacht. dann fing seine freundin jana an, ständig vorbeizukommen. die hat mich jedes mal so abschätzig angeguckt, als wär ich dreck. sonntagabend war's dann soweit. leo kam zu mir ins wohnzimmer. ey, wir müssen reden, meinte er ernst. ich leg den controller weg. was ist los? das mit uns als mitbewohner klappt einfach nicht mehr. du bist mega unordentlich. jana meint, das hier ist voll ekelig und mir ist das voll peinlich, wenn leute da sind. ich schau mich um, die wohnung war sauberer als sonst. ich hatte vorher noch alles geputzt. leo, ich hab heute gesaugt, gespült, sogar den müll runtergebracht. ja, aber es geht nicht nur um heute, es ist halt dauernd so. jana fühlt sich hier einfach nicht wohl wegen der unordnung. genau in dem moment kommt jana aus seinem zimmer. wahrscheinlich hatte sie die ganze zeit gelauscht. sorry, ich hab das jetzt mitgehört, sagt sie mit so einem gespielten lächeln. leo will halt ein bisschen mehr. erwachsenen standard. mir platzt fast der kragen. erwachsenen standard, ich zahl die hälfte der miete und mach meistens den haushalt. sie grinst nur. so sieht das aber nicht aus. und seit wann hast du überhaupt was zu sagen bei der wohnsituation? leo geht dazwischen. ich hab schon jemand neues. jemand der besser zu mir passt. du hast bis monatsende zeit. ich starre ihn nur an. wir sind seit dem ersten semester befreundet, wohnen seit zwei jahren zusammen. willst du mich echt rausschmeißen, nur weil deine freundin mich nicht leiden kann? nein, weil du rücksichtslos und widerlich bist, sagt er. in der nacht konnte ich kein auge zu tun. irgendwas war faul. leo hatte sich nie über sauberkeit beschwert, bis jana öfter hier schlief. am nächsten morgen war leo zur arbeit und jana noch da. komisch, weil sie eigentlich morgens uni hat. gegen.

was war das brutalste, was ein elternteil während einer sorgerechtsverhandlung getan hat? ich arbeite als gerichtsschreiberin und habe schon brutale sorgerechtsstreitigkeiten miterlebt. eltern, die ihre kinder als waffen benutzten, sich gegenseitig belogen und ein vermögen für anwälteausgaben, nur um ihrem ex zu schaden. doch letzten monat wurde ich zeugin von etwas, das mir noch immer schlaflose nächte bereitet. dieses paar, sarah und mike, ließ sich nach fünfzehn jahren scheiden. sie hatten die achtjährigen zwillinge luna und jake. die anhörung begann wie alle anderen. anwälte stritten, anschuldigungen flogen um die wette. beide elternteile behaupteten, der jeweils andere sei ungeeignet. dann bat der richter um ein gespräch unter vier augen mit den kindern. luna und jake kamen händchenhaltend herein und wirkten verängstigt. der richter, sonst eher streng, wurde sanfter kinder. ich weiß, das ist beängstigend. könnt ihr mir sagen, was ihr wollt? luna, der mutigere zwilling, meldete sich zu wort. wir wollen zusammen bleiben und wir wollen, dass mama und papa aufhören, so sauer zu sein. jake nickte und flüsterte uns, egal wo wir wohnen, wir wollen einfach, dass alle wieder glücklich sind. der richter fragte, wenn sie sich für einen elternteil entscheiden müssten, bei dem sie leben, wer wäre das? beide kinder fingen an zu weinen. luna sagte, das ist nicht fair, wir lieben sie beide gleich. jetzt wird es herz zerreißend. der richter rief die eltern zurück und wiederholte, was die kinder gesagt hatten. sarah fing sofort an zu schluchzen. mike vergrubt den kopf in den händen einen moment lang. sah es so aus, als könnten sie sich einigen. sarah sah mike mit tränen in den augen an und sagte, vielleicht können wir ihnen zuliebe ein gemeinsames sorgerecht vereinbaren. mike nickte hoffnungsvoll. das fände ich gut. die kinder haben diese scheidung nicht gewollt. doch dann flüsterte sarahs anwalt ihr etwas ins ohr. ihr gesichtsausdruck veränderte sich völlig. sie richtete sich auf und sagte kühl, eigentlich euer ehren habe ich meine meinung geändert. ich möchte das alleinige sorgerecht. mike ist beruflich.

What happens when your fake marriage becomes legally binding? Three years ago, my coworker and I got married in Vegas for a work visa. The plan was brilliant. I needed to stay in the country. He needed my health insurance for his daughter's surgery. Quick courthouse wedding, two years of fooling immigration, then a quiet divorce. We high fived after signing the papers like we just pulled off a heist. We had. The first year was pure performance art. We memorized each other's birthdays, allergies, childhood pets. I Learned he takes his coffee with three sugars. He Learned I sleep on the left side. Immigration interviewed us twice. We passed by knowing things real couples probably didn't. We'd studied each other like a test. His daughter Emma called me daddy's friend even though I was at every soccer game. We had rules. No dating others for two years. Too risky. Separate bedrooms when no one was watching. Joint bank account for show. Separate finances for real. We wore our rings to work and family events. Took them off at home. Mine lived on my keychain, his in his gym bag. Year two, the lines blurred. I started making his coffee without thinking he'd already be on the left side of the couch, leaving my spot open. Emma started calling me by my name instead of daddy's friend. When she got sick. I drove them to the E R. At 3 a m. Without him asking. Stayed for seven hours. That Wasn't for immigration. We joke about our divorce party we throw in. Six months, made a Pinterest Board of freedom cakes. His mom kept asking when we'd give her grandchildren. We'd laugh and say, after the divorce, when she couldn't hear. She never knew it was fake. Still doesn't. Eight months ago, I was offered a job in London. Dream position, triple salary. I said yes immediately. The marriage was almost over anyway. That night he cooked dinner. Real dinner, not our usual takeout. So you're leaving? He said, not looking up from the cutting board. What's the most inaccurate thing your child has ever been taught in school? I picked up my daughter Zoe from school Tuesday afternoon, and when I leaned over to kiss her forehead like I always did, she jerked away. Don't, dad. Miss Novak taught us that when you get kissed, the person's DNA stays inside you for seven years, like you're infected. She said, we're collecting other people's gross stuff and can't ever get it out. Her eyes welled up. Mom kissed me goodbye this morning. Does that mean I have her gross DNA stuck in me now? My hands tightened on the steering wheel. I teach AP biology at the high school across town. And not only was this scientifically false, it was psychologically damaging. That evening, I sent Miss Novak a polite email explaining that I was Zoe's father and a biology teacher, and that DNA from saliva breaks down within hours, not years. Her reply came quickly. Mr. Coleman, it was a simple lesson on DNA and germs. You know, how kids can traumatize things. Wouldn't worry about it. I tried to brush it off, figuring maybe she just misspoken or Zoe had misunderstood. But then Wednesday morning, Zoe refused breakfast, and when I asked why, she pushed her bowl away and said, yesterday Miss Novak was crying in class. She kept talking about this guy she used to date, like, three years ago. She said she can still feel his gross DNA inside her from when They kissed him and she called him a walking contamination or something. I nearly choked on my coffee. She's discussing her ex boyfriend with 12 year olds. Zoe nodded miserably. She was actually crying, dad. She said guys like Brad just want to infect girls with their DNA and then leave them. It was really weird. By Thursday, the parent group chat explode. Multiple children had come home terrified of physical contact. One mother wrote that her daughter wouldn't hug her uncle anymore because Miss Novak said men spread more DNA than women. Another parent said their son was dehydrated because he refused to use the water fountain after Miss Novak said drinking from it was basically like kissing everyone who used it before you, collecting years of their DNA in your mouth. First thing Friday morning, I met with Prince Vazquez alongside three other concerned parents. We presented our concerns about Miss Novak, discussing her personal dating life and teaching false science. The principal reviewed her file and found two previous complaints.

She came home sobbing, mascara running down her

How I exposed my mother in law's custody conspiracy. Three months after my wife died from cancer, my mother in law started going after me. She'd been staying with us to help with my nine year old daughter, Megan. And at first I was thankful, but then. And Megan came to me, twisting her hands together and said, daddy, why does grandma keep asking when we're selling the house and moving somewhere cheap? That should have been my warning sign. The real trouble began when she called CPS herself, telling them I was neglecting Megan and leaving her home alone while I slept all day from depression. The case worker, Miss Lane, showed up with her clipboard already out and her pen clicking. And two days later, my mother in law filed for emergency custody. I tried explaining I work from home, but Lane just kept her eyes on her notepad, scribbling away. And my chest got tight watching her write down whatever story she'd already decided was true. My lawyer, Tom, was the only one who believed my side of things. When I brought him the custody papers, I watched his eyebrows shoot up as he spread them across his mahogany desk, pointing to different sections where my mother in law had brought up the life insurance trust fund three times in documents that were supposed to be about Megan safety. Why would she keep mentioning money and papers about keeping Megan safe? Tom tapped the papers with his Pen and said we needed to look deeper into her motivations. That's when pieces started falling into place. Bought a leather journal and started tracking everything. After Miss UNT. Lane's second surprise visit, the pattern was obvious. Once I started writing it down. Lane would show up unannounced with her clipboard, and somehow my mother in law's silver car would appear within minutes. Every single time, she'd step out with her hand pressed over her heart. Playing the worried grandmother perfectly. Tom's investigator changed everything when he slid that Manila folder across the desk. My mother in law owed $200,000 in tax liens. The dates made my stomach drop. Filed just two months before

Dad moves in, soon to be bride gets pregnant, and she demands I leave the house because she needs my room. I'm 19, working at target during the day and delivering pizzas at night just to afford community college. Dad moved in with his girlfriend Nicole three months ago after losing his apartment when he got fired. The arrangement was supposed to be temporary, just until I get back on my feet, he promised. That was 12 weeks ago, and he spent most of his time on my couch watching Netflix. Yesterday, Nicole storms into my room while I'm trying to study for my accounting midterm. She's got that entitled look she gets when she's about to make unreasonable demands. We need to talk about your living situation. I looked up from my textbook my living situation. With the baby coming in six months, we're going to need your room for the nursery. You're young and flexible. You can sleep anywhere. I stared at her. This woman who contributes exactly zero dollars to household expenses was trying to kick me out of my own bedroom. This is my room, Nicole. She crossed her arms. Not anymore. Your father and I discussed it, and we've decided you can use the garage. We'll get you a space heater for winter. I actually laughed out loud. The garage? Are you completely insane? Don't be dramatic, Lucas. Lots of college kids would love a free place to stay. You should be grateful. Free place? To stay? That's rich, coming from someone who hasn't paid a dime toward anything. That's when inspiration hit me. I pulled out my phone and scrolled to my landlord's number. What are you doing? Nicole asked nervously. I hit dial and put it on speaker. Hi, Mrs. Davis, it's Lucas. Quick question. Whose name is on the lease for this house? Nicole's eyes went wide as she realized what was happening. Just yours, Lucas, like we discussed when you signed it six months ago. Why? Is there a problem? No problem. And who pays the rent every month

I overheard my girlfriend say, he's going to propose tonight. Watch me say no and make him cry. I still took her to the rooftop, got down on one knee, then pulled out her texts with her gym buddy and said loudly, actually, I'm not proposing. I'm here to say goodbye. In front of everyone you tried to impress? This happened three weeks ago, and I'm still processing it. My girlfriend Danielle and I had been together for three years. She's been dropping engagement hints constantly, showing me rings, talking about weddings I've been secretly saving for months. Even picked out a ring. The plan was to propose at her company's rooftop holiday party. Kept mentioning how romantic it would be with the city lights and all her co workers there. But last Tuesday changed everything. I came home early from my hospital shift. I heard Danielle on Facetime upstairs, laughing. Melissa, he's definitely doing it at the party tomorrow. He's been acting all secretive. I stopped on the stairs. That's exciting. Are you ready? Her sister asked. Here's the thing. I'm saying no right in front of everyone. My blood went cold. Danielle. What? Why? He needs a reality check. Plus, you know Anthony from Crossfit? He just started his own business. Way more ambitious than a nurse. Anthony? The guy she'd been training with three nights a week? You're really going to humiliate him at your work party? Picture this. All my co workers watching. He gets down, On one knee. And I just say, sorry, but no. Maybe he'll understand. He can't coast through life helping sick people all day. They both giggled. I quietly went to my car and sat there for an hour. That night. Danielle was all over me. Babe, I love you so much. All I could think about was her planning my destruction. Wednesday morning, her phone buzzed with a text from Anthony. Can't wait to celebrate tomorrow. She'd left it unlocked. I scrolled through their messages.

What's the easiest hundred dollars you've ever made in your life? This scrawny kid named Georgie slipped a hundred dollar Bill into my hand during lunch and told me it was mine if I beat up Carson Block. I almost spit out my chocolate milk. Carson was the biggest eighth grader anyone had ever seen. He looked like he spent time in prison and was pitching, not catching G, if you know what I mean. The kid was six feet tall with arms thicker than my legs. Meanwhile, Georgie was maybe 90 pounds, soaking wet, with these skinny arms that look like twigs. His left arm was in a homemade sling made from an old T-shirt. I stared at the money, thinking this had to be some kind of joke. Nobody in their right mind would pay someone to fight Carson. The kid had put three seventh graders in the nurse's office just this month. I'm pretty sure the security guards were scared of him. But Georgie's eyes were dead serious and kind of desperate. Why me? I asked. Because you're the only one who stands a chance. You knocked out that ninth grader last year who was messing with your sister. That was different, though. That kid had been picking on my little sister for weeks. This felt random and weird. Plus, a hundred bucks was more money than I'd ever seen a middle schooler carry around. Georgie must have noticed my confusion because he leaned in closer. Please, I've been saving up for months. Nobody else will do it. Something about the way he said it made me pause. This wasn't about showing off or some stupid dare. Georgie looks scared but determined. I pocketed the money and told him to meet me after school to explain what was really going on. We sat on the bleachers by the empty football field. Georgie kept glancing around like he was worried someone would see us talking. Up close, I could see bruises on his neck that looked a few days old. His homemade sling was because he couldn't afford a real doctor. Carson and his dad moved in with us two months ago. Georgie finally said his dad is dating

Have you ever been in a love triangle? I rejected my childhood friend for his brother, and now, 12 years later, I'm the one trying to win him back. I missed my best friend, Gavin, and I never got to tell him. Not after I heard him so badly he stopped talking to me and his own family. Why not just get him to forgive you? My mom asked, handing me Rex's wedding invitation. His brother, the guy I chose over Gavin 12 years back. F it, why not? It was there that I saw him the first time in years. Gavin, now taller, breathtaking and cold. I smiled and waved at him, but he looks right through me during the rehearsal dinner, like I was wallpaper. Just walk. Don't look at me, don't talk to me, Gavin said during the practice run. Should we at least try to pretend we're okay? He replied sharply. I've been pretending you don't exist for 12 years. One more day won't kill me. He sat far from me at dinner, left when I entered rooms, hopped over me when I tripped, and fell flat on my face. Even when Rex joked about baby brother, old crush, Gavin just yawned as if he was bored. Even thinking about me, it hurt, but all I could think was how he used to wait for me after school, carrying me on his back. When I got hurt at the wedding, my first goal was to get Near him, I switched our place cards, only to watch him switch seats. I wrote I'm sorry I called you a liar on a napkin and slipped it under his water glass. He looked at it, looked back at me, then used it to wipe up spilled champagne. Every plan failed spectacularly, but one thing did. Pick away at the ice around him. When a bridesmaid started crying, I sat on the floor with her, fixed her makeup, and made her laugh through the tears. I glanced up and Gavin was in the doorway, watching with a soft smile. I looked away, embarrassed, but when I looked back, he was gone. A lost opportunity that made me want to bang my head on the table. By eleven PM, I knew I blew it. I drank down a glass of champagne and sat in the back of the room, feeling sad and best friendless. I watched the groom, Rex, stand up to give his drunk and sloppy speech. Thank you all for coming here. And thanks also to my ex. He pointed at me. I sat up straight.

How normal she looked. Mom tilted her head. Hospital? What are you talking about? I haven't been to a doctor in months. My last checkup was in March, and everything was fine. The flowers slipped out of my hand. But Kevin said you had heart problems and needed surgery. Heart problems? Mom laughed. Honey, I've been working in my garden all week. Yesterday I moved three bags of mulch by myself. Where did Kevin get that idea? That's when it hit me. Kevin had played me. He'd used Mom's health to scam me out of $2,000. And he knew exactly which buttons to push. He knew I'd feel guilty about not calling mom enough. I called Kevin immediately, hands shaking from anger. Hey, man, how's mom doing? I asked, giving him a chance to come clean. Oh, much better. The doctor said she can rest at home now. Thanks again for helping out. Funny thing, Kevin. I'm standing in mom's kitchen right now, and she says she's never been to any hospital. Dead silence. Look, I can explain, he started. Mom, come here for a second, I said. I put the phone on speaker. Kevin wants to tell you about your hospital visit. What hospital visit? Mom asked loudly. Kevin, what is going on? Kevin tried to spin some story about how mom must have forgotten because of stress. But mom wasn't having it. She tore into him right there on speaker phone, asking how he could lie about her Health. To steal money from his own brother? That's when Kevin finally broke down and admitted it. He spent the money on a weekend trip to Vegas with his girlfriend, Ashley. He'd blown it all on poker and expensive dinners. You used my fake death to fund your vacation? Mom was furious. Are you insane? When

When has someone tried to guilt trip you? My brother Kevin had been asking me for money since we were teenagers, and I'd always said yes. The guy borrowed, like, $50 here, $100 there, and somehow never remembered to pay me back. But this was different. I was eating cereal and watching Netflix on a Tuesday night when my phone rang. Kevin was crying actual tears, which freaked me out because he never cried about anything. Dude, you gotta help me, he said between sobs. Mom's in the hospital, and they're saying if we don't pay these bills right now, they're gonna stop her treatment. My stomach dropped. I hadn't talked to mom in, like, two weeks because work had been crazy. The guilt hit me like a truck. What happened? Is she okay? I asked, already reaching for my laptop to check my bank account. Heart problems, Kevin said. The doctor say it's serious and they need $2,000 today or they're transferring her to some crappy public hospital. I already spent everything I had on the ambulance ride. I felt like the worst son ever. While I was sitting there watching stupid shows, mom was suffering and I didn't even know. Kevin kept talking about how scared he was and how mom didn't want to worry me because she knew I was stressed with my new job. Send me your Venmo, I said. I didn't even think twice. I transferred $2,000 that was supposed to be for my car. Payment. Kevin was so grateful, thanking me over and over. He promised he'd pay me back as soon as insurance kicked in. I felt better knowing I'd helped, but the guilt was still eating at me. Three days later, I drove to Mom's house with flowers and soup. I figured she'd be resting at home by now. When I knocked, mom answered the door, looking perfectly fine, like she was wearing her garden

What's the most genius way you've dealt with a controlling partner and actually got them to stop? I admit it. I messed up. I had forgotten my phone was on silent, and so for two hours straight, I sweated my butt off on Smash Bros. At my friend's house and forgot to text my girlfriend Cindy back. So when I finally saw her, 15 missed calls, she was furious. I need to know you're actually where you say you are, she said. But I already sent you my location and a picture of us on the coach. It's not enough. What if there are girls hiding behind you on the couch? Or what if it's just an old picture? I'm not stupid. From now on, when you're out, we video call so I can see. Or you can wake up single the next day. She hung up, practically foaming at the mouth. The first few calls were painfully awkward. I'd have to go around the house, introduce each of my friends to her, basically give her a house tour to show it's all clear before she hang up. And randomly call again in the next hour or so to make sure I didn't change locations or invited over girls to my friend's house. After a few days like this, everyone was going crazy over her rule. My friend Jeff pulled me to the side with a concerned look. Dude, honestly, if she's gonna act crazy, you gotta do it, too. That's when it came to me. A brilliant idea. The next time I was at Jeff's house, I answered Cindy's call in my best David Attenborough voice. Here we observe the male human in his natural habitat. Approaching the buffalo wings with caution, I slowly turned the camera towards my friends, who immediately caught on and started acting like wildlife. In the background, dinner was pretending to be a gazelle and Jeff was chest beating like a gorilla. Very funny, Cindy said, rolling her eyes at us. The next Friday, we took it further. I answered the call holding a microphone, reading out a fake weather forecast, while Jeff held up a map glued to a pizza box. Currently, we're experiencing a high pressure system of Mario Kart moving through the living room area, I announced. Temperatures are rising as we travel through Rainbow Road. Now back to you, Cindy. Stop being weird.

I was 32 at the time with no kids of my own, and my husband Mike was completely on board. We figured we'd give Jalen the stable home he deserved after bouncing between foster homes for two years. Ellen was this quiet, serious kid who'd seen way too much for his age. He'd flinch whenever we raised our voices, even if we were just calling him for dinner from the other room. It took months before he'd laugh at my terrible dad jokes or let us hug him without going stiff. But slowly, he started opening up. He'd help Mike in the garage on weekends, asked me to pack extra snacks for school, started calling us mom and dad around his 10th birthday. For years, everything was perfect. Helen made good grades, played baseball in middle school, had friends over for sleepovers. We never hid his adoption from him, but he seemed completely settled with us. When he turned 16, I taught him to drive in our old Honda Civic. Mike took him fishing every summer. We were a real family. But then his senior year, something changed. When I asked what was wrong, he said some guy named Carlos had messaged him on Instagram, claiming to be his older half brother. My stomach dropped. What's the one sentence your kids said that instantly silenced a whole room? I was at one of those chaotic indoor play places for my son Leo's seventh birthday party. He'd spent the entire hour at the ticket spewing Jackpot game, his face a mask of pure concentration. Finally, he hit the grand prize. A river of 1,000 tickets poured out of the machine. He was ecstatic, clutching the massive paper snake to his chest like a holy relic. That's when I saw him. A little boy, maybe five years old, pointed at Leo's tickets. I want that one. His father, a guy in an expensive tracksuit who'd been on his phone the whole time, came over. He didn't look at me, only at the tickets. Hey, my son wants those, let him have them. I was genuinely stunned. I'm sorry, what? My son just won these. The dad let out a long breath like I was a massive inconvenience. Look, he's having a meltdown. Just give him the tickets. The kids birthday party. They need to learn to share, right? I stared at him. No, he saved his tokens. All party to win this. He's not giving it away. He raised his voice loud enough for the other parents at our party table to hear. Are you serious? You're going to let your kid be selfish over a bunch of worthless paper? What kind of values are you teaching him? I could feel the blood in my cheeks. Kind Of values where you don't hand over your things just because someone throws a tantrum. Now he was practically yelling, my son is having a bad day. You're raising a spoiled brat who doesn't care about other people's feelings. His son was still screaming. And now other families were starting to stare at the scene he was creating. Leo had been watching the whole thing. He looked from the screaming boy to the angry father, then down at his precious roll of tickets. The father saw his chance and knelt down, his voice sickly sweet. Hey, little man.

They said I was too small for football, so I made them regret every word. On championship night, I was 5 feet 6 inches and 145 pounds as a high school freshman. The size of a decent seventh grader. My dad's jeans had cursed me with a body better suited for cross country than contact sports. But I didn't wanna run in circles. I wanted to play football. Coach Morris looked at me like I was roadkill when I showed up for tryouts. 30 seconds into my first drills, I heard it. Wilson, what are you doing here? The chess club meets in the library. The team erupted in laughter. Kept my mouth shut. Finish the drill. You're gonna get yourself killed out here, kid. Coach said afterward, why don't you try something else? Maybe track? I looked him straight in the eye. I wanna play. He sighed. Fine. You can be equipment manager, help with practice. Maybe in a few years, if you grow. So that's what I did. I washed jerseys, fixed helmets, set up cones and filled water bottles while the actual players got to play. After everyone left, I'd run the same drills they did. I set up tackling dummies and hit them until my shoulders ache. I studied playbooks like they were sacred tech. Junior year, I grown two inches and added 20 pounds of muscle. Still small, but solid. I tried out again. This time I didn't just run drills. I demolished them. My 40 yard dash was second fastest on the team. My route running was precise. My hands never dropped a pass. Not bad, coach admitted. But this isn't a practice drill. This is varsity football. Those guys across town would snap you like a twig. He put me on special teams. The Suicide Squad. Just bodies to throw at kick returns. First game of the season, I flew down the field on kickoff, weaving through blockers twice my size, and made a tackle that echoed through the stadium. The crowd erupted. Coach ignored it, called it lucky. Then I did it again the next game. And the next. By mid season, I forced two fumbles on kick returns. Fans started chanting will, son! Will, son! Whenever kickoff came. Except for Brandon Reeves, our star quarterback and the coach's godson. 6 foot 3, college scouts at every game. Arrogance as big as his arm. He made it his mission to.

My sister Emma is 25, dropped out of college twice, and still lives in mom's basement. Last month she announced she's pregnant with some guy named Dave, already has three kids with two different women, and works part time at a gas station. Yesterday, mom calls saying they want to stop by and see how I've decorated the place. She's never cared about my decorating before, but now she insisted on bringing Emma along. They show up at 6 p m. With measuring tape, notebooks, and Emma's carrying a folder full of paint samples. I thought maybe Emma wanted decorating tips for her own future place. Boy, was I wrong. Emma immediately starts walking through every room like she's conducting a home inspection. She's measuring doorways and windows with her phone app, taking photos of electrical outlets, and making notes about where the crib would go. And this would be perfect for a nursery. She even opens my closets and starts talking about storage space for baby clothes. Mom sitting on my couch like she's conducting a business meeting, nodding approvingly at everything Emma says. Every few minutes, she'd call out suggestions like, don't forget to measure for the changing table and check if that window gets good morning light. After 30 minutes, Of this increasingly weird behavior. I finally asked what was going on. Mom puts down her notebook and drops the nuke. We've been doing a lot of thinking about Emma's situation lately. She needs a stable environment for the baby. And honestly, you're single with all this extra space. It just makes perfect sense when you really think about it. I'm standing there confused. When she continues without missing a beat. Emma's going to move in next month with Dave, and they'll start.

That single afternoon turned me into their unpaid nanny for the next 12 years. My sister would drop off her toddler for just an hour while she ran to target. One hour became three, then six, until she'd stroll back with fresh acrylic nails, a Starbucks Frappuccino, and zero apologies. I remember sitting on my bedroom floor surrounded by broken crayons and goldfish crackers, realizing I'd missed my entire shift at the local coffee shop because of her lies. Then my brother discovered the family gold mine. Midnight texts became routine. Emergency babysitting needed. The twins, regular sitter canceled. Of course, the emergency was always tickets to concerts, bar crawls, or weekend getaways with his girlfriend. I Learned to sleep with my phone on silent. College should have been my escape, but my family had other plans. My sister would show up unannounced at my dorm, sometimes driving four hours just to dump her kids on me for entire weekends. He cost me my first serious girlfriend when she called during our anniversary dinner screaming about a fake emergency. I watched her look at me across that candlelit table and say she couldn't compete with my family's chaos anymore. After graduation, things got worse. I dragged myself home from my marketing job exhausted from client presentations, only to find my living room transformed into a daycare center, toys scattered everywhere, juice boxes leaking on my white couch, and kids I hadn't even agreed to watch. My boss pulled me aside after I missed my third important presentation.

When did your girlfriend's family realize you weren't just a bartender? I'm 32 and my girlfriend's parents still think I'm pouring cheap beer at some dive bar. We've been together two years, but every family dinner felt like a job interview. I was failing. Last night was her father's retirement party. Three hundred guests at the country club. At the entrance, her mother looked at my watch and frowned. The coat check had a lost and found if you need something more appropriate. It was a ten thousand dollar Rolex. He assumed it was fake. During cocktail hour, her mother dragged me around. This is Doctor Morrison, Judge Williams, then me. This is my daughter's boyfriend. He works in the service industry. Her Aunt Patricia asked what exactly I did. Before I could speak, her mother said he pours drinks beer, mostly downtown somewhere. Patricia touched my arm sympathetically and asked about my career goals. Father interrupted me by the bar. You parked in the member lot. Staff and vendors use the back entrance. The guard mentioned your car doesn't have a member sticker. I drove a hundred thousand dollar Mercedes. He assumed I'd Stolen the spot. Then he pulled up his phone. There's a management training program at this restaurant chain. Six week course. I know the regional director. He showed me the application. Thirty five thousand to start, but it's steady. At dinner, they put us at table 23, near the service station. Her parents sat at the head table under a chandelier. Her father gave his retirement speech. He thanked his colleagues, praised his children's accomplishments. When he mentioned my girlfriend, he said, still waiting for her to find someone worthy of the family name. He stared at me while the room chuckled. After dessert, her parents ambushed us by the restrooms. Her mother had printed emails from her friend's husband. He owns several franchises. Fast food. But management track. 40,000 to start. My phone exploded with notification.

Out on bail, Bianca's harassment escalated. Her mother showed up with a printed invoice demanding 90 thousand dollars for emotional damages and loss of future earnings as a married woman. When I said we were done, she went nuclear swinging her purse at me while I recorded. Again, Bianca tried using my memorized credit card information for a three thousand dollar purchase to her parents house. The fraud department caught it. She showed up at my workplace claiming a family emergency, then made another scene when security escorted her out. That night she posted Instagram photos doing shots with the caption single and ready to mingle. X was abusive. During court proceedings, she arrived in a white dress with a fake arm sling and wheelchair. The judge reviewed all evidence, a video, security footage, witness statements, fraud attempts. When given a chance to speak, she said he ruined my life. He's always been controlling with money. He made me sign prenups and everything. You weren't married? The judge noted there was no prenup. Well, he would have made me sign one. That shows what kind of person he is. The judge looked exhausted. Miss, you're charged with false reporting an assault, not theoretical future prenups. Guilty on both charges. 200 hours community service, anger management classes, 5,000 dollar fine, 2 year restraining order, 1 year probation. She violated the restraining order by hiring her cousin Anthony to vandalize my car with baseball bats. Security cameras caught them, leading to her Second arrest for conspiracy. Final court appearance 120 days in jail, three years probation, $15,000 in fine. Five year restraining order. Her mother lost her job and marriage. Anthony got 18 months in prison. Bianca now works minimum wage because employers Google her arrest video. Click here to watch what happened next!

But here's the thing that really made me laugh. When I was packing up the kitchen stuff, I realised I'd bought all the cooking supplies too. The pans, the good knife set, even the can opener. My mom texted me at midnight. Write that you want to end your life when you're at Dad's house. I stared at my phone screen, reading it three times. Mom and dad had been separated for six months. The custody battle was getting ugly. I was 14, splitting time between their apartments, and everything felt broken. Then my phone buzzed again. Call me now. Mom's voice was desperate when I answered. Did you see my text? Yeah. What the hell are you asking me to do? Your father is winning. His lawyer destroyed me in court today. I need evidence that you're not safe with him. My chest tightened. Mom, you want me to fake suicide notes? Not a suicide note. A journal entry. The therapist appointment is tomorrow. Doctor Rossi needs to see that you have these thoughts at his place. Her voice got urgent. Right. That you stare at his sleeping pills count and you think about taking them when he's asleep. Mom, stop. Listen to me. If I don't get full custody, your father loses his health insurance through my job. You know he needs insulin. It's $800 a month without coverage. She paused. He's already rationing. You've seen it. You can't use his diabetes against me. I'm using it for him. If you write this, I get custody, and I'll keep him on my insurance for the whole year. Even after the divorce. I sat on my bed feeling sick. Dad had been rationing his insulin. I'd seen him skip doses, checking his blood sugar, obsessively trying to stretch his supplies. Last week, his hands were shaking so bad he couldn't open a water. Water bottle. I can't write that I want to die. You're not actually suicidal. It's just words on paper. Write that being at his apartment makes you feel hopeless. That you think about ending it. That you wonder if anyone would care. She was crying now. Please, his help. The next morning, she showed up at Dad's apartment while he was at work. She handed me a notebook and a folded paper. Copy this in your handwriting. I opened her notes. The words made me nauseous. I think about ending it. I wonder if anyone would care. When I'm at his apartment, I imagine taking all 47 of his pills. He wouldn't find me until morning. Mom, this is insane. This is necessary. Your therapist already knows you keep a journal. I told her last week you've been

I let my daughter dye her hair blue. My sister called me a bad mom until her kid told me the truth. When Emma asked if she could dye her hair blue for her 13th birthday, I said, sure, it's just hair, right? She'd been begging me for weeks, showing me Pinterest photos of these gorgeous ocean blue highlights at target. We picked out some semi permanent dye that would wash out in a month. She was so excited she could barely sit still while I painted the streaks in our tiny bathroom. The next morning at breakfast, she kept flipping her hair and grinning at herself in the toaster reflection. I made her favorite blueberry pancakes and she kept saying how the blue and her hair match the berries perfectly. honestly the happiest I'd seen her since her dad moved out last year. But when we showed up at my sister Beth's house for Sunday dinner, everything went sideways fast. Beth took one look at Emma and her face just dropped. He pulled me into the kitchen while Emma was playing with her cousins and started going off about how irresponsible I was being. What kind of message does this send, she whispered harshly, gesturing toward the living room. She's going to look like some delinquent at school. I tried explaining it was just temporary hair dye, that Emma was still getting straight A's and playing violin, but Beth wouldn't hear it. She kept shaking her head. And muttering about how I was clear, really struggling as a single mom and needed to set better boundaries. The whole dinner was awkward after that with Beth making passive aggressive comments about certain parent choices every time Emma's hair caught the light. When we got home that night, Emma seemed deflated. She kept touching her hair and asking if I thought it looked stupid. I reassured her it looked amazing. But I could tell Beth's reaction had gotten to her. That's when I decided to call my mom to vent about the whole thing. I'm listened patiently while I ranted about Beth being judgmental. Then she got quiet for a moment. Honey, she said carefully, there's something you should probably know about your sister's situation. Apparently, Beth had been calling.

My roommate's boyfriend announced I had to move out immediately. The landlord started laughing. My roommate's boyfriend, Wesley, had been planning this moment for months, ever since he started staying over back in June. He'd been telling his boys about how he was finessing his way into a free apartment. He even started forwarding his mail here to establish what he called residency rights. The relationship wasn't even official before Wesley started making his move. He'd walk around my apartment, well, what he thought was going to be his apartment, measuring room and telling his cousin which wall would be perfect for his TV setup. Melanie's been carrying this dead weight for too long, he'd mutter while eating my groceries. Time for her to learn she doesn't need a roommate anymore. So there I was, standing in my own living room on a Thursday night. The whole place smelled like the Cologne Wesley bathed in. Wesley showed up with his cousin Mitchell and two duffel bags, already acting like he owned the place, both of them looking like they were ready to physically move me out if needed. Melanie, I hope you found somewhere else to stay, Wesley said, dropping his bags by the door. This is happening tonight. You've been taking advantage of my girl's kindness for long enough. I stayed quiet, scrolling through my phone, let him have his moment. Melanie sat on the couch, avoiding eye contact with everyone. Wesley had been working on her for weeks. Convincing her that I was holding her back, that they needed their privacy, that couples shouldn't have roommates. She'd started parroting his words recently. Maybe it's time for a change. Maybe we've outgrown this arrangement. Classic Wesley manipulation. The man didn't even have his own place. He'd been couch surfing before he latched onto Melanie. Wesley pulled out a crumpled piece of paper from his pocket. I printed out this 30 day notice. But honestly, you should just go tonight. Make this easy on everyone. Mitchell nodded like this was all perfectly legal. Smart move, Wesley. She's had a free ride.

What happened when your sister made you ask out her best friend to prom? My sister burst into my room and blocked the door, screaming, please just take Angie to prom. She's been crying about going alone. I stared at her from my desk chair and said, this has disaster written all over it. Three weeks before prom, my sister sat on my bed and launched into her pitch. Angie's been rejected by four different guys. She won't eat lunch anymore, just hides in the library. She pulled up Angie's Instagram, showing months of deleted photos. She's been my best friend since fifth grade, and now she's talking about not even going to prom. Would it kill you to ask her? The guilt was working. Angie had practically lived at our house growing up, always laughing at my dumb jokes, always bringing homemade cookies. She needs one good night before graduation. I felt my stomach not up, but agreed to try. Finding her alone in the library was easy. I walked over nervously and cleared my throat. Hey, Angie, would you maybe want to go to prom with me? She looked up, shocked, her book dropping, are you serious? When I nodded, she whispered, yes, eyes bright with disbelief. The week before prom, we went corsage shopping together at the local florist. Angie kept touching every flower nervously. I don't know anything about corsages. Is white too boring? I picked up a bright orange one and held it against her Wrist. How about traffic cone orange? She laughed and pushed my hand away. That's hideous. We spent 20 minutes making increasingly ridiculous suggestions until the florist looked ready to kick us out. Angie finally chose a simple white rose with baby his breath. So pretty, I said, looking at her. Prom night came too fast. At her house, her mom positioned us for photos by the staircase. Her dad joined her mom with his professional camera. Turn your head slightly left. No, your other left, Angie muttered. There's only one left, dad. I tried not to laugh, but failed. Start over. You're both laughing, her mom scolded. We took approximately 700 photos. Angie's face hurt from fake smiling. I looked arranged in all of these, she said, scrolling through them. Her little brother photo bombed the last few, making bunny ears behind us. At least those are honest, Angie said. In the

At the airport, a woman shoved her baby into my arms and said, please just hold her until I come back. Don't let anyone take her. I okay. I stood there frozen while she vanished into the airport crowd without looking back. The baby was maybe 8 months old, wearing a yellow onesie with ducks on it, and he gripped my shirt with her tiny fist like we've done this before. Other passengers started staring immediately. An older couple whispered to each other while a businessman looked up from his laptop. The baby smelled like vanilla lotion and stayed weirdly calm, just watching me with huge brown eyes. Thirty seconds had passed, but it already felt like an hour. What kind of mother just hands her baby to a complete stranger? Five minutes in and the baby started that pre cry whimpering. That meant I had maybe 30 seconds before full meltdown. I tried bouncing her while making shushing sounds, but nothing worked. People were really staring now, some moving away from us like we had something contain ages. An older woman wearing a World's Best Grandma sweatshirt came over and said, honey, did she just leave you with her baby? I explained she said she'd be right back, but grandma shook her head with this knowing look. Maybe she abandoned it. People do crazy things at airports. You should find security. The baby chose that moment to go full Siren mode with that piercing cry that makes everyone in A 50, but radius wins. I walked in circles trying to calm her, but she just screamed louder. My arms were already getting sore. Where the hell was this woman? The grandmother suggested maybe I should take the baby to the information desk, but something about the mother's desperation made me stay put. At the 10 minute Mark, I noticed a man in a navy suit standing by the windows, pretending to look at planes, but watching us in the reflection. When I shifted the baby to my other arm, his head turned slightly to track our

What's the most disrespectful thing someone did at your parents funeral? My dad died last March after battling cancer for two years. The whole thing was brutal, watching him slowly waste away. My mom became a shell of herself during those final months. We all pulled together as a family except for my brother Chet. He had been the black sheep for years before dad got sick. Chet had stolen money from dad and dropped out of college three times. He refused to get a job or take any responsibility for his life. Dad finally cut him off financially last year after Chet stole $30,000. He took the money straight from their retirement account without asking anyone. When dad passed away, Chet showed up at the funeral home acting devastated. He even volunteered to handle the gravestone paperwork to help mom out. We were all shocked, but thought maybe losing dad had changed him. Mom was barely functioning, so we let Chet handle the Monument arrangements. We had already picked out the inscription. Together as a family. Family. It would say. Beloved father and husband forever in our hearts. The words were simple and classic. Exactly what dad would have wanted. The funeral came and went without any major incidence. Chet gave a speech about redemption and family that made everyone cry. For three weeks after the funeral, we thought he'd finally grown up. Mom even started talking about reconciling with him. She kept saying, dad would have wanted the Family to stay together. Then the day of the gravestone unveiling arrived three weeks later. Mom had been counting down to this moment since the funeral ended. She desperately needed that closure and permanent place to visit dad. My other brother, Simon, drove her to the cemetery that morning. I met them there with fresh flowers for the grave. Chet said he'd meet us there, but texted that he was running late. The cemetery worker LED us to Dad's lot in the memorial garden section. A black cloth covered the new granite stone that had just been installed. Mom was already crying while clutching
