I told my wife she makes traveling no fun. My wife Rachel and I have been married eight years, and every single year she insists on driving 12 hours to visit her family in California. I live in Colorado, so it's not exactly a quick trip. When we first got married, we'd fly out there, but ever since our daughter Mia turned 2, Rachel decided we had to drive because it's safer for kids. The thing is, Rachel Overpacks like we're moving there permanently. I'm talking about filling our entire SUV from floor to ceiling. We upgraded from my old Honda to a massive Chevy Suburban specifically because she complained about not having enough space. Guess what happened? She filled that thing up, too. I literally can't see out my side mirrors because she stacks stuff that high and we don't use 90% of what she brings. Packs like five different outfits for every single day we're there. Last time she brought an entire tote bag just filled with towels because she doesn't trust hotel towels. Another tote bag with blankets because hotel comforters are gross. She even packed our coffee maker because she doesn't like the hotel coffee. The worst part isn't even the over packing, though. It's that she's always three hours late to everything. I'll tell her we need to leave at 10 in the morning to make good time. She'll roll out of bed at 11:30, take an hour to get ready, then suddenly remember she Needs to pack the car. We never actually leave until past noon. Then she wants to drive until midnight to make up for lost time. I'm stuck driving 12 hours straight while she's in the passenger seat telling me I'm going too slow or too fast. The drive becomes this miserable Marathon where we're both exhausted and cranky. This past weekend was supposed to be different though. My company sent me to a conference in Vegas. Nice resort, great location.
NA

My boyfriend wants a paternity test on our Newborn daughter. I just gave birth to my daughter Emma three weeks ago. The entire pregnancy was rough, but I thought the worst part was behind me until my boyfriend Jake dropped a bomb on me in the hospital recovery room while I was still hooked up to IV's and barely able to walk to the bathroom without wincing. He starts pacing around my bed like he's got something major to confess. I'm thinking he's gonna tell me his mom's coming to visit or something normal. Instead, he looks me dead in the eyes and says he wants a paternity test on our three week old daughter. The daughter I literally just pushed out of my body after 18 hours of labor. I stared at him for like 10 seconds thinking he was joking. When I realized he wasn't, I asked him why the hell he would need a paternity test. He starts rambling about how Emma doesn't look like him and how babies are supposed to look like their dads. Emma has dark hair and Jake's blonde. That's literally it. That's his entire reasoning. Never mind that my entire family has dark hair, including me. Never mind that most babies don't look like anyone specific when they're brand new. But it gets worse. He pulls out his phone and starts showing me Google searches about paternity fraud. Apparently he's been researching this for weeks. While I was pregnant. While I was Throwing up every morning and couldn't sleep because of heartburn and swollen feet. I told him he was being ridiculous and that I've never cheated on him once in our two year relationship. I don't even have guy friends he doesn't know about. My whole world has basically been work, him and preparing for this baby. He gets all defensive and says it's not about trust, it's about being sure that any responsible father would want to know for certain. That he's seen too many stories online about men raising kids that weren't theirs. The nurse walked in right as I started crying, and Jake immediately shuts up and pretends to be the supportive boyfriend. As soon as she leaves, he starts up again about how this is normal and lots of couples.

I told my in laws to get a job. My husband's parents showed up at our place last year asking if they could crash for a couple weeks. Their landlord was being a complete ass and wasn't fixing their heating, so they needed somewhere warm to stay while they figured things out. I felt bad for them, honestly. It was December and freezing cold outside. Two weeks turned into six months real quick. They set up camp in our living room with their air mattress and started treating our house like their personal hotel. His mom would sleep until noon every day. While I was getting ready for work, she'd shuffle to the kitchen in her pajamas and complain that we didn't have the right coffee creamer or that our Wi-Fi was too slow for her shows. His dad wasn't any better. He'd sit on our couch all day watching those weird conspiracy theory videos on YouTube with the volume cranked up. I work from home three days a week and couldn't focus on anything with him yelling at the T V. About lizard people or whatever. The worst part was dinner time. They expected me to cook for four people every single night, but never offered to help or buy groceries. I'd come home exhausted from work, and his mom would be like, oh, good, you're home. I'm starving. What's for dinner? Meanwhile, she spent the whole day doing absolutely nothing. I started keeping track of our grocery Bill. And it literally doubled. They were eating us out of house and home. His dad would finish entire boxes of cereal for breakfast, and his mom would make these huge sandwiches with, like, half a loaf of bread. When I brought it up to my husband, he just shrugged and said, they're going through a tough time. We need to be patient. But patient for what, exactly? Neither of them were even looking for jobs. They weren't apartment hunting. They weren't doing anything except making our lives miserable. The breaking point was when I found his mom going through our mail. She was sitting at our kitchen table with our bank statements spread out, looking at our account balances. When I asked what she was

What's something your child has done that you're going to talk about forever? My daughter Ellie, at 16, started a small business making custom jewelry, mostly earrings and bracelets. She sold at local craft fairs and built a steady following online. Nothing crazy, just enough money to save up for college. Last summer, another mom from Ellie's school, Becky, ordered matching bracelets for herself and her daughters. Simple job. Ellie finished them in a day. Two weeks later, Becky showed up at our door, red faced and furious. He demanded Ellie refund her immediately, yelling about a severe allergic reaction caused by the bracelets. Ellie was mortified and apologized profusely, quickly refunding Becky. I didn't think much of it until Becky started bad mouthing Ellie online, tanking her reputation and ending the business overnight. I was angry, but let it go. Six months later, I ran into Becky's husband at the pharmacy. He saw me buying allergy medication and asked if I was okay. Confused, I mentioned Becky's bracelet reaction. He paused, then laughed bitterly. Bracelets? Becky never wore them. She sold them online. She used the money to buy diet pills that put her in the hospital. Turns out Becky had blamed Ellie to hide her secret shopping addiction from her husband. Ellie never restarted her business, but Becky's marriage imploded, accurately for the world. Danny and I had been getting close again, but we didn't want to rush anything. Then I got pregnant with Jake at 32, and We both cried when we found out. Happy tears, but also terrified tears. Because what if the cancer came back? It did. When Jake was two. I felt that same exhaustion creeping in. This time it was worse.

I told my fiance my stepdaughter isn't mine. Sort it yourself. My fiance Marcus had this nine year old daughter named Kayla from his previous marriage. The kid was honestly pretty sweet when it was just the three of us hanging out, but the second her mom came into the picture, everything went to hell. Marcus and his ex wife had this weird custody thing where they never actually talk to each other directly. Everything went through Kayla, which was already messed up enough. But then his ex started using me as her personal messenger service. It started small. She'd text me instead of Marcus about pickup times or if Kayla forgot her backpack. I thought she was just being friendly at first, trying to include me since I was going to be Kayla's stepmom soon. But then it got weird. She'd send me these long messages about how Kayla was acting up at her house, how she needed new school clothes, how Marcus wasn't paying enough child support, stuff that had nothing to do with me. When I tell Marcus about it, he just shrug and say his ex was crazy and to ignore her. The breaking point came last Tuesday. I was at work when my phone started blowing up. Kayla's mom was texting me non stop because apparently Kayla had gotten in trouble at school for hitting another kid. The principal had called both parents, but Marcus wasn't answering his phone because he was in meetings all Day so his ex decides that I need to leave work immediately and go handle it. She's sending me message after message telling me I need to go pick up Kayla, that she can't leave her job, that this is what being a stepmom means. She even said I was being selfish for not dropping everything. I looked at my phone and just lost it. I texted back exactly what I was thinking. I told her that Kayla isn't my daughter, I'm not married to Marcus yet, and I'm not responsible for fixing their parenting disasters. I said she needed to figure out her own custody drama and leave me out of it. She immediately called Marcus screaming about how I was abandoning his daughter.

I refused to wake up my husband when my parents visited. And kicking them out when they insisted. My husband Tyler, had been working 18 hour days for three weeks straight. Some department at his company completely screwed up and cost them $50 million. So his team had to fix everything. I'm talking coming home at two in the morning, eating cold leftovers, showering and passing out. Some nights I'd find him literally sleeping face first in his dinner plate or passed out on the bathroom floor with the shower still running. Two nights ago, he finally stumbled through the door around midnight with this huge grin on his exhausted face. We did it, he said. Boss gave us the rest of the week off. He ate some leftover pizza, took the world's quickest shower and was snoring before his head hit the pillow. Next morning around 9, I made breakfast but let him sleep. Poor guy looked like a zombie for weeks. Around noon, my parents showed up unannounced. I'm six months pregnant, so they visit sometimes to check on me. We're sitting there having coffee when my mom asks where Tyler is. Since his truck's in the driveway, he's still sleeping, I said. My mom's face went all pinched. It's past noon. That's unacceptable with a pregnant wife. Wake him up. I explained the whole situation. Three weeks of hell. Fifty million dollar crisis. Barely any sleep. My dad just shook his head like Tyler was some lazy bum. I'm not waking him up, I said. He needs to rest. Well, if you won't do it, I will, my mom said, standing up and heading for the stairs. I jumped up and blocked her path. If you can't respect my husband getting proper sleep after three weeks of torture, then you need to leave our house now! Are you kicking us out? My dad asked, all shocked. Yes, get out! They left, all huffy and dramatic.

I remarried my ex even though I'm going to die. So I'm 36 and I've got terminal cancer. Me and Danny got married right after high school. We were those stupid kids who thought love could survive anything. You know, college, three kids, money problems, all of it. Our oldest is 12 now. Then there's Emma, who's 11, and our little guy, Jake, who's 4. But when Emma was 3, Danny's work schedule went completely insane. He was pulling 80 hour weeks, sometimes sleeping at the office. I was basically a single mom raising three kids while he chased some promotion that never came. We fought constantly. The house felt empty even when he was there because he was always on his phone or laptop. One night, after he missed Jake's first steps because of another emergency meeting, I told him I was done. We divorced six months later. It wasn't dramatic or messy, just sad. We both knew it wasn't working anymore. Two years later, I started feeling tired all the time. Like, couldn't get out of bed tired. Went to the doctor thinking it was stress or maybe low iron. Nope. Cancer. Age 2. At first, which scared the hell out of me, but felt manageable. Danny found out through Emma, who overheard me talking to my sister. He showed up at my door that same night with groceries and this look on his face, like someone had punched him in the gut. Why didn't you tell me? He kept asking. The funny thing is, going through chemo actually brought us closer than we'd been in years. He cut his hours way back to help with the kids and drive me to appointments. We'd sit in those awful hospital chairs for hours, just talking about random stuff. T V. Shows what the kids were doing. Stupid memories from when we were young. I beat it the first time. Remission at 31. And I felt like I could conquer.

My husband's best friend came out of our bathroom holding abortion medication and said, I thought you guys were trying for a baby. I looked up from my laptop, where I've been researching IBF clinics. We are trying. Zane, what are you talking about? Beside me, my husband Jasper froze midreach for his coffee. Zane held up an orange prescription bottle. Then why do you have mefloquine stone? This is abortion medication. It terminates pregnancies. I laughed nervously. That's not mine. I would never. Jasper, is this yours? The silence was deafening. Zane looked between us, realization dawning on his face. There's only two people who live here, I said, as Zane started reading the prescription label. Filled last month and the month before. My stomach dropped. My miscarriages, I whispered. I've had four miscarriages in 23 months. I stood up slowly, my legs shaking. You've been poisoning me. You've been calling our babies. Jasper backed against the counter, his face gray. It's not Walmart. You think? Then explain why abortion medication is in our house. While I'm taking fertility supplements, I said, my voice rising. While I inject myself with hormones. While I've been blaming my body for failing us, you called our children. The words came out raw, broken. Your mother called me defective at Thanksgiving, asked if maybe we should explore other options. Your sister announced her third pregnancy at Christmas, and everyone looked at me with pity. My voice was rising even more. I refused my Promotion to reduce stress. I gave up coffee, wine, sushi, even my anxiety medication to increase the odds. Jasper opened his mouth. The doctor said stress could. Don't you dare! I cut him off. Don't you dare quote the doctors to me! Zane stood frozen. I did three rounds of Clomid that made me so sick I couldn't work. They shot dye through my fallopian tubes. Do you know how much that hurts, Jasper? While you were poisoning me, I was letting doctors torture me to find out why I couldn't stay pregnant. We named our babies. I continued, tears streaming. Now you remember how we picked them out together? Phoenix, Sage, Indigo, Xavier. I was knitting their baby blankets while you were making sure they'd never need them. Jasper's hands were trembling. Reaching out like he was the one who needed comfort. Zane's face suddenly went wider than it had been.

I lied to my wife that I'd forgive her cheating. So my wife Emma came home last Tuesday with that look on her face. You know, the one all guilty and nervous, like she just got caught stealing candy. She sat me down on our ratty old couch and started crying before she even said anything. Turns out she'd been hooking up with her coworker Jake for, like, three months. Three months while I was working double shifts at the warehouse to save up for our anniversary trip to Florida. She kept saying sorry over and over, begging me not to leave her, promising she'd cut all contact with this guy. I just sat there staring at our wedding photo on the coffee table. The one where we're both laughing because my cousin Rick photobombed us making bunny ears. We looked so happy, so stupid. Emma grabbed my hands and asked if I could ever forgive her. And here's where I became a complete psychopath. I looked her dead in the eyes and said yes. I told her we could work through this, that our marriage was stronger than one mistake. All that bullshit you see in movies. I was lying through my teeth. The next morning, I called in sick to work and drove straight to Jake's apartment. Found his address through Emma's Instagram. She tagged him at some restaurant last month. Dude answered the door in his boxers, looking all confused. I introduced myself as Emma's husband and Watched his face go white. Then I very calmly explained that I knew everything and that he had exactly 24 hours to quit his job and move out of town, or I'd be paying visits to his parents, his ex girlfriend Sarah, who he was apparently trying to win back, and his boss, who definitely didn't know.

My mom checked our location 14 times a day until it destroyed our family. Mom's eating breakfast scrolling through Facebook while Dad's counting out quarters for gas money when she announces we're all downloading life 3 60. We're two months behind on the electrical, but her friend says this app is the only way to keep family safe and honest. I'm 17 and work part time at target while my dad does construction. We don't have time to be anything but safe and honest. He says if we have nothing to hide, we have nothing to fear. Which sounds like something a dictator would say, but whatever. She makes us install it right there at the table and checks that everyone's location is on, and I realize immediately what she doesn't understand about this app. Life 3 60 doesn't just show where you are. It shows your speed when driving, your phone battery, and sends notification for everything, including when someone checks someone else's location. Mom works from home doing medical billing and has nothing but time to watch that app all day while dad and I are actually out in the world. Perfect! Now I'll know everyone's safe, she says. But what she means is now she can watch us like the musical Jolly Chimp from Toy Story. Her phone buzzes and she glances at it. Oh, shoot, I have a doctor's appointment in an hour. Dad offers to drive her, but she says no, she needs the car. All day for errands. After months ago, my mom asked me to start covering for her when she goes out saying she shopping or at the doctors. Whenever dad asks where she is. Men lose interest when you mention women. Things she tell me she doesn't realize she just set herself up. Day one and my phone buzzes every 10 minutes with mom check your location while I'm at school. Dad text she checked me 14 times this morning and we both realize she's literally sitting there refreshing the app constantly instead of working. Day 3. Mom calls me screaming because the app says I was going 67 in a 65 and threatens to take my keys. So I start driving under the speed limit, which means I'm late to work and my manager writes me up. Dad gets stuck in traffic, won't go even 1 mile per hour over.
NA

I got upset at my wife's reason for marrying me. My wife Emma, is basically a robot when it comes to emotions. She's this data scientist who literally turns everything into spreadsheets and pros and cons lists. Like when we were picking what color to paint our bedroom, she made a whole Powerpoint about how blue affects sleep quality. I thought it was cute at first, you know, made me feel like she really thought things through. But last Saturday, I asked her something that's been eating at me since we were just sitting on the couch watching Netflix. I turned to her and was like, why did you marry me? I was expecting some romantic answer about how much she loves me or how I make her laugh or whatever normal couple stuff. She looked at me dead serious and said, because you asked. I thought she was joking, so I laughed it off, but then I pushed a little more. Okay, but, like, what made you say yes, though? And this woman, my wife of three years, looks me straight in the eye and says, because I trust your judgment. I just stared at her. What the hell does that even mean? So I asked her to explain, and she went into full professor mode. She told me love isn't enough to marry someone. That when she was in college, she was head over heels for this guy named Tyler, who was basically a walking disaster. Good looking, Charming, but had no goals, no savings, and spent all his money on stupid stuff like vintage band t shirts and energy drinks. She said she would have married him if he asked back then because she was young and dumb. But now she knows better. Marriage isn't about feelings. I left my sister's wedding early because she kept my husband out of pictures. My sister Chloe has always been the type of person who needs everything to be absolutely perfect according to her vision. And when I say perfect, I mean everyone else has to bend over backwards to make her happy. She's three years older than me and has always acted like she's the main character in everyone else's story. When she got engaged to her boyfriend Trevor, she immediately started planning this massive wedding like we're talking about a forty thousand dollar event with colour coordinated everything and a guest list longer than my grocery receipt. She sent out these fancy invitations with gold foil and expected everyone to dress according to her specific colour scheme. I've been married to Josh for two years now. He's this really laid back guy who works in I T. And honestly couldn't care less about fancy events. But he's always been supportive of my family stuff, even when Chloe gets a little intense. The week before her wedding, she called me panicking about the photographer and how important it was that every single photo turned out magazine perfect. The day of the wedding, Josh and I showed up dressed exactly how she wanted. I was wearing this dusty rose dress that cost me way too much money, and Josh had on a navy suit that actually looked really good on him. We were running a few minutes late because traffic Was insane, but we made it. Before the ceremony started. Everything seemed normal at first. The ceremony was beautiful. Chloe looked gorgeous, and Trevor was crying happy tears. During the cocktail hour, Josh and I were mingling with other guests and having a decent time. That's when the photographer started gathering people for family photos. First it was just immediate family, then extended family, then the bridal party. But when they started doing the casual group shots with friends and family mixed together, I

First thing Monday morning, a student said, we appreciate you being here, Mister Peterson, but shouldn't you have taken today off? What kind of question is that? I looked up from my attendance sheet, genuinely confused. Marcus, who usually burst through the door 30 seconds before the bell, was standing frozen by his desk. The entire classroom had gone eerily silent when I walked in. Kids who were usually comparing homework answers or scrolling through their phones suddenly stopped mid motion. Everyone was stealing glances at me, but whenever I made eye contact, they quickly look away. Sarah, usually the first to answer everything, was slumped forward with her face hidden in her arms. Even the boys in the back row, who never stopped joking around, were dead serious. The whole room felt wrong. I haven't missed a day in five years. I trying to lighten whatever strange mood had taken over my classroom. Why would today be different? Marcus shifted uncomfortably and cleared his throat. Mister P, I really think you should check your phone. Or maybe. Maybe you should go to the main office, like, right now. My heart started racing because something was seriously wrong. Whatever this was. My students were looking at me like I was about to get the worst news of my life. I reached for my phone in my jacket pocket, but remembered I'd left it in my car after rushing in late from stopping for coffee. I'd overslept after staying up grading Essays until 2:00am. Can someone please tell me what's going on? I asked, hearing my voice crack slightly. The silence was deafening. Even Kevin, who never stopped talking, was staring at his desk. Finally, Ashley from the second row spoke up, her voice barely a whisper. Mister Peterson, did you. Did you not check the news this morning? No, I overslept. I barely made it here on time. My hands were starting to shake. Now. What happened? Ashley exchanged looks with Marcus, who shook his head violently, but she continued anyway, maybe you should call someone. Your family? Family? My parents

What moment finally made you snap? Slap? The sound of the owner's hand when he hit the pregnant waitress's face made the entire restaurant freeze. All you ever do is complain! You're lucky I even let you keep your job! Mister Schiller! Yelled. The pregnant waitress held her cheek tightly. Please, Mister Schiller, I need those tips for the hospital! She begged. Tips? You cost me more than you make! He grabbed her arm, dragging her towards the kitchen. My baby's due next month. Please! Not my problem! He shoved her hard. Now clean that up, he said, pointing to the broken glass jar he had dropped after stealing his employees tips. She started picking up glass on her knees, sobbing. Schiller kicked more glass toward her. Faster! I stood up, holding the heavy ceramic plate over my head. Yoo hoo! I whistled before dropping it onto the marble floor. Crash! Everyone gasped. What the? He spun around just as I picked up another plate and dropped it. Sir, what are you doing? That's $700 each! I shrugged, picked up the window glass and dropped it too. Then I walked over to the next table and swept everything off. Stop! Stop! I'm calling the police! Good! I said. Call them! I kept going. Schiller rushed over and grabbed my collar. You'll pay for every piece! And you'll pay for everything everyone has had to deal with under you! I grinned back at him as he blew up in my face. Everyone stood still, watching us, wondering the same thing. Why? Why I was a stranger suddenly throwing around plates? Well, it was for a good reason. The police arrived quickly, walking in, looking just as confused as everyone else was. Mister Schiller grinned, letting my collar go finally. Officers, arrest this man? He demanded snobbishly, pointing at me. The officers raised an eyebrow. You want us to arrest him

I told my friend she's in the same league as men she calls ugly. My coworker Zoe constantly talks about how she's too good for the guys in our office building. She works reception on the third floor. I work IT support for the whole building, fixing everyone's computers and network issues. Every single day during our lunch break, point out different guys walking through the lobby and just tear them apart. You look at his receding hairline. Why do bald guys even think they have a chance with someone like me? Or that guy from marketing is so short. Or miles from accounting keeps bring me coffee. But seriously, look at that dad bought at 25. He probably still lives with his mom in the basement playing video games. And it wasn't just casual comments either. She'd take pics of guys from the company directory and send them to our group chat with crying laughing emojis. This guy from HR asked me out yesterday. Can you believe the audacity? She'd rate them out of 10 like she was some kind of celebrity judge on a reality show. The thing is, Zoe works reception. She answers phones, signs for packages, and schedules conference rooms. She's not exactly climbing the corporate ladder here, but she acts like she's the CEO's daughter who deserves nothing but investment bankers and male models. Walking straight out of GQ magazine. Last Monday I'm in her cubicle fixing her computer because she somehow managed to get 17 different toolbars installed, plus some suspicious browser extensions. While I'm running malware scans and updating her antivirus, she starts her usual lunch routine, pointing out guys walking by the reception desk. Oh, god, there's miles again with his pathetic daily coffee delivery. Look at him. Dad bod, cheap Supercuts haircut. Probably drives his mom's Honda Civic with the dented bumper. Why do guys like that think they can ask out someone like me? I mean, I have standards. That's when something clicked in.

My golden child brother said weakness was contagious. Guess who came begging for help? I was born two months premature and stayed small my whole life. 90 pounds through high school, while my brother came out 11 months later looking like he was meant for a Nike commercial. Dad immediately decided which son was worth his time by middle school. My brother's the star quarterback and I'm still getting mistaken for someone's little sister at the grocery store. Freshman year I tried joining J V. Football to be part of something, and during tryouts my brother walks over from varsity practice and tells the coach in front of everyone that weakness is contagious and I'll make the whole team soft. Coach actually listens to a 14 year old because my brother's already locally famous. Dad hears about this at dinner and instead of defending me he laughs and says my brother has a point, even suggest I try chess club instead. I get a job at the local gym cleaning the equipment just to be around fitness. My brother brings his teammates there specifically to point at me mopping and tell them not to get too close or my weak jeans might jump onto them. They all laugh like it's the funniest thing they've ever heard. Senior year my brother gets a full ride scholarship to date and my parents throw a huge party I only found out about through Instagram and when I asked dad why I wasn't invited He said it was for athletes only. I start working out at 3 in the morning when nobody's around to laugh, and gym owner notices my dedication and offers to train me for free. First year I gained 15 pounds of muscle, which isn't much, but it's something. I start posting progress videos online with hashtag contagious strength because I'm petty and it feels good. My brother wins state championship his senior year, but tears his ACL in his first college game.

My gym teacher chose flirting over our lives, and it doesn't surprise me. The only reason he even volunteered for the camping trip was to co chaperone with the beautiful Miss Dizon. But of course, don't let his wife know, right? So while he was there trying to impress her with his wilderness expertise, a baby bear cub wandered into our campsite, sniffing around me and the other students. He stumbled back and pointed at it. Mister V, there's a bear! He yelled in a high pitched voice. Mister IV looked over and laughed at our worried expression. Are you seriously scared of a little moving build? A bear? It's smaller than my Labrador. He walked over and picked up the cub on the back of its neck and held it up like a stop animal, winking at Miss I Dizon. See? You kids need to toughen up when we get back to school. 10 laps, all of you! He laughed as the cub cried and squealed before kicking it into the bushes. There, done. Now everyone go to bed. When we tried to say something, he cut us off. Anyone who disrupts adult conversation gets detention for a week. He turned to Miss Dizon, who was sitting by the fire. These city kids are so dramatic. Wanna check out the stars by the lake? Better view away from all these tents. I giggled and stood up. Lead the way. When they were gone, all of us looked at each Other with wide eyes. We all knew something bad was going to happen. I hate to be the bringer of bad news, Daphne said, cutting through the tension, but didn't our biology teacher warn us that a baby bear always mean the mother is nearby? Another kid with glasses nodded. My uncle survived a bear attack and told us never to mess with a cub. So what should we do? While we all stood there trying to figure out what to do, the smart kid Alex, started moving all our food and coolers to an empty tent opposite from where we were sleeping. Are you guys gonna help or what? We practically sprang into action, carrying all our snacks into the same tent, filling it up like we were making an offering to some local deity. Mr. V snuck up on us and yelled, what are you doing with all the food?

What moment made you go? No contact with family. My sister Tara got a German Shepherd for her 16th birthday. I got a card. The dog's name was Jack's and he cost $3,000 from a champion bloodline. My parents built him a heated dog house that cost more than my car. When Jax bit me the first week, dad said I must have bothered him. Jax killed my childhood cat, peaches, three months later. I'd raised peaches from a kitten bottle, fed her when she was abandoned. I found her lifeless in the backyard one morning. My parents shrugged and said cats were boring anyway, that dogs had personality. They refused to let me bury her properly because it might upset Jax to smell another animal in his yard. I buried peaches at my friend's house and cried alone. I paid for my own college, working three jobs. Sarah dropped out sophomore year to become a dog trainer. She'd never trained Jax to even sit yet. My parents bought her a 40 thousand dollar mobile grooming van for her new career. The business lasted two months. I graduated nursing school with honours. My parents couldn't make it to graduation. Jax's had a vet appointment when Tara's dog turned 1. They threw a party with 50 guests. Then Jax attacked my neighbour's poodle. My parents paid the vet bills and bought Tara a second German Shepherd to keep Jax's company. When I asked for help with my textbooks, mom said, that's My responsibility. The second dog's name was Athena. She was worse than Jax. Together, they destroyed my childhood bedroom. During Thanksgiving, I found peaches hidden toys under my bed torn to shreds. My parents laughed and said, dogs will be dogs. Everything unraveled when I met Steven. We dated two years before getting engaged. My parents said they were thrilled, but never asked about wedding plans. When I mentioned wedding costs, they suggested courthouse ceremonies were more intimate. At the same time, Tara announced Jack's needed surgery for hip dysplasia. My parents spent $15,000 without blinking. Then Jack's destroyed my wedding dress. During the fitting, Tara had brought him to my appointment uninvited. He jumped on me with muddy paws and tore the train clean off. The dress was ruined.

What happened when my parents blamed me for my brother's chaos? When I turned eighteen, my parents sat me down for what they called a long overdue conversation. You need to move out, mom announced. Every disaster in this house happens because you're constantly provoking Gonzales. I stared in disbelief while my 14 year old brother Gonzales sat there looking innocent. The kitchen fire last week, the destroyed laptop, the hole in the garage door. It's always when you two are together. We need peace. You have two weeks to find somewhere else to live. Gonzalez smiled sweetly. I just want our family to be safe, he said, hiding behind my parents backs as he mouth goodbye. Fine. If they wanted me to stop protecting them from Hurricane Gonzalez, I'd wish them good luck. The day after I moved out, Gonzalez decided to upgrade the house's electrical system. Every light in the neighborhood now flickered in rhythm with our toaster. When mom tried to make toast. It activated the garage door, the ceiling fans, and somehow started Dad's car. The power company had to shut down our entire grid and rewire our house. The Bill was $3,000. It's synchronized living, Gonzalez explained proudly to the electrician. Next, he discovered online chemistry tutorials without me. Secretly replacing his chemicals with baking soda, he created what he called rainbow smoke bombs in the kitchen. But they were actually just straight up acid that ate through the tiles and corrupted all the food. Hazmat had to gut our kitchen entirely. Total cost $8,000. Why didn't you tell us this would happen? Mom yelled at me through the phone. I did. You just never listened. I reminded her. Then Gonzales revealed he'd been training squirrels in the attic. They're my army, he explained, as 20 squirrels wearing tiny tin foil hats descended through the ceiling during Dad's Zoom meeting with his boss. Dad got fired on the spot. Then came the car improvement.

What's the most rebellious thing you did as a teenager? In my family, there was one rule. I needed my twin's permission to seek medical help. I was watching Vanessa practice her birthday speech when my lungs seized up. I reached for my inhaler on the coffee table, but mom snatched it away. Vanessa, does Ellie need this? My twin didn't even look up from her phone. She used it at lunch. She's fine. You heard your sister. Mom dropped my inhaler in her purse. No attention seeking today. It's Vanessa's sweet 16. The rule had been in place since we were 12. The day I faked pneumonia during Vanessa's ballet recital. I hadn't faked it, but Vanessa said I had, so that became the truth. From then on, every headache, every fever, every asthma attack had to be verified by the golden twin. Can't breathe. The wheeze was starting. That whistling sound my doctor called your body's alarm bell. Ellie, Dad's voice boomed from the doorway. What do we do when you claim you're sick? I knew the script. Ask Vanessa first. And what did Vanessa say? Vanessa finally looked up, annoyed. I said, she's fine. Gosh, Ellie, do you have to make my day about you? My chest was tightening like someone was sitting on it. Each breath felt like sucking air through a coffee stirrer. Please! I gasped. Need hospital, mom! Vanessa whined. She's doing it again! Make her stop! Mom rushed to comfort Vanessa. Don't worry, Sweetie! Ellie, go to your room if you're going to act like this. The modelling scout will be here soon. I tried to stand, but had to grip the couch. My fingernails were starting to tinge blue. Look! I held up my hands. Vanessa laughed. She probably painted them blue. Remember when she faked passing out at my recital? I hadn't faked it. I had an asthma attack. But Vanessa told everyone I was jealous. So my parents refused to leave her performance. The doorbell rang. Party guests started to arrive. Ellie, disappear! Dad ordered. Vanessa's modeling scout is coming. We don't need you wheezing in the background. I couldn't move. My lungs were working overtime, visible through my shirt. Every breath was a

When did you realize your daughter was gonna go to jail? When I rushed into the ER carrying my bleeding grandbaby. I came home from the most important presentation of my career to find my 11 month old granddaughter screaming and kicking on the living room floor, all alone, with a large gash on her head from where she had hit the coffee table. And my daughter, the actual mother of the baby, who had swore this time she'd stay and watch over her, nowhere to be found. I was shocked, furious, in desperate tears as I scooped her up and called for an ambulance. The nurses took her for a CT scan immediately while I filled out forms with shaking hands. Is she going to be okay? Please tell me she's going to be okay, I begged. Where did this happen? The intake nurse asked coolly. I hesitated. At home, she fell off the couch. Are you the mother of the child? I shook my head. Grandmother? The nurse raised an eyebrow. Where is the mother now? I opened my mouth to speak, but I wasn't even sure how to answer her. I opened up Instagram from my phone and found her post from an hour ago. Enjoying a nice smooch with a stranger at a music festival. How long was the baby unsupervised? The doctor asked when he came out. Maybe a few hours. I kept calling my daughter. Straight to voicemail every time the hospital called. The Police. In the meantime, a social worker approached me in the waiting room and called my daughter on her personal phone. This isn't normal for her, I tried to explain. She's young. She's still figuring things out. The social worker just stared at me, expressionless. When my daughter picked up, she spoke bluntly. Your baby is in the hospital, and that custody of yours is hanging on a thread. So show up, Bam! And call. The social worker pulled out her tablet. Now let's talk about what normal looks like. How often do you watch the baby? Well, at first it was just during classes, and now I bit my lip. More often she waited? Yes, okay, every night. But I'm her mother. And I'm that baby's grandmother. You got how to understand I. When was the last time your daughter spent a full 24 hours with her baby? She interrupted writing out a long list on her case file. When I couldn't answer, she scribbled even more on her clip.

Predators who work in retail. What's the saddest thing someone ever returned? One, I used to be a manager for a Disney store. We had a regular old man come in with his wife regularly. Super cute couple. I mean, matching outfits, holding hands, just cute as could be. We used to sell these huge stuffed animals, like ginormous. The couple came in about once a week and would just walk around, laugh and smile, buy things here and there. One night he came in on his own and bought one of these gigantic Mickey's we had. It was $300, I think. He was so excited. He told us all about how he was going to take her out to dinner and it would be sitting there on the bed to surprise her when they got home. Anyway, two days later, he walked back in carrying the gigantic Mickey Mouse plush to return it. He had bought it to surprise her for her 75th birthday. She passed away in her sleep the day before her birthday. He thanked us and said goodbye and that he would not be coming back because our store reminded him too much of his wife. We found out he passed away a week later, was just seven days from the day his wife passed. We found out all the details because one of our employees went to the same church they attended. Two customers regularly come in with large amounts of baby supplies, returns. They Get the wrong gender items or duplicates. An older woman came in with a cartload so I asked about the new baby. She slowly and through tears explained that her only child and grandbaby didn't make it during childbirth. 3. Not a return, but I worked in a jewelry store and the saddest sale we ever had was a labor. The guy had this ring on labor for 12 months but passed in a car accident. His parents came in and picked up the ring so his girlfriend could keep it. I don't think she had any idea he was going to propose. 4, I work at a store in a college town and one night some younger guy was returning a keg barrel only was still half full. I jokingly asked the guy if it was a trash party or something along those lines and he responded with, yeah, it was a party for one of our friends who passed the day of the party. Five, I was working at a large pet store in the tropical fish department. One busy weekend a very well dressed, rather snobby woman came in and bought six baby angel fish, each about the size of a dime plus the fins. The store I worked in was inside a huge high end shopping mall so we had a holding service where we would bag up fish, cash the customer out and float the fish in their bags in a warm tank until the Customer was finished all their shopping and was ready to leave for home. As a matter of course, I offered to hold this lady's baby angel fish. She said she was all good and left. Four or five hours later, she stormed back into the store demanding a manager and a refund. She was shaking the bag in our faces for emphasis, yelling that her gorgeous angels were all deceased. On close inspection, we discovered that the silly woman had put the poor fish in her car, presumably so she didn't need to carry them while she shopped for other things or returned to the store to pick them up. Unfortunately, because it was January and the temperature outside was extremely cold, the tiny babies had frozen. 6. A guy was returning baby formula and he was looking pretty down. I asked him how his day was and he said that he has been having a long day and that he's been having a long month too. I thought he just had a baby, so maybe he just got the wrong formula. I asked if he just had a baby and he said he used to have a baby. I told him I was sorry and he said it was okay. There were a few minutes of silence and he said he was a fun little guy, seen a lot of things, but that one broke my heart.

What is the creepiest glitch in the matrix you've experienced? One. I had an Android phone which had a Google Cards feature option that could notify you like 15 minutes to home if you were out. I thought this feature was annoying and useless, so I kept the feature off. After several months of no card notifications, one night I'm at home and a card pops up saying 35 minutes to home, pinning me at a random intersection on the other side of town. Let's call it First Street in Story Avenue, I think. That's weird. I'm not even way over there. I don't even know where that is. I've never been to that area. I go to my card setting to turn it back off, but it's already turned off. That's weird. The next night the same thing happens. 35 minutes to home from 1st Saint Story. What the. Still definitely not over there. Check cards feature and the notifications are still turned off, so no idea why I'm getting a notification. A few days later, a friend and I are out running errands and he misses his intended exit, so he takes the next one. Once on the streets, I ask where are we? I've never been over here. a car to our right tries to turn left and crashes right into us. Messed up the wheel turning system, so we pulled forward to the curb to call a tow truck. We had our kids in the Car. So I called my sister to pick us all up. When my sister asks me for the location, I look up at the street signs. First Street and Story Avenue. 2 in college, I delivered pizzas to make money. I had a delivery that should have taken about 20 minutes. When I returned to the store, the manager asked me what had taken so long. I asked him what he meant, and he pointed to the computer, showing I had been gone for an hour and seven minutes. I don't remember delivering the pizza, only turning into the store when I was returning. 20 years later, I still have no idea what happened. Three. I had a dream of some kid that I had never seen before, dancing at a busy party. He was wearing a blue shirt, black pants, had Bieber hair, and there was a purple strobe light on the wall behind him. Wake up, think to myself, huh, what an odd dream, and carry on with my life. Several years later, I was at my cousin's wedding reception, chilling and hanging out with a different cousin. Music comes on and we start jumping up and down. And then I realized that I was reliving the dream. Same clothes, same hair, same purple lighting in the background. 4 A few months before my first car accident, I dreamed about it happening. Everything from the sounds to the placement and the smell was the same. The thing is, The girl driving tried to get me to find a different ride because she didn't want to do any extra driving that day. And after the crash I told her about my dream and she said she had the same one the night before and that's why she didn't want to drive. Freaky. 5 I once was woke up by a phone call from my GF. At the time she was at her friend's house, which I didn't know about until the phone call. We figured out our plans for the day. Told her that I was gonna lay around for 15 minutes to wake up a bit. I'd have a shower and head over to get her. I just laid down, started to fall asleep. Then the phone rang about 15 minutes after the last phone call. It was her calling from her friend's house again. Convo was the same word for word, so I played along. Then when it was done, she was wondering why I was laughing. I told her we just had this convo 15 minutes ago. She disagreed and I figured was pulling my leg. Later that day I checked my calls, only had one from that number. And she showed me her friend's phone. Same, only one call made. 6 I knew someone that fell asleep drunk on a three story flat roof which they rolled off of during the night. The doctors said the main reason he didn't break anything was that his Body was in such a state of relaxation from the booze induced coma he was in that he pretty much just bounced off the concrete.

What is the most inoffensive thing you've seen someone get offended by? One maybe 22 years ago, I had a phone interview with a baking company. I didn't care to have my peers know what I was up to, so I took the call on my cell phone in my car. The call was crystal clear and no technical issues. At one point, they had mentioned the weather and asked how it was where I was. I told him that I was sitting in my car and I could see that it was actively snowing and what not. The interviewer asked me, are you taking this call on a cell phone? I told him I was. Then he asked me if I thought that was appropriate. I asked him what he meant by that. He said he thought it was kind of rude to take a formal call on a cell phone. I told him I would be more than happy to conclude the interview if talking on a cell phone was an issue. If he was interested, I'd be happy to continue it the next day when I'd be at a desk. He again repeated how rude he thought it was that I had called from a cell phone and that there was no need to continue the interview process. I disagreed with the first point, but did agree with the second. To this day, I wonder what in the world he was talking about and where he was. Coming from too. At my wedding we marked the vegetarian items as vegetarian. This made the one vegetarian in my wedding sister in law who hates me fly into a catatonic rage because we are singling out the vegetarian food as vegetarian and not treating it as normal food. Then how the heck are they supposed to know it's vegetarian? Guess she wanted to be able to ask so then everybody knows they're vegetarian lol. Three. I once listened to my boss try to lecture the fire marshal because he was talking about something being flame retardant. Her reasoning was you should just call it fireproof because retardant was an awful word. It was one of those times where I really should have tried to stop her, but instead I just stood off to the side making a surprise Pikachu face. Four. This guy at a Halloween party I was at was dressed in a giant bacon costume. Some girl was yelling at him for being so offensive toward those who didn't eat bacon. For various reasons. Mind you, she ate pork. One of the guys who didn't eat bacon at the party asked her what the heck she was talking about, but she didn't back down. Lol. I have no idea why people feel they need to go out of their way to be inaccurately offended on behalf of other people. 5. One time someone got offended when I put on my seatbelt. She thought I was commenting on Her ability to drive. The same thing happened to me when inside a taxi, he asked, do you wear your seatbelt when you're with your dad? I said, yes. Six. My seven month old was wearing a shirt that had a rocket ship and the NASA logo. And some middle aged woman in the shop said he shouldn't be wearing that because he's clearly not an astronaut. I was dumbfounded. 7 at school, someone didn't have a calculator and asked if anyone had one they could borrow. Someone offered them a pink calculator and they refused, saying that they were offended. They try and give them something less masculine. Clearly they didn't need a calculator that badly if they're just gonna whine about the color. Eight. I'm a nurse at a children's hospital. I was wearing Mickey Mouse Halloween scrubs, which have little dancing skeletons on it. A visitor for one of my patients complained that I was wearing scary and inappropriate scrubs. Nine. People get very offended that I don't like being touched, and this happened just last week. I work at a bank in an affluent part of Atlanta, and a woman called in to let us know she was offended by the security questions for her online banking. The security questions she set up herself. 11. Wearing a mask in public.

When did you triumphantly call someone out for lying? One, at my job recently, a woman claimed I had promised her something for free when in fact all I did was offer her a significant discount. She came in demanding it for free and I refused. She said she had a recording of me saying it was free. I don't know what her endgame was, but on the off chance I had messed up what I said badly enough, I would honor it, I asked her to play me the recording. She refused because I was being difficult. She actually had the nerve to ask for my boss's number so she could complain about me not honoring a product for free valued at around $400 and thought they would actually side with her. 2. I created a binder for a hotel my company owns with forms and templates. I highlighted and wrote explanations on everything. About a month later, I go to the property to assist with some things and the GM brings out the binder and says, yeah, I just put this together as a tool for us here. I immediately tell him, no, you didn't. I made that and gave it to you. His face went white as he tried to recover saying, well, I added a few things. He didn't love the faces of my colleagues when I went back to the office and told them all three. When I worked at a fast food place, I Had someone call in during the opening shift while we were still prepping everything for the day. He tells me he was just there and that the service was terrible and his order was wrong. I asked him when exactly he came in. He said about half an hour ago. I said, oh, that's weird because we don't even open for another 45 minutes. He just hung up without a word. 4, my ex wife told my kids I didn't pay child support regularly. I was able to lay out each and every receipt for three years showing each payment made on time or early. But I wouldn't say triumphant. There are no winners in divorce. 5, my friend's favorite is from when working at Mickey D's. She was on drive drive through and a guy came through complaining about the ice cream he got earlier. That's when everyone who worked there came to the drive through window to see. Friend casually lets them know they haven't had a working ice cream machine in four months. Six, at an auto shop, angry customer ahead of me was shouting, we've been here more than two hours. The shop manager gets out a piece of paper. We printed the work order you signed less than 30 minutes ago. Seven, I was waiting at a red light behind a red BMW. I saw that its bumper was kind of messed up. The light turns green and he starts going and I slowly accelerate. Like any normal human. Then he slams on his brakes and I do the same. Don't hit him at all. He reverses into my car and turns on his hazards and pulls into the shopping complex near us. We exchange information. I am absolutely calm. Later at small claims court after rejecting his claim with my insurance, he goes, yes, your honour, this rear ending left me with 5,000 in damage including paint and 1 thousand in emotional distress as I have needed physical therapy. Judge looks at me and you say you have video of this incident. Me. Yes, I do, sir. And I hand the CD to the bailiff. The dash cam clearly shows his fraud. Judge, so is that you in the video? Him. Um, he literally got arrested and had to pay me 5,000 in damages. Get a dash cam, people. 8. I had a customer once call and say she had bought these ice cream sandwiches the week before and they were all freezer burned. She was super aggressive and was yelling. So I very politely confirmed the exact product she bought. She yelled, yes, that one. That's what I've been telling you. And I said, miss, we discontinued those six months ago. She stuttered a bit and hung up. I was 19. It was my first job and it was so satisfying.

What's one thing your partner doesn't know? 1, she left her toxic ex boyfriend for me. He was always showing up in places she would be or randomly showing up at her house with no good intentions. She asked me not to get involved, so I respected her wishes for a while. he tried to break into her home one night while everyone was asleep. He got caught, made a run for it and keyed her car on the way out. Shortly after it happened, I was informed by a witness to the events. The witness expressed to me that at that time they were scared because they knew the ex boyfriend had been physically aggressive in the past and had recently tried to do it again as well. My girlfriend called me that night also but told me it was okay now and not to worry. For the next week, I staked out her house at night in case he tried again. I also found out where he lived and hung out and his routes to such places. I observed him and tracked his schedule. I waited for him to try something again and he came back to try and break in. Added security measures prevented him and after trying other ways, he left. He rode his bike down an isolated dirt path every morning as a shortcut to work. I waited and when I saw him, I blocked off his path with my vehicle. I did what? Had to be done and destroyed his bike. I told him if he even came near her again, even by accident, he wasn't going to walk away from it. An empty threat. I would have just roughed him up more at best. I also told him I recorded him trying to break into her house and damaging her property. I also read out to him in explicit detail his schedule and routines. I told him if I even thought he was sniffing around her again, I would find him. We never heard or saw from him again. We have been together for nearly 2 decades now. Very happy, successful and much so in love still. I swear I'm not a psycho, lol. I'm not possessive or an aggressive person. Everyone calls me a big teddy bear or a big softie. I grew up in a home with that kind of behavior and have zero tolerance for any of it. 2. Every time we go into a restaurant or place of business, I make sure to identify all the exit points in case something bad were to happen. Also never have my back to the doors. 3. I pretend to be asleep when he wakes up because I love how sweetly he wakes me up. 4. That I knew he was planning to propose to me, but I still acted surprised. We've been married 14 years now, but I still haven't told him. He is so proud of the idea that He managed to surprise me. 5. That I know their Reddit account. 6. That her mom called for her the moment before she passed when her mom was passing. She was in the room with her for almost 24 hours straight and left for 30 seconds and I was there in those 30 seconds. Her mother passed, but not before calling for my wife. I don't know if it will haunt her or not, but I just don't think it's something she needs to know. 7. He does not know that he was my teenage crush since I was 12 and I wrote so many beautiful poems about him. We have been married for six years and have a child together. I don't know if I will ever have the courage to tell him that I have always loved him. 8. That I have a folder of photos on my computer called Places I Have Found My Wife Shoes that is legitimately filled with thousands of pictures of my wife shoes that are neither in the closet or shoe rack. 9. That she's my partner. We rent together, go on dates, laugh together, cook together, eat together and talk about each other's day every evening. But she doesn't want a relationship right now. Before anyone says anything, I know how it sounds and I'm slowly making my way out of the situation. 10. Out of grocery shop efficiently. I can't stand going into the grocery store with her. She makes A list and then follows the list order through the store back and forth. She visits the same aisle three to four times.

What's the scariest thing you've woken up to? One, when he was little, my younger son wouldn't try and wake you up if he needed something. He'd do that creepy thing kids do where they just stand there looking at you until you wake up. Well, I wake up at about 1:00am in a dark bedroom and see the black silhouette of a young kid standing right next to the bed. Golly, that's scary. Then he asked, hey, dad, Wanna play Rock Band 2? Waking up to my husband yelling, get out of my house. A man broke into my house and crawled in bed with me. Turns out he was in the house for a couple of hours. According to my door camera, my husband was asleep on the couch, came to bed and found the guy on the bed beside me asleep. Also, I accidentally left my door unlocked when I lived in this studio apartment in Philly. I woke up and it felt like someone was watching me. You know that feeling. Then I heard a shuffling noise and turn the lights on. There was a guy in a hoodie standing at the foot of my bed. I screamed. It was a young drunk dude that I literally had to push out. He seemed confused, but I'll never know what his intent was. I've never left my door unlocked since 3. Once I woke up to go to the bathroom, got up, smack something, slap me in The face. Turns out it was my entire right arm. Completely numb. Nearly scared the piss out of me and concerned me greatly afterwards. Has not happened since. 4. Back when I lived alone in an apartment, I used to wake up to just about anything. Never woke up more terrified than the night when I woke up to the sound of my toilet flushing. To this day, I can only assume that a ghost just couldn't hold it anymore. Five, I woke up and my dad's alarm clock was going off through the wall. He was a really light sleeper and he always turned it off immediately. It had been going off for several minutes and I think I knew before I got to his room that he was no longer with me. It was just so incredibly out of character for that alarm to be going off like that. He went in his sleep with a blanket still completely undisturbed. And I think I felt some small comfort at that, even though I was just a kid. 6, I once woke up to an earthquake at 4:00am. I lived in a house over the ocean on stilts, so my house was rocking like crazy. It was my first earthquake. And for some reason my brain first thought that someone was robbing me. I grabbed a machete and ran outside shirtless in my underwear. Neighbors next to me looked at me alarmed and started laughing. 7, my partner waking. Me up during a camping trip. He woke me to gather all our gear and our dogs into our truck ASAP. Lightning we had spotted six hours earlier in the day had sparked a wildfire. We got out as ash and sparks were falling around us. When we reached the top of the ridge surrounding our camp, we got out to look and watch the fire eat our entire campsite. We're so glad we called in the strike when we saw it. We met fire crews on our way out. The fire burned for like a week. One of the fires in Oregon in 2020, the Lakeview Paisley Fire 8, a bed bug infestation. I had had them for weeks and had no idea what they were. I would see one or two here or there and I'd just squash them, wonder what they were and move on. One morning, I woke up early and found quite a few of them on my bed. I started looking more closely and realised that the creases of the mattress were infested with them. Then I started to do some research, Learned that I had bed bugs, felt my soul leave my body, then began the process of getting rid of them. They're a psychological horror experience I wouldn't wish upon my worst enemy. Five years after the fact, and I still get paranoia attacks at a random speck in the sheets or mysterious red marks in the morning.

What's the most ridiculous rule in your place of work? One. I once needed a pen. Figured this was a reasonable ask, went to the supply closet on my floor, which was locked. Asked the floors admin, and she told me to go to the main supply room in the basement. I went to the basement and explained my situation of needing a pen. They told me all requests for supplies must be approved by my department head. The problem is, being new, I'd never met my department head. She also worked in San Francisco. I worked in Milwaukee, so I needed to send an email both introducing myself and asking her if I had permission to get a pen from the supply closet. 2. All the extra toilet paper in the building has to stay in a single closet, where it can be overseen by the toilet paper queen. I heard her shrieking the other day when she discovered someone had hoarded one spare roll of toilet paper upstairs so the people who work upstairs wouldn't have to walk down multiple flights of stairs when the toilet paper ran out. It's the cheapest one ply toilet paper available on the giant rolls that only fit in the special dispensers. I can't imagine anyone wanting to steal it. Three. A rule that said if you have time to lean, you have time to clean. Which fairly obviously meant if there was no work, then you should be cleaning things. It Was at an aircraft servicing station that was fairly small, but we needed a crew of at least three people for larger planes. The problem was that sometimes there were just no planes, so there was no work. We would clean for a couple of hours and then just run out of stuff to clean. But according to management, that was no good. We had to be busy. It got to be that we would fight over work when it came in, because everyone was so bored. And finding pretend busy work was much harder than just working. I remember getting the crew together to pick up pebbles off the taxiway for a couple hours. There's an old joke in aviation. Go sweep the taxiway. So we actually did it. Four. I drive LA. The company handbook says you're never allowed to back up, ever. You absolutely cannot do the job without reversing. It's impossible. It's in there because of liability in our insurance policy. This way, it can always be the valet's fault if an accident occurs. Ever. The rule only exists to cover the company's rear. Five. When I was in the military, I saw a buddy of mine sitting outside crying. I went and consoled him as best as I could. Apparently, he was just unhappy. After he was feeling a bit better, I went to go and find someone to tell them what was happening. They knew. In fact, he had been crying so much lately, That they had instituted a no crying at your desk policy, which is why he was outside. 6. Empty inbox my boss was an inbox enforcer. Like if you had old emails in there he would flip and make you respond to them or delete them. Apparently you shouldn't have anything left at the end of the day. Deal with them or delete them. Jokes on him though, I just made a subfolder marked personal and everything went in there. 7. My workplace doesn't let you use the word problems. Instead we have to say challenges if something is wrong, as a problem is a negative word and challenges promotes the fact that there is room to fix said problem. 8. I used to work at a place in which my boss implemented a no more than two glasses a day water policy. I ignored this rule and complained directly to our CEO and the matter ended later that day. Nine. Can't have my hands in my pockets. 10. Business casual dress code. Even when I work at home they video call me to check. 11. No one can go to lunch between 12 and 2.

People who discovered a deal breaker partway through a date. What was the rest of the date like? One, first date from a dating app. We went for beverages at a hotel spot restaurant. When we were ordering the beverages, she said to the bartender, you can serve the restaurant menu here, right? I'll have the end. Proceeded to name the expensive dish she already knew by name. That was the there will be no second date red flag. The plan wasn't dinner, was a drink. Originally she had suggested an expensive restaurant, but I'd said let's just have a drink the first time, clearly just a foodie call. The I'm leaving now red flag was that she got on the phone and texted for a while, then said, my friends are coming to meet us. Let's order some more appetizers and a bottle. That was when I said the plan was some beverages to get to know each other, not be the wallet for your friends night out. I'll cover these beverages, have fun with your friends and left to pay my part of the Bill. Two, we matched on a dating app and he kept messaging me persistently, but he seemed like a nice guy. So he picked me up and took me to a decent sushi place. The actual dinner part went fine. Aside from him being very nervous and visibly sweating as he drove me home, he continually professed his love for me. By the time We got to my building. I was ready to book it as fast as possible into the entrance door which would lock behind me and he would be unable to enter without a key. Balked immediately. 3. An immediate red flag was that she told me she had no money and then she ordered the most expensive beverage on the list halfway through the date. She said she came from her ex boyfriend's house, but not to worry, they were no longer together. I finished my drink and excused myself to the bathroom. I tracked down our waitress and paid for our beverages. When I returned to the table, I told her I didn't think this was going to work out and left. Four, guy admitted to being technically homeless and crashing in a studio with two other guys. Told me he'd had 13 injuries that may have LED to memory loss. He didn't believe in key rings so he kept his keys on a rope, farted on a cat. I could go on. So much happened and all of it was unhinged. He got up to go to the bathroom and in a moment of inspiration and panic, I suddenly gained self awareness and realized I could leave. I threw money down on the bar top, made sympathetic eye contact with the bartender who had been watching the train wreck go down and then sprinted out of the restaurant. 5, she wanted to order lobster. I said, waiter, separate Bills, please. She glared at me, calling me broke while making the face. I ate my cheeseburger and fries and left her alone. Talk about spoiled. 6. We were having a very nice time, good chat, good company, etcetera. I looked over my shoulder to see the decor of the place we were in and she said, excuse me, I'm over here. She didn't like me not making eye contact all the time. If I looked away, she was insulted. The date ended and I drove away. 7, blind date, friend of a friend. He did not stop talking the entire time, didn't ask me one question. I just sat there mentally playing my favorite songs in my head until the Bill came. Because I'm a nice person and thought he might be nervous, I gave him another chance. The same thing happened over the phone. I fell asleep for 15 minutes and when I woke up, he was still talking. We did not meet up again. 8. She had never seen Star Wars. I'm not a fan. I don't even really like Star Wars. She brought up in conversation, complaining that her brother had become obsessed with the Star War. And that was it the whole rest of the date. Inside my head I asked myself, but how could she not know the name? Surely she's heard other people say it. Her brother has a lot of merch. She's read it many times. She doesn't have to care about It, but like, how is it even possible?

What is causing your friend to remain single that you don't have the heart to tell them one? The type of guy she claims she likes isn't what she's actually attracted to. She keeps saying how much she loves shy, introverted, sensitive guys, but when she finds one and dates him, suddenly he's not outgoing enough, doesn't speak his mind enough, and is too shy. I kind of think she has this I can fix him syndrome and doesn't really acknowledge it. Like she's attracted to the idea of a typical shy guy, but thinks once they're in a relationship they'll suddenly be more open and turn into the guy she actually wants. That's not how it works. 2. I can smell them. Everyone can smell them. I also had a coworker who started smelling like a poorly cleaned public restroom. Didn't smell like poop, but it was a terrible, almost chemical smell. I had a meeting with him. I had to make an excuse to leave the conference room because I felt like I was going to vomit. His manager finally took him aside and was like dude, what the crap is going on? Turns out he had started something that caused it and claimed he couldn't smell it. I have my doubts about this. He took a week off and came back smelling fine. Apparently his doctor swapped out his prescriptions and that was it. So maybe a similar situation. 3. I always wondered why she couldn't get A date because she is gorgeous. Until I saw her flirting with someone first night they met, flirted, swap numbers, then immediately clingy talking in a baby voice to him and making baby noises. He made a completely innocent comment which she found offensive and threatened him. Not shocking at all when he never called. Four really is not as nice of a person as he thinks he is. Five he keeps hanging on to the past and spending all his time hanging out with ex girlfriends who are unavailable or women who like him, but he doesn't romantically like. 6 the people they like aren't real. They are idealized, cartoonish caricatures. Now my friend himself has a lot to offer emo, but he is looking for a person that doesn't exist. Hard to find something that's not there. Seven she is so lovely, so kind, so generous, and so beautiful, but her crippling lack of self esteem is so huge it's visible from space. Basically, when she's nervous that she talks at 100 miles an hour in several directions at once. It's like being handed eight happy Labrador puppies to try and hold in your arms. I so badly want her to be happy and feel fulfilled, but even I find it tiring sometimes. 8 her standards are excessively too high. She brings nothing to a relationship. She's a walking contradiction. All of which is why she is single. I think it's great to have standards, but hers is Just a checklist of wants. 9 for my husband's friend, it's the selfish arrogance. I want what I want. And the subtext was that he never cared about what his girlfriend wanted. He would only go places he wanted to go, which never included her friends or family. He wanted to spend all his money on collectibles related to SCI fi movies, DVDs, figurines, etc. Engagement rings were a waste of money investing or buying a house. Ditto. No compromises were possible, he said no and no discussions were entertained. His opinion on every topic was the correct one and he was not interested in your opinion or listening to extra facts he did not know that might change his mind. 10 summarizing the two types of my single friends super successful, smart, funny, and good looking. They also tend to go for folks who leave them on read for days. Their self esteem is their own worst enemy. Other friends don't know how to commit to anything, including a job. It almost feels like an it'll happen when it happens type of ideology, and so they don't even try to make things happen.

What was something you saw you were definitely not supposed to see? One, when I was 14, a friend hosted a birthday party at his house with all the parents invited, needed to use the restroom, but the main one was occupied. So my friend told me I could use the one in his mom's bedroom. As I walked up to the door, I could hear somebody in there. So I decided to wait until whoever was in there was finished. A good 10 minutes later, my friend's mom, who was hosting the party and another good friend's stepfather walked out and saw me standing there all confused. They asked what I was doing there and I just said I was waiting to use the bathroom. Surprisingly, they played it cool and just said I can use it now and walked off. 2, I found my dad's will. I was on his computer while he was at work and ended up finding a strangely titled word document. First, it didn't seem like a big deal. It contained a note to each of his kids. It wasn't until I got to the last one, my youngest brother, then I realized it wasn't just a will. The start of that line read something along the lines of, if anything is going to make me change my mind, now it's writing. This part, I realized I had found my dad's note for his last moments. I was about 14 or 15 at the Time and I had no idea how to go about talking to him about it. I decided to just keep it to myself. He started buying us gifts and stuff and I would get really scared. 3. As a middle schooler, I picked up a book at the library, flipped through the pages and found an application for a replacement birth certificate for some old man. It had every detail about his personal identification on it. So naturally I took it home thinking I'll just hold on to this in case I ever need to assume a fake identity by pretending to be an 80 year old man and flee the country. My mom found it and had to explain to me that no, we don't steal people's identities. 4. I was about 8 or 9 and my parents were going to be out of town so they had me and my siblings stay with a family from our church. Once we got to the house, which was really nice by the way, they had one rule. You can play wherever you want but the basement is off limits. Being the little rascal that I was, snuck down there the first chance I got and was supremely disappointed to only find rows and rows of plants growing under lights. Looking back, I now know what it was. 5 when I started a new job, someone had left a bunch of HR files on the computer I was given. I opened One up, not sure what it was and I got to see every employee's salary in the company, even the CEO. The next day it was gone. My boss realized his mistake and logged into my system and deleted the files. It was a memorable experience. 6. I worked at a fancy health food restaurant years ago. One day I was early and saw the owner mixing his homemade cold pressed garlic aioli. It was Cisco mayonnaise and a big jar of minced garlic. 7. I was bartending and it was slow. I was putting away glasses by the only two people sitting at the bar. They seemed a new couple, very touchy, etcetera. At some point I noticed that she was wearing a wedding ring and he was not. Right. As the music silenced between songs, he turned to her and said, you know, they're going to ask you where you were when he passed. NOPED out of there real quick. Hey, my parents toy collection. That was way more reality than my 10 year old mind was prepared to handle. 9. My mother's autopsy report. My mom passed in a car accident because she pulled me out of the way of a speeding car. It, it was so unreal that I didn't even cry until years later. Several years later, I was probably 16 or 17 and looking into my dad's archive for some personal documentation about myself to submit a college application. Out of nowhere I opened This folder and found pictures of my mother lying on an operation table.
