I watched so much TikTok, it ended up saving a life. My first few months as a 9 1 1 operator were scary, but nothing could have prepared me for when I got a call late at night from a young girl. I could barely understand what she was saying through her sobbing, but she told me she had just swallowed an entire bottle of pills and just wanted someone to talk to before they did anything. I started asking her why she would do that and asked for her address. She thought I already had it. But after a few minutes, she finally told me where she lived. She said she was severely depressed and just wanted everything to end. I asked her why, just trying to keep her on the phone and she said she couldn't take the hate she was getting anymore. I knew I only had literal minutes to do something and tried talking her into throwing up. She told me no. So I asked her what kind of hate she was getting. Apparently, she just wanted people to like her and wanted to help people. She was getting a lot of hate comments on TikTok and even people in real life. Then it all clicked. I knew I recognized her voice and I actually knew who she was. After a few minutes, I asked her if she was who I thought and she was really surprised. I started to tell her how one of her Videos actually changed my life and got me out of a toxic relationship. She knew I wasn't lying because I told her all about it. I asked her one more time and she finally agreed to try and make herself throw up. She was unconscious when the paramedics got there, but because of that, she was still alive. She now has millions of followers and I'm glad to see her much happier today.

My son made a kid cry on his birthday and I was so proud of him. When my son was in the third grade, he was a bully. We tried everything, but he kept constantly getting in trouble and sent to the office. He was known throughout the school for tying balloons to the class rabbit and almost letting it float away. I was leaving work to go get him and as my phone rang, I already knew who it was. I had a special ringtone for his teacher because she called me so much just so I could prepare to hear what he did. She was crying when I answered and I knew it was bad. I told her I was on the way, but instead of getting upset, she started to thank me. I was really confused and she started to talk about what a sweet boy I raised. Literally nobody had ever told me that before for. And I asked what happened. Apparently another kid who didn't have a lot of friends was in his class and his mom had handed out birthday invitations to everyone the day before. Right before the bell went off, he stood up in front of everyone and asked who was coming to his party. The entire class was now silent and he just stood there looking around for someone to tell him they were going. Nobody was saying anything. And she said she could see the kids heart literally breaking in Real time. Then, as he went to sit back down in shame, my son stood up and said, I'm gonna come. I'll be there. His face lit up, and one by one, all the other boys in the class followed his lead and also started telling him they'd come, too. He was trying not to cry when we showed up that weekend.

People who got expelled from school. What did you do in 9th grade? I got the teacher everybody wanted for biology. Except one morning our entire class could hear her outside the room getting chewed out by our assistant principal for being late on grading. We also knew she had lost her sister the week before, so she was having a really rough time. A few minutes into teaching, she started explaining something about our final exam and the guys next to me were passing notes. They usually did it every time she turned around, but this time she saw them. She usually wouldn't have cared, but she thought it was something about her. So she walked over and asked to see it. Kid shook his head without saying anything. So she basically reached into his pocket to grab the note. She started reading it in front of the class and said, I left it in the garbage bin in room W12. It's all there with the. And stopped herself before reading the rest out loud. She looked down at the boy, clearly having read something bad and didn't know what to say. Her face was pale and not knowing what to do. She grabbed them both and literally yanked them out of the room. We all sat there confused for a half hour wondering what that note said. There were police at our school and they asked our whole route to come to the office. They questioned everybody about It, but nobody knew anything. And by the time they let us go, they had sent everybody home. We later found out that the note said there was a key to the office in that garbage bin along with a loaded gun. Both of them denied writing it and said they didn't know who it was for. So they decided to fire our teacher for creating a school wide panic and expelled our entire row.

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? A few students decided to play a senior prank on the principal by writing on his car. And it made him so mad he decided to cancel the entire prom for the year. Everyone was pissed. So at the homecoming game the week after, we were chanting to bring it back. Eventually at the end, some kid with a banana suit jumped over the bleachers and ran across the field. Everyone screamed as he was being chased by coaches and teachers, and even the players loved it. Eventually, they tackled him hard and he ended up breaking his arm and had to go to the hospital. They had to cancel the game and the staff were so mad they suspended him for the rest of the year. He was probably gonna get expelled, but the students loved him so much, they decided they were gonna do something about it. That day, free Banana Man was born and everyone started chanting it in the halls. Few guys sold t shirts that said it and they wrote it all over the walls. At our school, there were bananas everywhere. And this made our principal so mad, he banned the phrase entirely. However, he didn't just stop there. He decided to go as far as to ban the actual fruit itself and even the entire color yellow. You literally weren't allowed to wear yellow to school. And if you were caught eating A banana, you were sent home for the day. This rule made the entire student body so furious they pretty much declared a war on the administration. Hundreds of students were getting sent home because they decided to bring bananas and wear yellow. And when they tell them to take their yellow shirts off, they'd walk around shirtless to class. I even saw a guy come to school in all yellow, and when they made him take it off, he tried to go to class only in his underwear, which was also yellow. It got so crazy that one kid who literally needed to eat bananas for the potassium couldn't for the week and ended up passing out in the middle of class. He went to the hospital and his parents threatened to sue the school. The very next day, we watched our principal walk out for the last time and the banana guy returned wearing his costume.

My teacher thought I was cheating on a test, so she sent me to the er. When I was in 9th grade, I got stuck with our school's worst teacher, who was infamous for trying to make a Muslim girl take off her headwear to prove she wasn't wearing headphones in class. There were a lot of students who got away with cheating by wearing headphones during tests, so she was constantly checking. Since then, she didn't do anything too bad until we had to take our final exam at the end of the year and she stood up to walk around the room. It was really hot that day, so I wore a lighter shirt. I also happened to have type 1 diabetes, so you could see my insulin pump. That day, my blood sugar was low, so I turned my pump on and walked into class. We were almost done taking the test and she stood up to walk around the room. I was honestly focused on just passing until I heard her walk straight up behind me. In that moment, two things happened. She grabbed my paper off my desk and told me I failed. And I felt her grab the pump on my waist. I just sat there in shock as she walked away and had no idea what had just happened. However, it wasn't until I noticed she was holding Scissors that it clicked what she had just done. She seen the wire hanging off My waist and assumed I had headphones in. When I looked down, the tube was cut. After a few seconds, my pump started beeping very loudly and everyone started looking at me. A few people sitting around me saw what happened and were in shock. She came over and when she realized what she did, I watched her face turn pale. She had messed up big time and had no idea what to do and neither did I. She told me to go to the nurse and on the way there, I started getting, see, I made it there, could feel myself starting to pass out. The nurse called 9 1 1 and I had to go to the hospital. But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

Teachers, what's the saddest thing you found out about a student? I taught 5th grade for a few years and had to stay up really late one night to grade some essays. I was exhausted, but I remember reading one of them and couldn't believe what I saw. I told my class to write about a funny story, and this girl, Kelly, wrote about how her mom had almost killed her. She said her mom woke her and her brothers up one morning yelling at them because someone ate a candy from her room. All of them denied it, so they had to stand in a corner until one of them admitted they had eaten it. After an hour, nobody said anything. So their mom stepped it up. She was determined to find who did it, so she made all of them drink an entire cup of salt water until they vomited. She said her throat hurt so much she started crying. I couldn't believe I was reading this and thought she had to have been making it up. I knew her mom and she seemed so nice. She said whoever ate it would have to sleep outside that night. And when she was about to get another glass of salt water, her brother stepped up. He said he took it and her mom was furious. She was literally moving his bed outside. But as she did, their dad came home and had no idea what was going on when He found out it was because of the candy. He told them he was the one who ate it. This was supposed to be her funny story. This girl was 9 and there was no way she was making this up. I couldn't just go to bed. So I called and woke our student advisor up and read her essay word for word over the phone. She, too, didn't believe it was real. So we asked her about it the next day at school. Apparently she just thought it was a funny story and didn't think her mom was being too mean. We had to report. But as soon as someone went out to talk to her parents, she took her daughter out of the school. I hope she's doing okay. Update. I just saw her on the news. She was arrested and put in jail last night.

My mom almost ended my life, but her gut feeling saved me. I remember sitting in math when the bell rang and I started walking towards the library to eat lunch. I was starving. There was nowhere to sit except the very back. As soon as I sat down, I remember hearing a sound from the hallway that sounded like a door slamming onto the ground. Nobody really reacted. But then we heard a girl screaming outside the library. She came running down the hallway and we heard the noise again. It was so silent in there until she yelled, somebody help, he has a gun. And everyone completely panicked. I remember freezing up because I didn't know where to go. The room was all windows and everyone started flooding out the back door. I move and another guy went to hide in a utility closet behind us. He told me to come inside, so I did. We sat there silently crying for about five minutes, slugging our ears. It felt like hours. And everyone screaming was gone. It was so quiet. So we opened the window on the door slightly to see out. As soon as I did, I saw they were inside the library. We stayed as silent as we possibly could and my mom wouldn't stop texting me. We couldn't move, but I realized if my mom calls me, my phone would go off. If she called me, we probably wouldn't survive. We sat there with our Hands over our mouths, trying to breathe as quietly as we could. And I was praying they wouldn't look inside. We could hear them right outside the closet we were in. But they started running out and we heard the police in the school. We sat there for another hour until the police found us and we made it out safe. When I asked my mom why she didn't call me, she said she didn't want it to ring in case I might be hiding.

But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

Parents, what do your kids think they're hiding from you? My 13 year old son, Alex asked if he could download a chess app on his tablet. I was shocked. All his friends were begging for Fortnite or some zombie game, and here's my kid wanting to play chess. I said yes immediately. See, I'm pretty strict about screen time. No games, no social media. Homework first. Alex has always been quiet, kind of awkward around other kids. Chess seemed perfect for building his brain. He got obsessed fast. Every day after school, straight to his room with that tablet. I'd hear him muttering moves under his breath. Night to E4, check. When I asked how it was going, he'd light up, talking about strategy and logic patterns. Months in, I noticed something weird. He'd quickly close the tablet whenever I walked in. Said he was just thinking through positions. Then one night, I heard him talking. Not muttering chess moves, actually talking to someone. I knocked. Who are you talking to? Just practicing out loud, dad. Helps me think. My gut said something was wrong. Next day, I checked his tablet while he was at school. The chess app was deleted. Completely gone. When I asked him about it, he said he took a break and was doing puzzles in his head now. That's when I installed tracking software. Took me three days to figure out how, but I did it. What I found made my blood boil. He'd Been using a fake chess app that was actually a cover for some underground gambling site. He was playing speed chess for money against adults online. Real money. His username was Chess Master J, and he had over $400 in his account. I watched one of his matches through the tracker. My quiet, awkward kid was trash talking grown men like some kind of gaming streamer. You call that a defense? My little sister plays better than you. Then he destroyed them in under five minutes with moves I couldn't even follow. But here's the crazy part. I kept watching, and this wasn't some gambling addiction. The kid was genuinely incredible. He was beating adults who'd been playing for decades. One guy even accused him of cheating and demanded a video call. Alex turned on his camera, solved three chess puzzles in 30 seconds, then checkmated the guy in seven moves while explaining every decision. I dug deeper into his account. Turns out he'd been banned from our school's chess team six months ago for embarrassing another school's coach during a live tournament. Coach had called Alex a know it nothing kid. So Alex responded by beating him in front of 200 people while explaining each mistake the coach made. The school said it was unsportsmanlike conduct. Alex never told me. Just said he quit the team because it was boring. So for months, he'd been rebuilding his reputation online, earning money, and getting revenge on everyone who'd written him Off the fake chess app. Wasn't about being lazy. It was about hiding how good he actually was. That night at dinner, I put a chess board between us. Wanna play a quick game? His face went white. Dad, I don't really. One game. Humor your old man.

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? A few students decided to play a senior prank on the principal by writing on his car. And it made him so mad he decided to cancel the entire prom for the year. Everyone was pissed. So at the homecoming game the week after, we were chanting to bring it back. Eventually at the end, some kid with a banana suit jumped over the bleachers and ran across the field. Everyone screamed as he was being chased by coaches and teachers, and even the players loved it. Eventually, they tackled him hard and he ended up breaking his arm and had to go to the hospital. They had to cancel the game and the staff were so mad they suspended him for the rest of the year. He was probably gonna get expelled, but the students loved him so much, they decided they were gonna do something about it. That day, free Banana Man was born and everyone started chanting it in the halls. Few guys sold t shirts that said it and they wrote it all over the walls. At our school, there were bananas everywhere. And this made our principal so mad, he banned the phrase entirely. However, he didn't just stop there. He decided to go as far as to ban the actual fruit itself and even the entire color yellow. You literally weren't allowed to wear yellow to school. And if you were caught eating A banana, you were sent home for the day. This rule made the entire student body so furious they pretty much declared a war on the administration. Hundreds of students were getting sent home because they decided to bring bananas and wear yellow. And when they tell them to take their yellow shirts off, they'd walk around shirtless to class. I even saw a guy come to school in all yellow, and when they made him take it off, he tried to go to class only in his underwear, which was also yellow. It got so crazy that one kid who literally needed to eat bananas for the potassium couldn't for the week and ended up passing out in the middle of class. He went to the hospital and his parents threatened to sue the school. The very next day, we watched our principal walk out for the last time and the banana guy returned wearing his costume.

Teachers, what's the saddest thing you found out about a student? I taught fifth grade for a few years and had to stay up really late one night to grade some essays. I was exhausted, but I remember reading one of them and couldn't believe what I saw. I told my class to write about a funny story, and this girl, Kelly, wrote about how her mom had almost killed her. She said her mom woke her and her brothers up one morning yelling at them because someone ate a candy from her room. All of them denied it, so they had to stand in a corner until one of them admitted they had eaten it. After an hour, nobody said anything, so their mom stepped it up. She was determined to find who did it, so she made all of them drink an entire cup of salt water until they vomited. She said her throat hurt so much, she started crying. I couldn't believe I was reading this and thought she had to have been making it up. I knew her mom, and she seemed so nice. She said whoever ate it would have to sleep outside that night. And when she was about to get another glass of salt water, her brother stepped up. He said he took it, and her mom was furious. She was literally moving his bed outside. But as she did, their dad came home and had no idea what was going on. When He found out it was because of the candy. He told them he was the one who ate it. This was supposed to be her funny story. This girl was 9, and there was no way she was making this up. I couldn't just go to bed, so I called and woke our student advisor up and read her essay word for word over the phone. She, too, didn't believe it was real, so we asked her about it the next day at school. Apparently, she just thought it was a funny story and didn't think her mom was being too mean. We had to report, but as soon as someone went out to talk to her parents, she took her daughter out of the school. I hope she's doing okay. Update? I just saw her on the news. She was arrested and put in jail last night.

People who got expelled from school, what did you do in ninth grade? I got the teacher everybody wanted for biology. Except one morning, our entire class could hear her outside the room getting chewed out by our assistant principal for being late on grading. We also knew she had lost her sister the week before, so she was having a really rough time. A few minutes into teaching, she started explaining something about our final exam, and the guys next to me were passing notes. They usually did it every time she turned around, but this time she saw them. She usually wouldn't have cared, but she thought it was something about her, so she walked over and asked to see it. Kid shook his head without saying anything, so she basically reached into his pocket to grab the note. She started reading it in front of the class and said, I left it in the garbage bin in room W12. It's all there with the. And stopped herself before reading the rest out loud. She looked down at the boy, clearly having read something bad and didn't know what to say. Her face was pale, and not knowing what to do, she grabbed them both and literally yanked them out of the room. We all sat there confused for a half hour, wondering what that note said. There were police at our school, and they asked our whole row to come to the office. They questioned everybody about It. But nobody knew anything and by the time they let us go they had sent everybody home. We later found out that the note said there was a key to the office in that garbage bin along with a loaded gun. Both of them denied writing it and said they didn't know who it was for. So they decided to fire our teacher for creating a school wide panic and expelled our entire row.

How did you become a millionaire? When I was 17, my mom forced me to start babysitting, but I had no idea who I was doing it for. When I met this woman, I couldn't believe how overprotective she was. She had cameras in every room of the house and asked me to call her every half hour just to make sure her daughter was okay. She told me I wasn't allowed to do anything except watch her. And when she finally left, I basically just sat there for three hours doing nothing until she came home. She came back and basically ran into the room to make sure the girl was okay and I assured her everything was fine. I had long hair at the time and had put it up at this point. And should probably now mention I have severe hearing loss. I have to wear hearing aids, which can usually be easily mistaken for headphones. Then as I was standing up to say bye to the girl, her mom noticed them in my ears. She thought I was wearing headphones the whole time and wasn't paying attention to the little girl. This made her furious and a second later, I felt her grab my head. All I remember was feeling the worst pain I've ever felt in my ear. I turned around to see her holding my hearing aid and realized what she did. She thought I was listening to music. She ripped my hearing aid. Out of my ear, thinking it was a headphone. And since they connect directly to my eardrum, she completely ripped that out, too. The pain was so intense I passed out and woke up in the hospital to my mom crying. She was livid. And even though they begged us not to, we sued her. I will never hear out of my ear again, but I'll never have to work again either.

I watched so much TikTok, it ended up saving a life. My first few months as a 9 1 1 operator were scary, but nothing could have prepared me for when I got a call late at night from a young girl. I could barely understand what she was saying through her sobbing, but she told me she had just swallowed an entire bottle of pills and just wanted someone to talk to before they did anything. I started asking her why she would do that and asked for her address. She thought I already had it, but after a few minutes she finally told me where she lived. She said she was severely depressed and just wanted everything to end. I asked her why. Just trying to keep her on the phone and she said she couldn't take the hate she was getting anymore. I knew I only had literal minutes to do something and tried talking her into throwing up. She told me no, so I asked her what kind of hate she was getting. Apparently she just wanted people to like her and wanted to help people. She was getting a lot of hate comments on TikTok and even people in real life. Then it all clicked. I knew I recognized her voice and I actually knew who she was. After a few minutes I asked her if she was who I thought and she was really surprised. I started to tell her how one of her Videos actually changed my life and got me out of a toxic relationship. She knew I wasn't lying because I told her all about it. I asked her one more time, and she finally agreed to try and make herself throw up. She was unconscious when the paramedics got there, but because of that, she was still alive. She now has millions of followers, and I'm glad to see her much happier today.

Have you ever seen a teacher get fired? I went to a public school that love to control its students and one day they introduced the dumbest rule I've ever heard. Apparently they thought too many people were out in the halls instead of learning. So one morning they announced that students were no longer allowed to go to the bathroom during class. I literally thought it was a joke at first people started getting detention for being in the halls during class. Didn't matter how bad you had to pee, you simply weren't allowed to go. I remember watching a few people sit through class in pain because they couldn't go. But that was nothing compared to one girl. We were in art class and that teacher had got into multiple arguments with our principal about the rule. A lot of people loved this teacher, but I think our principal even threatened to fire him. So when a girl in my class was dying to go pee, he couldn't let her. She ended up sitting there in pain butting for 20 minutes and wasn't gonna make it until lunch. So since he wasn't gonna let her pee her pants in front of all her friends, our art teacher decided to walk her over to our art storage room. He stood outside the door and she peed in a bucket. Pretty good move on his part. Now, he wasn't gonna lose his job. That's what you think. Turns out A few bratty kids in our class knew what she did and started telling their parents. The news of it spread, and soon enough, reporters were at our school questioning him. The next day, there was a news article about how that teacher made the girl pee in a bucket but didn't mention our school's rule at all. Our school's administration panicked, and guess who they blamed? They fired him for creating an unsafe environment.
NA

My son made a kid cry on his birthday and I was so proud of him. When my son was in the third grade, he was a bully. We tried everything, but he kept constantly getting in trouble and sent to the office. He was known throughout the school for tying balloons to the class rabbit and almost letting it float away. I was leaving work to go get him and as my phone rang, I already knew who it was. I had a special ringtone for his teacher because she called me so much just so I could prepare to hear what he did. She was crying when I answered and I knew it was bad. I told her I was on the way, but instead of getting upset, she started to thank me. I was really confused and she started to talk about what a sweet boy I raised. Literally nobody had ever told me that before. And I asked what happened. Apparently another kid who didn't have a lot of friends was in his class and his mom had handed out birthday invitations to everyone the day before. Right before the bell went off, he stood up in front of everyone and asked who was coming to his party. Entire class was now silent and he just stood there looking around for someone to tell him they were going. Nobody was saying anything and she said she could see the kids heart literally breaking in real time. Then as he went to sit back down in shame, my son stood up and said, I'm gonna come. I'll be there. His face lit up, and one by one all the other boys in the class followed his lead and also started telling him they'd come, too. He was trying not to cry when we showed up that weekend.

My mom almost ended my life, but her gut feeling saved me. I remember sitting in math when the bell rang, and I started walking towards the library to eat lunch. I was starving. There was nowhere to sit except the very back. As soon as I sat down, I remember hearing a sound from the hallway that sounded like a door slamming onto the ground. Nobody really reacted, but then we heard a girl screaming outside the library. She came running down the hallway, and we heard the noise again. It was so silent in there until she yelled, somebody help! He has a gun! And everyone completely panicked. I remember freezing up because I didn't know where to go. The room was all windows, and everyone started flooding out the back door. I move, and another guy went to hide in a utility closet behind us. He told me to come inside, so I did. We sat there silently crying for about five minutes, slugging our ears. It felt like hours. And everyone screaming was gone. It was so quiet. So we opened the window on the door slightly to see out. As soon as I did, I saw they were inside the library. We stayed as silent as we possibly could, and my mom wouldn't stop texting me. We couldn't move, but I realized if my mom calls me, my phone would go off. If she called me, we probably wouldn't survive. We sat there with our Hands over our mouths, trying to breathe as quietly as we could. And I was praying they wouldn't look inside. We could hear them right outside the closet we were in. But they started running out, and we heard the police in the school. We sat there for another hour until the police found us. And we made it out safe. When I asked my mom why she didn't call me, she said she didn't want it to ring in case I might be hiding

And even though they begged us not to, we sued her. I will never hear out of my ear again, but I'll never have to work again either.

Has your school ever had a real lockdown? A really well known celebrity that graduated from our high school was coming to speak one morning and a lot of the girls were really excited. But an hour before it was supposed to start, we were told to go to the gym and not bring anything. When I walked in, there were police dogs and officers searching everybody. Nobody really thought it was weird because this person was famous. But when everyone was inside the gym, we were told we weren't allowed to leave. This is when it started to seem weird. And after a while, some people were asking to go to the bathroom. They had to be escorted by police officers and they started asking every guy wearing a gray shirt to come down and talk to them. Lunch passed and people were getting angry and we had to eat in the gym. Nobody knew what was happening and none of the teachers would say anything. cops kept showing up to talk to people and wouldn't let anyone leave. One guy tried to fight one of the cops when he wouldn't let him out and they actually arrested him. It was past the end of school and still nobody was allowed out of the gym. Parents couldn't pick us up either because they couldn't even come on the property. the entire school was surrounded and everyone was getting really mad. So our principal finally told us what Was going on. She sounded really on edge and told us the police were searching the school because there was a bomb threat in one of the bathrooms. I'll never forget how quiet it was and everyone was terrified. Nobody was allowed to leave until they found who did it. But after a half hour, they took another kid down and arrested him. We all knew it was him because we were allowed to leave after. But it was surprising because he was one of the popular guys. Everyone knew this was super weird for him. But the next morning we found out what happened and nobody could believe they looked through the cameras for the entire day because one of our older teachers had heard a boy in a gray shirt say something in the hallway. Turns out he completely misunderstood what he meant when he overheard him telling another boy that he was going to blow up the bathroom later that day.

Apparently they thought too many people were out in the halls instead of learning. So one morning they announced that students were no longer allowed to go to the bathroom during class. NA
NA

Man, there is no lonelier feeling in school than when the teacher says, alright, class, pick a partner. And suddenly it's like musical chairs, but your chair disappeared. Like it's instant. People don't even wait. They already sliding across the room, locking in with their besties, acting like they rehearsed it. And me, I'm just sitting there fake smiling, pretending I'm not slowly panicking inside. You try to play it cool, looking around casually, acting like you're just taking your time. Deep down you're screaming, please, somebody make eye contact with me. And somehow everyone just knows how to avoid you. Like your whole class became trained professionals and not seeing you. It's like they went blind with precision. You shift in your seat a little, do that awkward cough like, hey, I'm still here. Nothing. Then the teacher hits you with the, oh, looks like you don't have a partner. Thanks for announcing it to the entire room, Mrs. Ava. Why not just put me under a spotlight and cue the sad violin while you're at it? And the worst part, the teacher sees it, oh, you don't have a partner. Hmm. Okay, just join that group over there, bro. That group already teamed up, planned the project, probably already gave each other nicknames and now I gotta slide in like the substitute friend. It's always the quiet group too. So now we're all just awkwardly pretending to be okay while not saying a single word at that point. I'm like, you know what, I'll work alone. I'll suffer in silence. At least I don't gotta ask someone if I can use their glue stick. And don't even get me started on when the teacher just assigns you to the one person in class you don't get along with. Now y'all gotta pretend to be civil for 5 minutes while exchanging half hearted ideas and silently judging each other's handwriting.

We all have that one friend that just never sleeps. Like I swear bro does not know what a bed is. I'll wake up at 8:00am and they're still online. Like, bro, I haven't slept yet. Like, what do you mean you haven't slept yet? I swear bro is secretly an owl because they never go to bed until it's brighter than the billboards in Times Square. It becomes genuinely impossible to make plans with them because their whole sleep schedule is comparable to Batman. Like, bro, one time I invited them to go see a movie at three PM and they look at me like I just suggested we go jump into the Grand Canyon. It genuinely gets to a point where I go weeks without seeing them because we're never awake at the same time. I swear sometimes I'll see them at school with eye bags darker than my future and they'll go, bro, I've been awake for 36 hours. Like it's some sort of flex, my brother in Christ, go to bed. And the worst part is that they'll genuinely try to act like it's normal. Like, nah, I'm built differently. No, bro, you're built wrong. You're not mysterious. You're medically concerning. I genuinely think we need to have an intervention for them because at this rate, they're gonna end up sleepwalking off a cliff.
NA
NA

My girlfriend said, you're my boyfriend, so act like one. So I did exactly that and watched her world crumble. She watched me get down on one knee five times and said no every single time. Eight years together. I've been playing husband since year 2. Paying her car note, keeping her on my insurance, covering most of the rent while she found herself through three different careers. She had this whole routine down. Tears in her eyes, hand on her heart. Then some perfectly rehearsed excuse. We're not ready, let's wait till we're more stable. The timing isn't right. Then came proposal No. 5. And she finally showed me who she really was. I'd gone all out this time. I'm convinced myself that maybe the problem was I hadn't made it special enough. I rented out her favorite restaurants, rooftop, hung string lights everywhere, and invited all our friends and family there. The whole production cost me three months salary, but I thought it'd be worth it. When she finally said yes. My girlfriend stood there in the dress I'd bought her, surrounded by everyone we knew. And she didn't even let me finish the speech. Just shook her head with this pitying smile. Like I was a dog that wouldn't stop bringing her the same stick. Back at our apartment that night, I finally broke. Asked her straight up if she loved me. Why did she keep doing this? Her whole face changed in an instant. And the Mask came completely off. It's my choice when I accept a proposal, she said, voice ice cold. You don't get to pressure me with your timeline. You're my boyfriend, so act like one. Stop trying to be my husband when I haven't even accepted your proposal. Know your place. Know my place? After eight years of building a life together, I was supposed to know my place? Those words rewired something in my brain. Eight years of playing husband while she kept me a boyfriend status because it was convenient for her. She wanted me to act like a boyfriend. Fine. I give her exactly what she asked for. But boyfriends don't pay their girlfriends bills. Boyfriends don't share bank accounts. Boyfriends don't sacrifice their futures for someone who won't even wear their ring. I started my new boyfriend only policy the next morning while she was at her yoga class. First, I sold the ring to a dealer for 12 grand, enough to cover what I'd spent on her car this year alone. Then I called Verizon and removed her from my phone plan. By the time she got home from yoga, I changed every password and moved my money from our joint account. Didn't even notice until lunch when her phone died mid phone call. Babe, my phone's not working. She texted from her laptop, annoyed but not worried. Call Verizon. It's being weird. An hour later, they said, I'm not on the account anymore. Then the panic Started creeping in. What did you do? I responded, I'm being your boyfriend and not your husband, just like you said. She actually laughed at first, thinking it was some kind of joke. She came home that night, acting extra sweet. Made my favorite dinner and tried to cuddle on the couch. Okay, you made your point, she said, kissing my neck. I'll think about what you said. Now fix my phone. I moved to the guest bedroom instead. The next morning, she couldn't log into Netflix. Then Hulu died.

I started calling everyone in my family fat every single week without fail. Aunt Patricia watched my plate like a hawk. Sweetie, are you sure you need the mashed potatoes and the rice? Then came the clothing comments. That's a brave choice wearing horizontal stripes. You know, dark colors are more slimming. I tried everything. I asked her privately to please stop focusing on my body. I told her it hurt my feelings. I even brought articles about body positivity. She patted my hand and say she was just looking out for me because she loved me. That opened the flood gates. Patricia has a point about portion control. My cousin Jennifer chimed in at Thanksgiving. Have you tried intermittent fasting? I could send you some links. Uncle Rob began his helpful gym advice. You know, muscle burns more calories. My 12 year old nephew started asking if I really needed dessert. Even grandma, sweet grandma, started saying things like, you have such a pretty face. If only my birthday dinner last month was when they took it too far. As I reached for a second slice of my own birthday cake, the entire table collectively sucked in their breath. Aunt Diane actually moved the cake. Go away from me. We're doing this because we love you, she said. Fifteen relatives nodded an agreement. The next family dinner, I came prepared. Aunt Patricia reached for the bread and I gasped. Patricia, carbs after six? That's brave. She froze, hand midair. I kept.

Guys, y'all do not know how annoying it is to be colorblind. Like you're just chilling with your friends and then you tell them or they find out that you're colorblind. They will begin to ask the dumbest question, like, what color is my shirt? Or what color is the grass? Like, your shirt is purple. And then they say, no, it's blue. Like, bro, it isn't my fault that I didn't know that because I see purple. And then as soon as they know it, they'll tell their friends, like, bro, did you know he's color blind? And then in one second, everyone comes and asks me questions. And then there is that one time I was with a friend, we got out of the store and I see a purple bicycle with green wheels. So I say, bro, what is that combination, bro? Like purple and green? And then he says, bro, that's blue. And I say, no. And then he calls an old man and says, sir, that bicycle is blue, right? And that gentleman says, yes. And then he says, well, that guy says it's purple. Or one time I saw someone drawing with gray and I asked him, dude, why are you coloring with gray? And he says, uh, bro, it's dark green.

You ever been happy about intentionally manipulating someone? Every Thursday for three years, I told my wife Becca the same thing. I'm going to hang with the boys tonight. Be back around midnight. Truth is, I was driving to the cinema to watch movies alone because I just needed some me time. But then two months ago, my movie ended abruptly, and I came home two hours earlier than planned. When I turned onto our street, there was a black Infinity in our driveway. My heart stopped as I watched back all the footage from our doorbell camera and saw a man getting out of the car and walk. Hang up like he'd done it before. Becca opened. Before he could ring, they kissed. The kind where her hand went to his neck. My stomach dropped. I wanted to burst through that door and confront them, but I decided on the spot that that would be too kind. I need. Needed to do something else. Something that would destroy her. So I drove around until 12:30 and walked in with a story about Tony getting drunk. Becca was showering. Hey, babe. How was your night? Good. You know how it is. Then next two Thursdays, I kept my routine, but park down the street at 8:30 to watch. At the same time, the same car pulled up. I zoomed in on the ring footage, and that's when it hit me. The man was Mark. Mark, who supposedly moved to Seattle. Two years ago, my knees were shaking, but I took screenshots and sent them to my lawyer to further build my case. When I was confident enough that I had everything basically set up, I dropped the bomb. Becca was going on about her fake plans for when I left for Boys Night, when I randomly blurted out, you know who I miss? Mark. That guy and I used to have so much fun before he moved to Seattle. Her fork stopped halfway to her mouth just for a second. Yeah, Mark was great. You guys still text, though, right? Sometimes. The next morning, she woke up different, with this nervous energy. She made some phone calls behind closed doors, and since it was Thursday, during lunch, she texted, what time are you heading out tonight? She never asked before, so I knew. The comment about Mark got her. Probably 7:30. Why? Just wondering. The guys doing anything special? Same old. After work. She was cooking in full makeup. You look nice, I said. Just felt like making an effort for you to come home to. But she kept checking her phone and setting it down, then pick getting it back up at 7:15. She practically pushed me out. Don't want you to be late. Tell everyone I say hi. I drove to my regular spot down the street where I watched them, but this time, there was no car that showed up. And at 9:15, Becca's own car pulled Out. I followed her. First stop, O'malley Sports Bar, where she thought I'd be. She walked in confidently, then came out five minutes later looking confused, checking her phone, scanning the parking lot. Then she got back in her car. Her second stop, the dugout, another sports bar. Through the windows, I watched her walk the entire place, moving table to table, even checking the bathroom entrance area. She showed her phone to a waitress, who shrugged. Back to the car, more frantic phone checking. Third stop, Buffalo Wild Wings. She stayed longer this time, 15 minutes. I could see her at the bar talking to the manager, showing him something on her phone. Probably my pic. He shook his head, pointed to their mostly empty tables. Thursday wasn't exactly Prime Sports Bar night. Fourth stop, the dive bar where Tony actually used to drag us. She went straight to the bartender. I slipped in through the side door, ducked into the hallway by the bathrooms. Heard her say, every Thursday night, group of guys, probably five or six of them, loud. One of them looks like this. The bartender studied her phone. Thursday's our slowest night. I definitely remember a regular group. Sorry. She left looking frustrated, sat in her car for five minutes typing furiously. Then she drove to the A M C. Theater. I gave her a 10 minute head start, then walked in through the side entrance. She was at the concession stand talking to the Teenage manager showed her phone again. He pointed toward the theaters. She went to check each one. Open doors, scanning the sparse Thursday night crowds. I went back to my car. Twenty minutes later, she emerged, looking defeated. Sat in her car for another 10 minutes. Through her rear window, I could see her on the phone, gesturing with her free hand. Probably calling Mark. Probably saying she couldn't find me anywhere. That maybe I knew that Thursday nights might not be safe anymore. She even drove by two more bars on the way home. Quick stops, desperate checks. When I got home at my your time, she was on the couch with wine, trying to look casual, but her leg was bouncing. How was your night? Studying. Guys go. Oh, Malley's. Why? Her jaw clenched. No reason. Just curious. Was it busy? Pretty dead, actually. Who all was there? Haven't heard their names in a while. The usual.

What's the funniest thing someone's ever paid you to do? When I was 17, my classmate Derek threw 50 bucks at me in the school parking lot and desperately said, I need you to be my boyfriend for one hour to scare off my mom's church friends. His mom thought he was gay because she found his elaborate skincare routine and absolutely freaked out. She was bringing her entire prayer circle over for what she called a healing intervention to save Derek's soul from eternal damnation. Act super gay and make them uncomfortable, Derek explained frantically while pacing nervously. They'll get so weirded out, they'll pack up and leave within 20 minutes. Easy money, right? I showed up at exactly 3 p m. Wearing the tightest jeans I could squeeze into and a bright pink shirt. I knocked on the door and screamed Derek, baby! So loud that neighbors three houses down started coming outside to see what could trophy was happening. His mom answered with five absolutely horrified church ladies clustered behind her like a religious huddle preparing for spiritual warfare. I immediately bear hugged Derek and loudly announced sweetie pie. I brought us matching cucumber face masks and a carefully curated playlist of Broadway show tunes for our romantic spa day. Derek's face went complete pale, but I was fully committed to this Oscar worthy performance. For the next hour, I went into full theater kid mode like my life depended on it. I called him Sugar Plum. Honey Bunny and my precious little cinnamon roll. I critiqued his mom's curtain choices with the intensity of a professional interior designer, started reorganizing their entire spice rack alphabetically while humming songs from Hamilton, and loudly complained that their throw pillows didn't match the seasonal aesthetic vision. And I was going for. The church ladies looked like they were watching a slow motion car crash that they couldn't look away from. One kept fanning herself frantically with a church program. Another was gripping her purse like it was a life preserver in a stormy sea. Then I made my absolutely fatal mistake. I spotted their old dusty piano sitting in the corner and declared dramatically, with full jazz hands, Derek, Honey, let's sing that special duet we've been practicing for the school talent show. Without waiting for his response, I launched into the most ridiculously over the top rendition of A Whole New World that is ever been performed outside of Broadway. Derek just stood there completely mortified and frozen like a deer in headlights. When I finished with a dramatic flourish, the church lady slowly started clapping. Then another joined in. Then all five of them erupted in thunderous applause like I had just performed at Carnegie Hall. Young man, the head church lady said, with actual tears streaming down her weathered face, that was the most beautiful, soul stirring thing I've ever heard in my entire life. Derek, you absolutely must marry this talented boy before someone else Snatches him up. Derek's mom immediately started planning our entire wedding on the spot, pulling out her phone to call venues and florists while I stood there still frozen in my final dramatic pose. But the situation got infinitely worse from there. The church ladies loved my performance so much that they invited me to sing at their Sunday morning service. They wanted me performing how great thou art with full choreography and backup dancers. One was already texting her granddaughter about hiring me for her Sweet 16 party. Derek was full on panicking at this point. His mom was already picking out flower arrangements and discussing catering menu options. One church lady was asking about my ring size and whether I preferred gold or silver wedding bands. Then Derek's little sister walked in from soccer practice, took one look at the complete chaos unfolding in their living room, and announced loudly to everyone, mom literally paid him $50 to pretend to be his boyfriend. I heard them planning this whole ridiculous scheme in the garage this morning. The silence that followed was absolutely deafening. Eric's mom slowly turned to stare at him with the fury of a thousand burning suns. The church ladies all stared at me in complete shock and bewilderment. I was still holding my jazz hands from the performance finale. Finally, after what felt like hours, the head church lady cleared her throat and said with perfect composure, well, Derek, at least we know you have Absolutely excellent taste in entertainment. She turned to me with a business like expression. Are you available for my granddaughter's wedding reception next month? We'll pay triple what Derek gave you. Derek still owes me another hundred dollars because I ended up singing at four more church events that month, including a funeral where I performed Amazing Grace with interpretive dance. His mom still asks me when we're setting our wedding date.
NA

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket, just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight. But by 12:30, half of them are knocked out brutally and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation, wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone's sneaking chips at 4:00am and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part, parents roll in. Like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.
NA

The popular girls at school bullied me for my Roblox channel, so I got revenge. My life has been a living hell since they found my channel, and it's getting worse every day, all because of one group of girls. Like, it started with hate comments and putting pictures in my locker, but the final straw was when they came into school and handed me a T-shirt of my channel, asking if I could sign it since I'm so famous. And, bro, her friends acted like this was the funniest thing they'd ever seen. But I wasn't gonna just let this slide now, so I did some digging and found all their social media channels and saw that they're actually trying to blow up on TikTok themselves, just not with much success. So since they wanna be famous, I'll make them famous by exposing everything they said, all in this video, then sending it to their parents, future college, and blowing this video up for millions to see. Help boost the video by subscribing.
NA

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

Bro, August was probably the craziest month in history. Like I don't even think historians are gonna know how to write this down. We literally got two new seasons in one month. An immortal person casually existing, a priest who went to hell and actually threw hands with Satan, radioactive nuclear spiders and then somehow the UK decided to spawn human sized rat. Oh, and the Black Plague made a comeback in 2025. But wait, it gets worse. Aliens are apparently landing in November. Citra out here building a 10 foot tall Terminator, animatronic, the Boo Boo dolls confirmed to be affiliated with the Devil. Ice cream trucks mysteriously appearing again like it's 2006. The iPhone 17 straight up leak. And then Roblox. Bro, Roblox was on another level of insanity. They said he sent an assist letter to SLEP which backfired so hard that SLEP actually clapped back. Roblox stock tanked by $12 billion. He dropped an AI generated apology. Chris Hanson pulled up, law by Mike pulled up and even the state of Louisiana started suing Roblox. Then out of nowhere, the US congressman gets involved. Roblox starts getting banned in countries like Qatar and Indonesia. And both the US and UK governments are now investigating Roblox for safety issues. While all this chaos is happening, creators like kreekraft are leaving the star program. And the best news of all, I got nearly 80,000 people to subscribe to my channel this month. Bro, August wasn't a month, it was An entire Netflix series.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. She showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated. He remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept stealing glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us. She found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting back, Or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over, set the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this whole thing started as pretend, but it doesn't feel fake.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I'd divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2 3 years, max. Change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation. To our eight year olds, that first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home, and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decision. It's no more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curveball. Our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year two brought unexpected changes. Without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to enjoy My children. Year three changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partner ship could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually, she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her bonus mom. Their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes, and tucked them in at night. Year five was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and be being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year six, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward. After three Years of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she own

I told my mom that I'm disgusted by and ashamed of my sister. It started when my sister Chloe came home crying because her boyfriend Jake dumped her. She's 25 and I'm 17, but she always acts like she's the victim in every situation. This time was different, though. She kept saying Jake was horrible and cruel. But when I asked what happened, she got all shifty. He said he broke up with her out of nowhere and kicked her out of his apartment. But then she mentioned she still had keys to his place because she forgot to give them back the next day. She left early in the morning and came back with this huge golden retriever. I recognized him immediately. It was Buster, Jake's dog. Jake love that dog more than anything. When his grandpa died last year, Buster was the only thing that helped him through it. I asked Chloe why she had Buster and she got this weird smile on her face. She said Jake didn't deserve to keep him since he broke her heart. Then she said something that made my stomach drop. She told me she was going to take Buster to the vet tomorrow to put him down as payback for what Jake did to her. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. This dog was completely healthy and happy, just confused about being in a new place. Buster kept looking around for Jake and whining by the door. It was heartbreaking. I told Chloe she was being insane and she couldn't just kill someone's dog because she was upset. She laughed and said Jake should have thought about that before he decided to hurt her. Then she said if I told anyone, she'd make sure I regretted it. That night I couldn't sleep. I kept thinking about Buster and how scared he must be. Around 2:00am, I heard Chloe on the phone with someone probably making the vet appointment. I knew I had to do something. Then next morning, Chloe left for work and told mom she was taking Buster for a walk later. Mom didn't know the whole story. Chloe just said Jake asked her to watch his dog for a few days. As soon as both then were gone, I called Jake. He picked up on the first ring and sounded terrible. I told him Chloe had Buster and was planning to put him down today. He went completely silent for like 10 seconds, then started freaking out. He said he'd been looking everywhere for Buster and thought maybe he got out somehow. I told Jake to come over now while Chloe was at work. He was at our house in 15 minutes. When he saw Buster, he literally started crying. Buster went crazy with excitement, jumping all over him and licking his face. I opened the door and Jake carried his dog out to his car. Before he left, Jake told me what really happened with Chloe. She Didn't just get dumped. She cheated on him with his best friend, Marcus. When Jake found out, he broke up with her and told her to move out. She stole Buster on her way out and left Jake's spare key on the counter so he thought she was being mature about the breakup. A few hours later, Chloe came home and went straight to look for Buster when she couldn't find him. She started screaming my name. She found me in my room and absolutely lost it. She called me a traitor and said I had no right to interfere in her business. Then mom came home and asked what all the yelling was about. Chloe told her I let some guy steal her dog. She made it sound like I just gave away her pet to a random stranger. Mom looked.

On a school trip, my best friend asked, if you had to choose between your mom and girlfriend to live, who would you pick? I responded, bros before hoes, but moms before all. And everyone cracked up. Jason didn't smile, though. His face drained of color like I just confessed to murder. He grabbed all his stuff and moved 3 rows up the school bus without a word. Jason, what's wrong? I was just kidding. I called after him, but he wouldn't turn around. That's when I heard it stay. Casey, my girlfriend's best friend, was crying her eyes out in the back row. When I turned to look, her friend whispered urgently in her ear and she glanced at me before crying harder. Okay, hey, that was definitely weird. I started to wonder whether my joke was really that offensive. That's when my phone buzzed. Three missed calls from dad, but there was no signal. And at the red light, I caught the bus driver wiping his eyes in the rearview mirror. In my three years of knowing him, the most emotion he'd shown was mild annoyance when kids left trash on the seats. A cold feeling crept into my stomach. I got up to go talk to Jason, but Missus Unfitzharris blocked the aisle. Sit down. We're moving. I just need to sit down. I'd never heard her voice like that. I sat. But the second we got to the destination, I cornered Jason. Dude, what is going On he backed away. Nothing. I just, I need space, bruh. I was just kidding. I don't know if I'd pick my mom or my girlfriend. Why did you have to tell everyone what I said? Sid appeared out of nowhere and pulled me aside. Our team captain who never said more.

Bro, why are popular girls so annoying? They're basically a fucking different species. why are they always screaming when they see each other in the hallway? Oh my God, hi, bestie girl. You saw her five minutes ago at your locker. And they always travel in packs like a swarm of pink, overly perfumed pigeons. You're trying to get to class and the hallway is always blocked. One's filming a TikTok, the others re applying lip gloss like she's on the red carpet. Like, move, bitch, I'm trying to get to class on time. And don't get me started on their fake compliments to you. Oh my God, your shoes are so cute. Then they turn around and go, did you see what he was wearing? I heard you, bitch. I have ears. And why do they act like they're the CEO of everything? The group project, they did nothing but somehow got the most credit. Party. They didn't even host it, but they still say, oh my God, our party was so fun. They're not even popular. Everyone is just scared of them. Like if you make eye contact for too long, they'll scan your outfit, judge your entire existence and sentence you to eternal hallway awkwardness. Nah, bro. Popular girls are like NPCs with main character syndrome. Total idiots, loud and everywhere. Follow for more daily rants.

What's the hilarious thing your grandma has ever done? My 82 year old grandma Dorothy discovered Amazon Prime last month. This woman who still doesn't trust ATMs and hides cash in cookie tins somehow figured out one click ordering. It started innocently. My cousin set up her account so she could order sunflower seeds for the cardinals in her yard. First delivery, 40 pounds of bird seed. Perfect. Second delivery, 80 pounds of bird seed just in case. Third delivery, an inflatable hot tub. Grandma, why did you buy a hot tub? I didn't buy hot tub. I just pushed button. But since it's here, she set it up in her small backyard. Soon her neighbors, Mrs. Johnson, Mrs. Miller and Mrs. Green, all in their 70s, started coming over for joint therapy sessions. They sit in the hot tub fully clothed because as grandma says, bikinis are for teenagers. Fourth delivery, a karaoke machine for hot tub nights. Now every Thursday evening, four elderly women sit in a hot tub belting out Elvis and Dolly Parton songs at top volume. Fifth delivery, 120 cans of Vienna sausages. It was bargain such deal. Grandma, you don't even like Vienna sausages but raccoons do. She's now feeding every raccoon in the county. Premium sausages. 6 delivery, a drone. Why do you need a drone? To spy on squirrels from kitchen she flew at once. It's now stuck in Mr Johnson's oak tree. He's convinced it's government surveillance and sprays it with The garden hose every morning. Seventh delivery. A 70 inch TV. Old TV. Too small. Grandma, your old TV was 60 inches. Yes, too small. Hard to see Judge Judy. She watches Judge Judy at volume 90 and yells advice at the screen like she's a co judge. The breaking point was delivery number eight. Motorcycle helmet. Grandma, you don't have a motorcycle? Not yet. Not yet. That's when I checked her Amazon cart. She had a Harley Davidson saved for later. I changed her password immediately. Why ruin my fun? Because you almost bought a motorcycle. It had good reviews. Now she has to call me Lana to order anything. But she found a loophole. She Learned Instacart. Last week, 50 watermelons showed up at her door. They sell by watermelon, not by pound. Deal of lifetime. She handed out watermelons to neighbors, delivery guys, even the UPS driver. Our street looks like a farmers market. Yesterday she called Lana. What's cryptocurrency? Why? Man on Facebook says I can turn watermelons into Bitcoin. Grandma, no, but he wears suit and picture looks smart. I rushed over. She was about to invest in something called Agricoin. Grandma, it's a scam, he said. I'm genius investor called me Warren Buffett of Ohio. She pouted then perked up. Lana, while you're here, help me set up TikTok. Mrs. Miller says. I could be influencer. Her username is now at hot tub grandma. 82. She has 20,000 followers in three weeks. Her top Video feeding Vienna sausages to raccoons while singing Dolly Parton. Comments are all. Protect this woman at all costs. She reads every comment through giant reading glasses and replies, bless your heart.

You ever been happy about intentionally manipulating someone? Every Thursday for three years, I told my wife Becca the same thing. I'm going to hang with the boys tonight, be back around midnight. Truth is, I was driving to the cinema to watch movies alone because I just needed some me time. But then two months ago, my movie ended abruptly and I came home two hours earlier than planned. When I turned onto our street, there was a black infinity in our driveway. My heart stopped as I watched back all the footage from our doorbell camera and saw a man getting out of the car and walk hang up like he done it before. Becca opened, before he could ring, they kissed the kind where her hand went to his neck. My stomach dropped. I wanted to burst through that door and confront them, but I decided on the spot that that would be too kind. I need did to do something else, something that would destroy her. You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like no big fall out, no drama, just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened. Like what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part, I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't. Cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. I can reach out, I can say something, but deep down I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it, pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them. I really wanted to stay Wakati Huo.

I told my mom that I'm disgusted by and ashamed of my sister. It started when my sister Chloe came home crying because her boyfriend Jake dumped her. She's 25 and I'm 17, but she always acts like she's the victim in every situation. This time was different, though. She kept saying Jake was horrible and cruel. But when I asked what happened, she got all shifty. He said he broke up with her out of nowhere and kicked her out of his apartment. But then she mentioned she still had keys to his place because she forgot to give them back the next day. She left early in the morning and came back with this huge golden retriever. I recognized him immediately. It was Buster, Jake's dog. Jake love that dog more than anything. When his grandpa died last year, Buster was the only thing that helped him through it. I asked Chloe why she had Buster and she got this weird smile on her face. She said Jake didn't deserve to keep him since he broke her heart. Then she said something that made my stomach drop. She told me she was going to take Buster to the vet tomorrow to put him down as payback for what Jake did to her. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. This dog was completely healthy and happy, just confused about being in a new place. Buster kept looking around for Jake and whining by the door. It was heartbreaking. I told Chloe she was being insane and she couldn't just kill someone's dog because she was upset. She laughed and said Jake should have thought about that before he decided to hurt her. Then she said if I told anyone, she'd make sure I regretted it. That night I couldn't sleep, kept thinking about Buster and how scared he must be. Around 2:00am, I heard Chloe on the phone with someone probably making the vet appointment. I knew I had to do something. The next morning, Chloe left for work and told mom she was taking Buster for a walk later. Mom didn't know the whole story. Chloe just said Jake asked her to watch his dog for a few days. As soon as both of them were gone, I called Jake. He picked up on the first ring and sounded terrible. I told him Chloe had Buster and was planning to put him down today. He went completely silent for like 10 seconds, then started freaking out. He said he'd been looking everywhere for Buster and thought maybe he got out somehow. I told Jake to come over now while Chloe was at work. He was at our house in 15 minutes. When he saw Buster, he literally started crying. Buster went crazy with excitement, jumping all over him and licking his face. I opened the door and Jake carried his dog out to his car. Before he left, Jake told me what really happened with Chloe. She Didn't just get dumped. She cheated on him with his best friend, Marcus. When Jake found out, he broke up with her and told her to move out. She stole Buster on her way out and left Jake's spare key on the counter so he thought she was being mature about the breakup. A few hours later, Chloe came home and went straight to look for Buster when she couldn't find him. She started screaming my name. She found me in my room and absolutely lost it. She called me a traitor and said I had no right to interfere in her business. Then mom came home and asked what all the yelling was about. Chloe told her I let some guy steal her dog. She made it sound like I just gave away her pet to a random stranger. Mom looked.

Hey, sis, can you come over tomorrow? Mom has some news about her health. His voice had that practiced concern, the same tone he'd used for every fake emergency. Sure, I said sweetly. I'll bring the whole family something special. I spent that night making copies of everything. Bank statements, medical records I'd helped to pay for. Receipts from Landon's failed ventures.
