You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like, no big fall out, no drama. Just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened. Like, what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part. I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this. Or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't. Cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. Yeah. I could reach out. I could say something. Deep down, I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it. Pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them, I really wanted to stay.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Don't change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parent decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to Enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. Their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years of Zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living.

People who work in HR, what's the wildest thing you've discovered that LED to a firing? Two women in our accounting department got pregnant at almost the exact same time. Jessica found out first and was super excited, showing everyone her ultrasound photos and talking about baby names during lunch breaks. Three weeks later, Amber announced she was also pregnant, due just two weeks after Jessica. Everyone was thrilled. The whole office was buzzing about having two babies so close together. Both women submitted their maternity leave paperwork right away, since we needed time to arrange coverage for their positions. Jessica went on leave first. When her daughter was born, everything seemed normal. Then Amber went into labour early, about a week before her scheduled leave was supposed to start. That's when things got weird. Our payroll system flagged an error. When I tried to process Amber's leave, it said someone had already filed maternity leave under her name and Social Security number. I figured it was just a computer glitch, so I called our IT department. They pulled up the records and found something impossible. According to our system, Amber had already been on maternity leave for three weeks. But she'd been working the whole time. She was literally at her desk yesterday. I started digging deeper and found the original leave request filed under Amber's name. It had her Social Security number, her employee ID, everything. But the submission date was from a month ago, right when Jessica Had filed hers. Something was seriously wrong here. I pulled the security footage from the day the duplicate paperwork was submitted. At 6:47 p m, after most people had left, Jessica was sitting at Amber's desk, using her computer. She spent 43 minutes there printing documents and filling out forms. But it got worse. Way worse.

Hating on a queer ship is not homophobic. I know it's hard to hear, but it's true. I fear just because the ship that you love just happens to be gay or lesbian doesn't always mean all hate that is directed at it is only because of it being gay. I genuinely don't know what it is with some people in the LGBTQ community using discrimination as Agacha when someone hates on a queer ship. And it's even worse when the ship is toxic. Like there is a good reason to hate it. Maybe if we stop calling the most stupidest shit homophobic, you would actually take the real discrimination against us seriously. Cause no one is gonna take you seriously when you cry and whine over someone's opinion and assume that it's discrimination when it's.

My boyfriend saw my Venmo and asked, why are you getting paid $500 weekly by someone called Sugar Daddy? I nearly choked on my cereal because that was not a conversation I wanted to have at 8:00am on a Tuesday. It's not what it looks like, I said quickly. But Jake was already scrolling through my transaction history with his eyebrows raised. Really? Because it looks like you're getting paid every Friday for the past three months by someone whose contact name is literally Sugar daddy Mike with money bag emojis. He turned his phone toward me showing the evidence. Are you seriously doing that kind of work? Without telling me, I grabbed my phone back, my face burning red. Jake, I swear to God it's not what you think. Mike is my boss at the pet sitting company. He stared at me like I'd grown a third leg. Your boss pays you through Venmo and you call him Sugar Daddy Mike? I realized how absolutely insane this sounded, but it was the truth. The company payroll system has been broken for months. Mike pays all the employees through Venmo. And I saved his contact as Sugar Daddy Mike as a joke because he's always buying us coffee and treats for the dogs. Jake was not buying this explanation at all. That's the most ridiculous cover story I've ever heard. Look, I'll prove it. I called Mike right there in our kitchen. He answered on the second ring with his Usual cheerful voice. Hey, and you're not scheduled until this afternoon. Everything okay? I put him on speaker. Mike, my boyfriend thinks we're having some kind of inappropriate relationship because of how you pay us and how your name shows up in my phone. Mike burst out laughing. Oh, no, not again. This happened with my daughter's boyfriend last month. He thought she was cheating on him with her sugar daddy Mike. He explained to Jake that his payroll company had been hacked six months ago, so he'd been paying everyone through cash apps. Jake still looked skeptical. But why Sugar Daddy Mike? Mike laughed even harder. Because I spoil my employees and the pets rotten. Free coffee every day, premium dog treats, bonuses for good work. The girls started calling me Sugar Daddy Mike because I'm always buying supplies and treating them like family. He invited Jake to come by the office to meet the team. You can meet the other four dog walkers who probably also have me saved as Sugar Daddy Mike in their phones. I could see Jake starting to believe the story, but he was still embarrassed about jumping to conclusion. This is why you should have just told me you had a job, he muttered. After we hung up with Mike, Jake apologized profusely. I should have just asked you directly instead of making assumptions. But then he got curious about other things. Wait, if you're only making $250 twice a month, how are You paying for all those expensive dinners you've getting delivered? My stomach dropped because I've been hoping he wouldn't notice my Doordash habit. That's a different situation, I said, trying to change the subject. But Jake was already connecting dots. Please tell me you're not actually doing sugar daddy stuff on the side to pay for food. I just waved it off and tried to ignore him for the rest of the day. The next day, I brought Jake to the pet sitting office to meet Mike and prove my story. He was exactly what you'd expect, 50 something guy in dog hair covered clothes who immediately offered us both coffee and dog treats to sample. See, he said to Jake, total sugar daddy behaviour but completely innocent. The other employees confirmed that they all had similar contact names for Mike and that he was basically the most generous boss ever. Last month he paid for my dog's vet Bill when I couldn't afford it, one co worker said. Jake felt terrible for assuming the worst and bought lunch for the whole pet sitting crew as an apology. I watched too much true crime, he explained to Mike. When I I saw those payments, my mind immediately went to the darkest possibility. Mike laughed it off and said it happened more often than you'd think. My wife gets suspicious, looks at the bank when she deposits checks made out to Sugar Daddy, Mike's Pet Care. That night, Jake finally relaxed. Convinced everything was fine. But when I checked my phone before bed, another 500 dollar transfer came in. The message read, good job. He bought every word.

Bro, can someone explain to me why the internet is obsessed with the dumbest meme ever? 6, 7. That's it? Two random numbers and suddenly everyone's acting like it's peak comedy. Like this weekend the calendar hits six for Saturday, seven for Sunday and people are losing their minds. Wow, crazy. Never seen numbers before. Someone asks me how old I am, I say 67 and apparently that's the funniest joke of the year. No, it's not clever, it's not deep. It's just two numbers slapped together like a bad group project. And yet somehow my whole feed is flooded with it. TikTok comments. Just a wall of people spamming 67 like they unlocked a cheat code. Bro, you don't look cool, you look cooked. Teachers ask what page we're on and kids scream 6 7 like it's a cult meme. How is this funny? It's literally the definition of cringe. And the worst part, the more I complain, the more people spam it. Like I'll rant for 2 minutes straight and the comments are still just 67 67, 67. At this point if feels less like a meme and more like brain rot. It's everywhere and now I can't even escape it. I'll wake up, check my phone, and first thing I see another 67 meme. My brain is broken. So fine. If you're part of this chaos, prove it. Type 67 in the comments right now. I wanna see the entire comment section cooked beyond repair.
NA

I can't watch anything that doesn't have a lesbian couple. Like it gets so boring. It doesn't even have to be a full on lesbian relationship. I'll happily ship two girlfriends together. I'm so starved for lesbian representation at this point. It's not that I hate straight ships. I just can't care about them. Like why would a man be there? Especially when it's written from the perspective of the girl? Same with gay ships. Yay, queer representation. Love the gays, but Loki, I just can't get invested. There's some exceptions though, like Pure Vanilla x White Lily from Cookie Run and a couple others, but that's it. I wish WLW ships were more normalized. 99% of the time when there's a girl who could end up with either a guy or another girl, the writers always go with the guy, even when the gay dynamic is clearly better. On the same note, I don't care if the girls I'm shipping have only interacted like four times. I love rare pairs most of the time. I also don't even care if the dynamic between the girls is more toxic. I get more joy from shipping girls together. I love you.

I don't care that Charlie Kirk died. And before some of you guys attack me, I do feel sorry for his family. I do hope that they can find peace as I'm sure he was a great husband, dad, son and whatever else. But then again, I've seen people say that people who are happy are disgusting. I just don't agree with that. Nobody is going to have empathy for a guy who said he'd force his daughter to give birth to her rapist baby. And how I see it, people are happy because Kirk was somewhat an oppressor who was also friends with an oppressor. And wasn't this the same guy who said that gun deaths were worth it to keep the 2nd amendment? Should he have been killed? No. Do I feel sad? No. Do I feel empathy for him? No. But until then, Jim Jam is out. Hashtag stay gooning.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like, at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly, someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket. Just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet, using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight, but by 12:30, half of them are knocked out drooling, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation? Wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone sneaking chips at 4:00am, and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. Morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock, and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part? Parents roll in like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

Do you guys ever laugh so hard to the point where you actually run out of breath and things get serious? Like, I swear there must be at least one person who passed away from literally laughing too hard. And I'm talking about the laughter that has you wheezing and makes you skip the gym because it gives you a whole core workout. So I was in freshman year, right? Everything was going decent. I was meeting new kids and stuff at lunch. I sat at a table with a group of my friends from middle school and I promise that was one of the funniest lunches I've ever had. I don't know why, but each single joke would have the table bursting out laughing. At the table, two of my friends were arguing and one of them said, shut up, bro. That's why when you smile, you have a 99% match to an orangutan. My other friend next to me choked on his rice and just spat it all over the table. Principal who was monitoring the cafeteria got mad and yelled at him to clean it up. The whole lunch table lost it. I mean, slapping the table and snorting. I was laughing so hard that there was a point where I actually couldn't breathe. My heart actually dropped. I legit panicked and it felt like an eternity. The table noticed and one of them said, breathe, brother, breathe. And I swear on dead dogs, he almost caused My unofficial passing, although I almost died. Damn, that wouldn't be a bad way to go out.

So it's been about a day since Charlie Kirk died, and I don't really give a fuck now. Of course, my heart goes out to his family, but he was genuinely such a weirdo. And some of the things he said were crazy. What do you mean? You'd force your daughter to give birth if she was raped. And some of his other takes were just shit, too. Like he supported pedophilia, was very racist and islamophobic, anti immigrants and abortion, and said black people are criminals, just to name a few things. Mind you, he was pro gun violence, so he kind of had this coming.
NA

so today was my first day at an American high school and oh my god, I have a lot to say so buckle up. First of all, to the motherfucker that decided school should start at 7:45 in the morning, fuck you. Say your prayers and count your days because I am personally going to file a lawsuit against you. Like I already adjusted to the time zones. I legit thought I was safe. Nope, I'm suddenly expected to brush my teeth before the sun even knows what's going on. Okay, moving on, let's talk about the cult you guys have labeled school fashion. Why was everyone wearing red and black pajama pants? Was this planned? It was like walking into a Christmas themed asylum. I'm not even gonna hate because I am absolutely dragging my host mom to target to get some so I can blend in with the cult members. Anyway, first thing they gave me was my schedule and then first thing I did was hide in the bathroom because what the fuck do you mean I'm supposed to actually talk to people? Absolutely not. Homeroom teacher was chill though. Shout out to Mr Lincoln for not forcing me to stand up and introduce myself. Fucking legend. Thankfully my host sister was in most of my classes so I just stayed with her and her friends. Now my classes were really easy like I suspected. So to the people who told me school was gonna be Hard yikes that is until I had biology 5th period bro. I did not realize how many science words exist that I don't know in English. They gave me a language helper like a translator. I felt like a fucking idiot. They also messed up my classes again and put me in French class. What am I supposed to do in there? They said it's gonna take a few weeks before I get my classes switched but you know what? I actually kind of get it now. I get why you guys hate French, but I don't even think it's the language's fault. I think your teachers just hate their jobs about lunch. Oh my God, lunch was disgusting. Starting to feel like the chicken was not chicken. How are you people not dying from this? Do you just build immunity over the years like a vaccine but edible also. Why is it so short? 45 minutes? That is not enough. I'm gonna stop here before this turns into a fucking documentary tomorrow I'll give you the tea on the people instead of the school itself. Anyways, I'm done yapping so bye.

Have you ever noticed that the school bathroom during class just stops being a bathroom? You walk in expecting silence, maybe a cough, maybe the faint smell of lemon cleaner. Instead, it's a fully operational underground economy. First of all, there's a kid leaning against the wall like a mob boss selling individual skittles for 50. Sensei. He's got a little ziploc bag of them and this tiny notebook where he writes down who owes him money. Like, bro, what happens if I don't pay you? Are you gonna send the urinal guys after me? Second stall. The door is locked, feet dangling. Kids not using the bathroom? Nope. They're sitting on the toilet lid like it's a lounge chair, playing Clash Royale on full volume. And when you glance under the stall, they shush you like you're interrupting a performance. By the sinks, there's three kids treating it like a mirror photo shoot. They've got sunglasses, LED lights. One kid's holding a ring light. Where did they get a ring light? We've been in school for two hours. I don't even think the janitor has a ring light. Then you got the acrobats. Some seventh grader decides the handicap stall is now a gymnast. Sticks are real, and they're doing pull UPS on the stall door frame while their friend times them with a stopwatch. Meanwhile, the door is creaking like it's seconds away from ending someone's bathroom. And through all this, the only person actually using the bathroom, Is the mystery kid. They're always in the last stall, always completely silent. And somehow they've been in there since second period. So now I'm just standing there holding my hall pass, trying to wash my hands without getting roped into buying a two dollar Starbucks or accidentally joining a TikTok. And when I leave, the teachers, like, you were gone for 10 minutes. What were you doing? Ma'am, I just survived an entire bathroom surface. I think I deserve extra credit.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque. Not here on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare, bro. Rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught smallpox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got a I rockets to Mars and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First, it was Covid tearing everything apart. Then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.
NA

TW my opinion I genuinely hate when my friends have the same interests as me don't get me wrong the ones that just like it too are okay. I'm talking about the ones who think they're a bigger fan than me like you just started liking it because I told you about it and and then they proceed to make it their whole personality and yeah they're my friend but it annoys me so much I just don't really care if we are friends in that moment if you're like that please think about your personality and change it anyways. Bye Ari out.

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20 and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude, maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, figured why not? My little sister Mia is 15 and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for like an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game and I was thinking this was actually pretty fun. And Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs and I found my Sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what?

Got herself pregnant is the dumbest phrase in the world. Like, for real. If it was possible to get pregnant by ourselves, we'd have eaten all the men long ago. It actually is possible to get pregnant without the sperm of a man whatsoever, using bone marrow from another woman. A child conceived this way can only be female. So actually, men are entirely useless. Fun fact. Let's begin the feast.
NA

Secret signs A boy likes you but is just shy. The last one will shock you. His body language gives him away. He sneaks, glances at you, but quickly looks away when you notice. His feet or body are often pointed toward you. He plays with his hands, adjust clothes, taps foot when you're around. TikTok knows someone who has feelings for you, but it's too afraid to tell you it's the second person. When you click share and more. He gets nervous around you. His voice cracks or he stumbles over words. When talking to you, he finds small excuses to be near you. He shows up where you are more often than coincidence allows. He remembers the little things. Comment I hate when and let your keyboard finish the sentence. Even if he doesn't talk much, he notices details about you, like your favourite snack, something you said weeks ago. He pays attention in ways others might overlook. He interacts differently with you than with others. He may be loud and confident with friends, but quiet around you. He engages online more than in person. He texts, comments, or likes your posts, but is quieter face to face. He's more relaxed when there's no direct eye contact. Before the last fact. Please like the video and follow or you might never see me again. His friends know something. They tease him when you're around. They may drop hints or act differently towards you because they know how he Feels

I don't think people realize how sweet it is when someone laughs at your unfunny jokes. Like they know it wasn't really funny and you know it too, but they still let out this little laugh just so you don't feel awkward. It's not even about the joke. It's about the kindness behind it. That tiny moment where they choose to make you feel good instead of letting you shrink into silence. It honestly means more than people think. Well, anyways, thanks out Mwah.

A man at the art gallery told me I couldn't possibly understand the painting in front of us. I painted it. I was standing in front of my largest piece at the gallery opening, champagne in hand, when a man in an expensive suit approached and started explaining my own painting to me. He had no idea I was the artist because the placard said Riley Turner, who he clearly assumed was a man since he kept talking about his brilliant technique. This guy, Robert, looked me up and down and said, you seem young to be at an opening like this. Let me guess. Looking for a rich boyfriend, smart girl, lots of wealthy men here. He gestured at my painting like he owned it. See, what Riley is doing here requires years of training to appreciate. You probably just think the colors are pretty. The average woman just sees decoration. I took a sip of champagne and said, interesting perspective, which I guess he took as encouragement. Robert moved closer to the painting, physically stepping in front of me and continued his lecture. A girl like you probably thinks this is just nice to look at, but there's actual intelligence behind it. The artist is obviously a man because women simply don't have this kind of technical mastery. Female painters do flowers and feelings. This has real intellectual depth. It's biological, really. Men are just more capable of this level of abstraction. When I mentioned I was familiar, With the artist's work, Robert laughed and patted my shoulder. Following him on Instagram to look at the pretty pictures doesn't count as being familiar with art, sweetheart. You probably think you're cultured because you went to that Van Gogh light show. Real knowledge comes from decades of study, not whatever you Learned from talk. Robert decided to test me, rapid firing questions. Who's baskiat? What's kiarascuro? Name three Renaissance painters besides da Vinci. When I started to answer, he cut me off. Wrong. See, this is why galleries shouldn't have open events. You probably googled some terms before coming here to impress men. But Riley here is working in a tradition you couldn't possibly understand without a proper education. Not community college, sweetie, real universities. He returned to my painting now explaining it louder to draw a crowd. How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. He showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated, remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, would grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept filling glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, that she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting Back or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.

My wife asked why I wasn't fighting for our marriage anymore. Should I tell her? After three months of her girls nights turning into therapy sessions about how marriage was just a trap, I was done fighting. She'd come home at two a m, reeking of wine, telling me about her divorced friends, authentic lives, how they were finally free and living their truth. Last week, she said maybe I should have listened when they warned me about settling down. So I stopped trying. Yesterday, she noticed. You're not fighting for us anymore. If you really loved me, you'd wanna fix this. I looked at her calmly. You want me to fight for our marriage? Yes. Obviously. Okay. I pulled out my phone and called her best friend, Janet. The twice divorced one who'd been coaching her. Hey, Janet, it's James. Quick question. Do you think my wife should stay married to someone she regrets being with? My wife's face went white. That's what I thought. Thanks for the honest advice. I hung up and looked at my wife. Janet says you should definitely leave me. Congratulations. Your advisor just made the decision for you. She started crying. That's not what I wanted. Funny, because three months ago you said Janet's advice was the best thing that ever happened to you. But I wasn't done. I called Crystal. Next one who spends weekends bar hopping, crying about how all men are trash. Crystal. Hey. My wife's been telling me about Your amazing single life. Should she join you? Live that authentic truth with you guys? Talk about through the phone? Crystal's voice got quiet. Well, I mean, maybe you two should work it out. Work it out? But you told her marriage was a prison last Tuesday. At least that's what she came home saying. I put the phone on speaker so my wife could hear Crystal backpedal. I was just venting about my own situation. I didn't mean. Oh, so when you said, dump his ass and live for yourself, you were just venting? Silence. Then I called Debbie, the twice divorced one living with her parents at 35. Debbie, great news. My wife's finally ready to take your advice about leaving me. When can she move in with you and your mom? Move in? I. There's not really room here. But you said independence was worth any sacrifice. My wife was pale, watching her support system crumble in real time. After I hung up, she whispered, they were just trying to help. Debbie's eating cereal for dinner because she can't afford groceries. Crystal hasn't had a second date in two years. Janet's on antidepressants because she's so lonely. You don't understand their situations. I understand perfectly. Three miserable women convinced you to throw away a good marriage so you could be miserable with them. She sat down hard, but they said I deserved better. Better than what? A faithful husband who works two job so you can Go to yoga class. Better than someone who's never lied to you or cheated. The silent stretch. They said marriage kills your soul. Whose soul got killed? Mine. Listening to you repeat your poison every night. Or yours. Because you let strangers reprogram you. She started crying again. I don't know what I want anymore. I do. You want their approval more than my love. You got it. The irony. Her friends are now panicking, realizing they pushed too hard. Janet called later, begging me not to divorce her because she didn't really mean it. Crystal

My stepchildren said they answer only to their biological parents. So I changed the locks, canceled every privilege in my name and told their father pick up was tonight. No one argued. I'm Tom, 35, and I've been married to Lisa for 18 months. She has two kids from her first marriage, Marcus, 17, and Sophia, 15. Their biological father lives about 40 minutes away and sees them maybe twice a month when he feels like showing up. When Lisa and I got together, I genuinely wanted to be the stepdad I never had growing up. My own father walked out when I was 12, so I knew what it felt like to need a father figure. I thought being a good stepdad meant being the yes man, always supportive, always generous, always understanding. New school clothes? Sure, no problem. Concert tickets for Sophia's favorite band, of course. When Marcus wanted the latest gaming setup, I dropped $800 without blinking when he crashed my car last month after staying hang out past curfew. I didn't even make him pay the 500 dollar deductible. But respect, that was a completely different story. It started with small things. You're not our real dad became their go to response whenever I asked them to do basic household tasks. When I'd ask Marcus to take out the trash, he'd say, I only listen to actual parents. When Sophia left dishes piled in the sink for days, she'd shrug and say, my mom didn't tell Me to clean them. Lisa would have talks with them about respect and they'd apologize and behave for maybe a week. Then we'd be right back to the same pattern. The breaking point came last Friday. I decided to leave work early to surprise Lisa with dinner plans for our anniversary weekend. I pulled into the driveway around 3 in the afternoon and immediately knew something was wrong. There were cars I didn't recognize park on our street and I could hear music blasting from inside the house. I walked through my front door to find about 20 teenagers having a full blown party in my living room. Red solo cups everywhere. The coffee table pushed against the wall. Kids I'd never seen before eating food from my kitchen. My house was completely trashed. Broken lamp, mysterious stains on my white couch, empty bottles scattered everywhere. Marcus was in the center of it all, acting like the king of the castle when he saw me. He didn't even look embarrassed, just annoyed that I'd shown up. Party's over, I said loudly. Everyone out now. The music stopped. Kids started grabbing their stuff and heading for the door, but Marcus didn't move. Clean this mess up immediately, I told him once the house was empty. He actually laughed. You can't tell me what to do. You're not my father. This is my house, Marcus. My couch that's ruined. My lamp that's broke. Can no. Sophia interrupted, appearing from the kitchen. It's Mom's house, too. We live here. We only take orders from real family, not from some guy mom married. That's when I noticed something that made my blood run cold. The door to my home office was wide open, and I always kept it locked. I walked over and immediately saw that my safe was open. My emergency cash envelope, the one where I've been saving money for Lisa's surprise birthday trip to Hawaii, was completely empty. $2,000 gone. I turned around slowly. Where's my money? Marcus shrugged with this smug expression. What money? I don't know what you're talking about. $2,000 from my safe. The safe that was locked this morning. Prove we took it, Sophia said with a smile. That made me realize this wasn't just disrespect anymore.

Bro, fuck you mean Charlie Kirk just passed? Like what the hell is even going on this week? A body found in David's car. Some girl got slime just because she's sitting down in a bus and this bullshit, I beg of you, don't even look it up. I'm begging you right now because that had me traumatized. I'm grown and people call me UNC and I still can't do blood. The second it started he pouring out like juice. I wanted to tap out bro. That's exactly why I could never be a surgeon or anything medical long term. I don't care what my parents say. Basically he was giving a speech at a university and some old bald sniper just came out of nowhere and actually took him out from like 30 feet away and it's wild because you can disagree with a man, I know I didn't with some things he said and think he said some foul or even racist stuff but at the end of the day he had a wife and two little daughters. You can't wish death on nobody. This division between Republicans and Democrats is gonna spread wide faster than the rift in Superman literally. Watch the presidential debate from 2008 between Obama and some other guy I can't remember. Jokes aside, shit was respectful. Now we got they're eating the dogs and Sleepy Joe memes from the two presidential debates from last year. That sniper got the worst karma coming his Way cause assassinations like this never make sense. You really gonna pull up with a rifle, plan it out and take someone's life when you the dude who's already old shooter should have spent his time in a retirement home or some shit or a warden. Yeah, that unless we're talking about monsters like Epstein, controversial people ain't worth that. I pray that Kirk's family gets through this. May god help America.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque. Not here on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare, bro. Rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught smallpox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got a I rockets to Mars and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First, it was Covid tearing everything apart. Then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Don't change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Sky, Taylor kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her moods. Things. Year 1 was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball in our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids'grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I've forgotten how To enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor, I only helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught sky to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after Three years of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living.

So Charlie Crick just died. Look, I never looked up to the guy or idolized him, but people celebrating his death isn't cool at all for any reason. And whatever he did is in the past. Yeah, he could have been a rapist or whatever, but being happy because someone died isn't cool at all. I know for sure there will be a couple of haters, but it's alright. I don't care. But like, just imagine one day Charlie's kids go on social media to see what happened to his dad and they start seeing all the videos and comments people are saying about him. He might have not been the best person in the world, but at least he had passion for his speeches and look like a great father. He might have done fucked up shit, but that's normal. I fucked up too. And I'm still here because y'all wanted me to be here. And if you don't got anything nice to say, just don't say it. Imagine Charlie was your dad and you start seeing people being happy about his death anyways, may Charlie quick rest in peace.

If there's an earthquake, just get on a plane. Like, bro, the ground is the one having a seizure, not the sky. Why are you crying in your collapsing house when Spirit Airlines is right there? Things that boys do when they like you. First thing, he'll try to make you laugh, even if it means making a fool of himself. Your smile is worth it. TikTok can reveal who secretly likes you. It's the second person that shows up when you click share. Then more. Boys will often find excuses to be around you, like asking for your help or accidentally bumping into you. 20 million people have the same birthday as you. Write yours in the comments to see who shares it. If he's always the first to view your stories or react to your posts, it's because he's keeping an eye on what you're up to. Most people's phone doesn't have this secret emoji, just comment star in square brackets to unlock it. Boys might act more confident or try to impress you when they're around you. It's their way of catching your attention. If you wanna know more, signs like this, follow now because you won't wanna miss what's next. When a guy likes you, he'll find ways to touch you, even if it's just a friendly pat on the back or a high five. If he remembers tiny details you've mentioned, like your favourite song or a story from months ago, he's definitely interested. Hit like if you've seen these signs before and drop a comment if you think someone's been showing them to you. And here's the last one. Boys might tease or playfully annoy you, but it's just their way. Of getting closer and seeing your reaction.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me we just fired a missile at a UFO and it deflected it? Look at this. That was a 200 pound missile and it shrugged it off like it was nothing. That's not defense, that's disrespect. And we're sitting here like, maybe it's peaceful. Well, it's a bit late for peace when we're the ones firing missiles at it immediately. You don't get to throw hands and then act surprised when it looks back. It was just floating there, minding its business. We threw the first punch, it didn't even blink. And now we're all just standing around like that's normal. If it ever turns around and starts charging up, we're cooked. 2,025 cannot get any crazier. But hey, at least it's ending with a bang. My dad treated us like crap until his boss had dinner at our house. For 17 years, I lived with two different fathers. The perfect employee who preached about his perfect marriage and strong kids, and the man who made mom sob herself to sleep for buying the wrong coffee brand. Mom Learned to time grocery shopping before his Thursday bowling league when he'd be rushed. Once she forgot, dad discovered generic pasta instead of name brand. You're too stupid to even shop, right? No wonder you never amounted to anything. He made her return every item while he watched, then quizzed her on prices to prove she was wasting his money. She cried in the car afterward. That weekend's company barbecue. I do the shopping because the wife gets overwhelmed by choices. His co workers laughed at how understanding he was. My brother walked past Dad's home office during a virtual meet. Invisible for just two seconds, dad kept smiling, discussing collaborative workspace culture. The second he clicked leave meeting, he cornered my brother. You made me look like I can't control my own house. The belt came out. Two weeks of complete silence followed. My brother stopped eating, stopped talking at school. Teachers thought he was just shy. I saved money from my part time job for college application fees, knowing he'd never support it. He found them anyway. You think you're better than me? He burned them in the kitchen sink while I watched. Later, his boss Asked about my plans. She's applying everywhere. We stay up late working on essays together. I nodded and smiled, knowing I'd missed every deadline. Two fathers. Only we knew which one was real. Then my dad announced, the CEO is coming to dinner on Saturday. After ten years grinding for senior VP, a 1 hundred thousand dollar promotion, it came down to this. The CEO was famous for his values based leadership. He'd fired executives for screaming at waitstaff. I passed over vps for bad parenting in public. Now he wanted to see Dad's home life personally. With a three hour dinner. One mistake, dad hissed, and I'll make you regret it forever. But dad had never maintained his perfect act at home for more than 20 minutes. Phone calls, easy, quick. Doorway chats, no problem. But three hours in his kingdom, where he trained us to fear him. That's never happened before. Watched Mom's hands shake, my brother shrink into his chair. For 17 years, home was where dad dropped his mask. Saturday, he'd have to keep it on for three whole hours. There was no way, right? We all prepared like our lives depended on it. Practiced conversations, rehearsed dinner etiquette. Cleaned until the house looked like a magazine spread. I helped mom cover the bags under her eyes. My brother practiced speaking in full sentences. Again. Dad was a wreck. Pretending to be calm. He'd bark orders, catch himself, force a smile. Remember, we're a happy family. He'd say through gritted teeth, the vein in his forehead pulsing. Saturday arrived and the doorbell rang. Showtime, Dad whispered, transforming into the man his co workers knew. A warm smile with a firm handshake. Welcome to our home. The first hour was perfect. Dad told charming stories. We laughed at the right moments. Mom served flawlessly. But I watched dad carefully. Saw his jaw clench when my brother took too long answering a question. I noticed his knuckles whitening when mom laughed too loudly at the CEO's joke. I watched that familiar vein start to pulse. By hour, two cracks appeared. His smile became strained, his laugh forced. He was gripping his wine glass so tight, I thought it might shatter. This was the longest he'd ever had to pretend in his own home. And it was killing him. I didn't have to do anything. I just had to wait. Then it happened. During dessert, mom served the sea

Why don't homeless people just try and rob a bank? Like hear me out. If they're successful, they're instantly rich. No more sleeping under bridges. They're straight up balling. But if they fail, what happens? Jail, which is basically free food, free bed, free shelter, free Wi-Fi if you're lucky. That's literally a win win situation, bro. Worst case scenario, you end up with three meals a day and a roommate named Big Mike. Best case scenario, you're the next Elon Musk, but without the lawsuit. Honestly, I don't get why no one's speed running this strategy. It sounds more efficient than half the self improvement TikToks I see.

We talk about people who self diagnose themselves like, no, Emily, you do not have 4 different mental disorders just because you saw a TikTok that said if you breathe sometimes and also blink, you might have ADHD. Congratulations. That's called being a human. Look, I get it. Mental health awareness is hella important. It's amazing that people are talking about it more openly now. But here's the problem. Scrolling through hashtags at 2:00am is not the same thing as a professional evaluation. Google is not your therapist. ID Labs, tests are not your psychiatrist. And that one influencer who talks about their symptoms in a story time, definitely not a doctor. When everyone just casually slaps a label on themselves, it waters down the real struggles people actually face. Like someone living with legit OCD is out here battling life every day. And then some dude is like, oh my God, I'm so OCD. I color code my closet. No, you're not OCD. You're just organized, my guy. And even with depression, just because you're feeling a little sad one week does not mean you have depression unless you're diagnosed. I don't wanna hear it. You're free to self pity in private. But self diagnosing is probably one of the most selfish and attention seeking things you can do. Faith out.

Every school has that annoying ass girl group who thinks they're the shit and every boy likes them. Like bro, they're always looking for attention. Like, Omg, everyone is staring at us. Yeah, we're staring because you sound like three fucking malfunction car alarms fighting each other. And then one of them says the most fucking driest, corniest and funniest ass joke I've ever heard in my time of living and they all start laughing like a dying pack of hyenas choking on sand. What the fuck? And then my fuck ass friends have the audacity to say, you like her, don't you? Like what? No, they're all fucking chopped and built like oversized vending machine friends every week like it's a fucking Netflix series. New season, new guy. Make fun of other people's looks. But then they take pictures and scribble out the spots on their face like, bro, you're just a fucking hypocrite. The worst part is when the girl everyone thinks I like starts playing along with it. So that just makes it even more fucking believable that I like her. I always explain to everyone that no, I don't fucking like her. She sounds like a dying vacuum cleaner choking on Legos that went up its ass. But no, still continue. At this point I might as well just confess to my real crush so people stop shipping me with that ugly hippo. Anyway, have a great fuck ass day.

Bro, what the flip is this? A man with alzheimer's forgets he had alzheimer's, remembers everything. Like how? Who are you? What are you? When did this happen? Bro literally beat the system. You're telling me this man forgot so hard that he forgot to forget? That's some next level anime plotline. This is literally math in real life. Negative plus negative equals positive. Bro used stones to destroy stones. Bro used some cursed reverse psychology and clutched up. This guy is him. This guy is overpowered. This guy teaches his teachers the air breathes. This guy. The earth walks. This guy. But wait, if he recovered his memory, wouldn't he remember he had alzheimer's? Like, wouldn't that just cancel out again? Bro is in an infinite memory glitch. But honestly, this is a W. He literally beat one of the worst illnesses ever. Spam w in the comments.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like, at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly, someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket. Just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet, using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight, but by 12:30, half of them are knocked out drooling, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation? Wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone's sneaking chips at 4:00am, and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock, and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part? Parents roll in like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque, not here, on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare? Bro, rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught small pox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever, and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like, think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got A I. Rockets to Mars, and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First it was COVID tearing everything apart, then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. He showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated, remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, would grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept filling glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, that she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting Back or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.
NA

He's been on tour for like, what, a month now? He hasn't been in LA for like a month. And the body hadn't decomposed enough for it to be in that car for so long. The body was in there for three days. The police haven't even made him a suspect. And plus he had a concert like yesterday, I'm pretty sure. But yeah, moving on to the girl that was stabbed. She was literally minding her business before she got stabbed. And as soon as she got stabbed, everyone was so Calm. Like, hello, she needs help. There was literal blood dripping on the floor. I don't have much information on the other situations, but the fact that this is all happened in a week is honestly scary. Like, this month has just started. What's going on

TikTok, what the heck is up with your filters? Because last night I was just scrolling, and a random person texted me saying, you should check out the ducky filter. And like the curious little George I am, I looked up the ducky filter, and I saw a little duck on the screen, and it said, tap the screen. And what did I do? I tap the dang screen. And when I say I scream so loud, I mean I tea. Because how is TikTok allows something like that? I threw my phone across the room so fast, not even the flash could save my phone in time. And if you think I'm being overdramatic, look it up yourself. But don't say I didn't warn you. But if you don't want to look. But you want to know what I saw. Pagorn like. Excuse me? You really think my innocent eyes were prepared to see something like that? And for the person who told me to look that up, I hope moonjoe gets you tonight. Anyways, bye.

What's your perfect example of play stupid games, win stupid prizes? My high school made all the boys holding their pee because someone wrote hi on the wall in Sharpie. Monday morning, we all showed up to find a sign taped to the boys bathroom door, closed until further notice due to vandalism. The girls bathroom was still open, of course, but our school only had one bathroom for boys in the entire building because it was an old school built in the 60s when they apparently thought teenage boys never needed to pee. Principal Carpenter made an announcement during 1st period, due to the disrespectful graffiti found in the boys restroom, this facility will remain locked until someone comes forward with information about who did it. The entire male population of our high school groaned at the same time. The crazy part was what the graffiti actually said. My friend Peyton had seen it Friday before they locked everything up. Someone had written hi in tiny letters on the bathroom stall. Not a curse word, not a drawing, just hi, I in black Sharpie about the size of a quarter. By lunch, the situation was getting desperate. Guys were asking teachers for hall passes to go to the nurse's office just to use that bathroom. But the school nurse caught on quick and started turning people away unless they were actually sick. Some guys tried using the staff bathroom but got detention for that. A few desperate souls walked To the gas station across the street during lunch. But security started watching for that, too. We tried talking to Principal Carpenter. Reasonably group of five guys went to his office to explain that punishing 300 boys for one tiny word was insane. He sat behind his big desk with his arms crossed. Actions have consequences. When the vandal comes forward, everyone gets bathroom privileges back. By Wednesday, things were getting bad. Guys were dehydrated from not drinking water all day. The basketball team couldn't practice properly because half the players were holding it in. Parents started calling to complain. The carpenter wouldn't budge. He sent out an email saying this was a lesson in collective responsibility. That's when Dean Patterson had his brilliant idea. He was this quiet kid.
