What's the worst, I hate to break it to you, moment you had with someone? My dad showed up at my apartment with flowers for me like I was his girlfriend. And my fiance had to tell him he was my father, not my husband. I always knew my dad was weird about me. When my parents divorced when I was 9, my mom moved on pretty quick, found herself a nice guy named Paul who treated me like a normal stepdaughter. But my dad, he never dated anyone, ever. He'd always say I was his whole world and he didn't need anyone else. At first, it felt special. He'd pick me up from school with my favourite candy. He'd take me shopping and let me get whatever I wanted. He called our Saturday Hangouts daddy daughter dates, which seemed normal enough when I was 10. But things got weird as I got older. When I started wearing makeup in eighth grade, he threw it all away and said I was too beautiful to need that garbage. When I got my first phone, he demanded all my passwords because he needed to protect me from predators. He'd scroll through my texts every night at dinner. High school was worse. He hated all my friends, especially the guys. If I hung out with anyone he didn't approve of, he'd give me the silent treatment for days, just sit at dinner staring at his plate, acting like I didn't exist until I Apologized. The worst was when I told him I was dating Trevor when I was 17. We were driving to target and I casually mentioned I had a boyfriend. He pulled into the parking lot and just started crying, like ugly sobbing. He said I was throwing away everything we had together for some stupid boy who didn't really know me. I felt so guilty. I broke up with Trevor the next week. College gave me some space, but he'd call me three times a day. If I didn't answer, he'd drive the two hours to campus to make sure I was okay. My roommate thought it was sweet at first until she saw him show up at 1:00am because I'd fallen asleep without texting him good night. After graduation, I moved to my own apartment and met Malik at my job. He was calm.

During chemistry class, the principal called my name over the intercom. Is Daisy Williams present in school today? My teacher, Missus Harrah, clicked the intercom button. Yes, the principal's voice echoed. Lockdown now. This is not a drill. The way he said it made my blood freeze. Missus Harrah shrieked under the desks. Lights off. Move, move, move. Nobody said anything, but everyone was thinking the same thing. There was a shooter. I couldn't help but think he was after me. A few minutes later, we heard sirens and then screaming. Missus Harrah tried to calm us down and told us it might be a misunderstanding, but her hands were shaking. She kept refreshing the email on her laptop like it was giving her live updates. The screaming got louder and it wasn't just one voice anymore. Multiple people in different parts of the building. Then we heard a loud pop from the hallway, like a metal slamming or something crashing hard. People started crying and whispering that the shooter was right outside and I believed them. Pia grabbed my hand and her palms were soaked with sweat. I could see Mister Kids class across the hall through our door window. Lights already off, no movement, just darkness where 20 kids should have been. I looked at our teacher and for the first time in my life, I saw her cry. She sat with us, hugged the younger kids and told us it would be okay. But after a while, She got up again and walked back to her laptop. Then we heard it, footsteps running past our door. Thud, thud, thud. I couldn't help myself. I had to look. Two paramedics were sprinting down the hall, pushing a wheeled stretcher, the kind you see on medical shows when someone's heart stops away from the door. Daisy, Missus Harrah whispered, voice shaking. She was scared, too. I sat down and immediately texted everyone what I had seen. Even Missus Harrah stood up slowly and crept to the door to check the window before opening it. That's when it flung open. The principal stood there with an actual cop who had his hand resting on his gun. You, Daisy, come with us. Immediately, my worst fear confirmed. The shooter had sent them or maybe they thought I was involved somehow. Missus Harra looked between them and me, confused. Get your things, honey, Missus Harra said. And that scared me more than anything because in three years of chemistry class, she'd never called me honey. Every single person was staring at me as I grabbed my backpack with shaking hands. The hallway was complete chaos. More cops than I'd ever seen in one place. I heard a paramedic shout, we're losing him. Move as he flew past us. My classmates were pressed against the door windows in every room watching me get us.

Most boyish thing he did that made your heart explode. 1, he wore mismatched socks on our first date, not because it was a quirky fashion choice, but because he genuinely didn't notice. I pointed it out and he got so flustered, mumbling something about laundry. Then he looked at me totally serious and said, are you gonna cancel the date now? Like a nervous middle schooler, I fell for him right there, socks and all. Two, we were at the arcade and he got way too invested in the claw machine, not for himself, but because he saw a stuffed turtle. He said, look like me when I'm cranky. It took him six tries, 20 bucks and some serious trash talk to the machine, but he got it when he handed it to me. He said, now you can hold me when I'm not around. That turtle's still on my bed. 3, he doesn't know how to cook at all. But one night I was sick and he showed up with instant noodles, gummy bears and a handwritten get well card drawn in blue pen. He spelled fever wrong, but he also drew me as a superhero, complete with a cape and a little speech bubble that said, I got this. I swear I got better instantly. He made me a playlist titled Songs That Remind Me of You and forgot to check the shuffle setting. First song was Shrek 2 soundtrack. I asked if it was a joke. He panicked and said, no, it's romantic. He really loved her. Five, he tied my shoelace because it came undone and said, safety first, princess, like he was a knight or something. I giggled and he turned red. 6, I caught him flexing in the mirror when he thought I wasn't looking. He whispered, she likes strong arms to himself. I had to pretend I didn't hear so he wouldn't die of embarrassment. 7, we walked past a Lego store and he stopped mid sentence, gasped and said, can we please go in just for a minute? Thirty minutes later, he was building a tiny pirate ship and explaining the lore of each mini figure. Eight, he named a raccoon that lives near his apartment. Captain bites and leaves snacks for it. Every time it shows up, he waves like it's a neighbor. First time I saw it, he said, look, he came.

Nobody came. The bell rang for 10 minutes before going silent. I broke through the dirt wall. Between us, a girl named Marisol fell into my tunnel, gasping and crying. She was only 15. Her parents buried her early because they'd caught her writing love letters. We spent 18 hours underground together. I shared my supplies, taught her the breathing exercises, kept her calm. When panic set in, we whispered about lives. We'd never get to live if we died down here. When they dug us up, they expected two broken girls. Instead, we crawled out, holding hands, filthy but furious. The crowd gasped. Two girls in one hole. Both alive, both unbroken. My mother's face went white when she saw Marisol. The elders immediately started shouting about tradition being violated, about how we cheated the ritual. My father grabbed my arm, hissing that I'd humiliated our bloodstream. But I wasn't done. In front of the entire village, I told them about the tunnel, about the girl whose bell they ignored. About the real tradition. Letting daughters die to create submissive wife. The elders called an emergency meeting. That night, my parents locked me in my room while they attended. Through my window, I could hear shouting from the community center. My mother came home sobbing, my father silent with. The next morning, they tried to bury me again. My father and three uncles dragged me from bed. My mother packed a second coffin with no water. This time, the Elders declared I needed a true burial, since I'd corrupted the first one. But Marisol had talked to her family, refused to participate. Three other families pulled their daughters from upcoming ceremonies. The photographer who'd been hired to document my burial for our family album caught everything. The forced second attempt, my screaming, my mother's dead eyes as she watched. He sent it to new stations that night. By the time they'd forced me into the second coffin, reporters were already driving to our village. They pulled me out after three hours when the first news van arrived. Tradition died in the flash of camera lights and the questions they couldn't answer about dead daughters. My family disowned me completely. They held a real funeral, buried an empty coffin with my name on it. They tell people I died in the first box. That what came out was a demon wearing my face. My mother burns sage when she sees me in the market. My father spits on the ground. But my sister Paloma won't be buried. Neither will Marisol's cousins or any other girl in our village.

Pretended to be my best friend's e girlfriend for 2 years and made his life hell. You ever get betrayed so bad it doesn't just hurt, it rewrites you. That was me. My ex best friend Eli stabbed me in the back in a way I still don't fully understand. We've been close since we were kids, shared everything, laughed until our stomachs hurt. I thought we were brothers. Then senior year came around and I found out he'd been using me. Not in the he copied my homework way. No, this was deeper. He took everything I told him in confidence about my anxiety, my insecurities, my family stuff, my parents messy divorce and used it to build clout with a group of people I thought hated me. Turned my personal life into a punchline. I confronted him and he just smirked and said, grow a thicker skin, dude. It's just jokes. That night I decided to become someone else. It started off stupid. I wanted revenge. Nothing deep, just enough to embarrass him. I made a fake profile of a girl and named her J. It started off small, like turning my pictures into a female version, setting up a fake Instagram. My plan was simple, get him to say some pathetic flirty stuff and then leak it to the school. But Eli fell fast, faster than I expected. And the more he fell, the more I leaned in. What was at first meant to be a two Week job quickly turned full time. By week three, I was using a voice changer to call him. He'd call me every night before bed. Obviously I needed some compensation, so he'd cash app me 10 bucks every call. He'd say stuff like I've never felt this comfortable with anyone. He opened up in ways I'd never seen before. The way he talked to her, the way he needed her. And I started to realize something. He never respected me, but this version of me, this soft voiced, smiling, wide eyed girl from a few towns over, he worshipped her. What started as a joke stretched into weeks, then months. I'd spend hours each day crafting conversations, sinking voice filters, sending selfies, managing multiple burner accounts. I created playlists, family stories, fake college plans. I Learned everything about his insecurities, his fear of being alone, of not being good enough, of being forgotten. And I used all of it. A year in, I realized I'd gone too far. This wasn't revenge anymore. This was something else. I wasn't just catfishing him. I was breaking him and myself slowly and quietly. But the worst part was that I didn't stop. That's when the real revenge started. Jade became distant.

What's the dumbest reason your daughter stopped talking to you? Oh, honey, let me tell you about the time my daughter didn't talk to me for two whole weeks because I betrayed her trust over a damn chicken nugget. So my daughter Lila, she's 14, has the attitude of a Beverly Hills housewife and the budget of a toddler. This girl acts like she's the CEO of the household. Tells me things like, mom, please don't embarrass me in front of my friends. Just stand still and blink like, ma'am, you live in my uterus rent free for nine months. Show some respect. Anyway, she decides she's going vegan. Great. I support her. I buy tofu, almond milk, overpriced plant nuggets that taste like regret. The whole shebang. Do I understand it? No, but I'm a supportive queen. But then one night, it's 1:00am, I'm watching reality TV in the dark, and I get hungry. I open the freezer and see those dino shaped chicken nuggets she begged for last year and never ate. So I pop, like, four in the air fryer. I'm minding my business, living my best life, and guess what? I forget to hide the evidence. Next morning, she walks into the kitchen, sniffs the air like a bloodhound, and goes, did you eat meat in this house? I said, uh, maybe. She gasps like, I just committed war crimes. You ate dead animals while I was sleeping? I said, baby girl, they were shaped like dinosaurs. They're barely meat. Calm down. She grabs her reusable water bottle, slams it on the counter, and yells, this is why the planet's dying, Because of people like you who can't control their midnight cravings! I said, okay, Greta Thunberg, relax. She storms off to her room and text me from down the hall, we're not speaking. This is a betrayal. I text back, fine, more dino nuggets for me. She leaves me on read y'all. Two weeks he wouldn't speak to me. Not even when I stubbed my toe and screamed so loud the neighbours checked on me. She just walked past me with her Hydro flask and judgmental aura. But then get this. One day I come home early from work, I walk into the kitchen, and there she is, standing in front of the microwave holding a plate with three dino nuggets. She's caught mid bite. We lock eyes. I removed my daughter's bedroom door because she won't stop slamming it. It started about six months ago. Every argument, every little thing that didn't go her way, slam. Every time I asked her to do dishes, slam. When I told her she couldn't go to some party where I knew they'd be drinking, slam! The sound would shake the whole upstairs. My coffee mug fell off my nightstand twice from the vibrations. My husband Dave, kept telling me to ignore it. He'd say, kids go through phases. She'll grow out of it. Easy for him to say, since he's usually at work when most of the slamming happens. I'm the one working from home, trying to take client calls while slam! Echoes through the house. The breaking point came on a Tuesday. Emma wanted to borrow my car to drive to her friend Jesse's house. I said no because she got a speeding ticket the week before, and we agreed her driving privileges were suspended. She started screaming about how unfair I was, how I never trust her, how all her friends think I'm psycho. Then she stomped upstairs and slam! But this time was different. This time I heard something crack. Went up to check, and there was a split running down the door frame. The wood was actually damaged. That door had been slammed so hard and so many times that it was breaking the house. I stood there staring at that crack, and something just snapped. In me, I marched to the garage, grabbed Dave's screwdriver set, and went back upstairs. Emma was inside her room blasting music, probably expecting me to yell at her through the door like usual. Instead, I started unscrewing the hinges. It took me about 10 minutes. Emma didn't even notice until I was lifting the door off the frame. Then her music stopped real quick. Mom, what are you doing? She called out. Solving a problem, said carrying her door downstairs to the garage. She appeared at the top of the stairs in her pajamas, mouth hanging open. You can't take my door. I need privacy. You lost your privileges when you damaged the house, I told her. Privacy is earned, not guaranteed. The next few days were interesting. Emma tried everything. She hung a bed sheet across the doorway, which I took down. She moved her dresser to block the opening, so I moved it back. While she was at school, she even tried staying at her friend's house. Jess's mom called me asking what was going on. By day four, Emma was sitting on her bed when I got home from the grocery store. No music, no phone. Just sitting there. This is embarrassing. She. What if someone comes over? Then maybe you'll think twice before destroying property. I said I wasn't destroying anything. I was just mad. The door frame says otherwise. That's when she actually looked at the crack she'd made. I could see her face. Change. When she realised she'd actually damaged something. Day seven was when things got real. Emma's boyfriend Tyler came over to work on some school project. I watched from the kitchen as he walked upstairs, expecting to go into her room and

Why the fuck do moms always think you and your sibling are about to throw hands when y'all are literally just having a normal ass conversation? Like me and my brother will be chilling having a full on ESPN level debate about who's better, Ronaldo or Messi. No yelling, no name calling, just some good passionate sports talk. And here comes mom busting into the room like she's diffusing a bomb. I am so tired of you two always fighting. Ma'am, we are literally just talking. Ain't nobody throwing punches, ain't nobody crying. You act like I just suplexed him through the coffee table. And you can't even defend yourself either. Cause the second you go, we weren't fighting. She hits you with the, oh, really? Then why are you raising your voice? Because I'm explaining why Ronaldo has more clutch gene. This is what we do, mother. We argue about ball like our life depends on it. That's not conflict. That's bonding. And the craziest part, if we actually were fighting like full WWE, someone getting drop, kicked off the bed type fighting, she wouldn't even be home. But the moment we're actually getting along, stop yelling. I'm sick of it.

Fathers, what did your daughter's boyfriend do that forever changed how you saw him as a cop? I hated the idea of my 17 year old daughter dating anyone. But when she brought home this boy named Pete, I lost it. He had a motorcycle, tattoos and that smug smile that made me want to run his name through the system. I made it my mission to break them up. I'd randomly show up at places they hung out, flash my badge around and remind Pete that I knew how to make bodies disappear. But this kid never flinched. He just smile and say, have a good day, sir. When he came for dinner the first time, I placed my gun on the table next to my plate. My wife kicked me under the table but I didn't care. Pete just looked at it and said, Nice Glock 19, sir. My uncle's got the same one at his security firm. That's when the real torture began. I started making him come over every weekend to bond. I'd have him help me with the most backbreaking chores I could think of. Reshaping the roof in July, digging out a tree stump by hand, moving every piece of furniture in the house to steam clean the carpets. This kid never complained. He'd show up at 7:00am sharp already wearing work clothes, even brought his own work gloves. When I try to wear him down with endless tasks, he just say what's next? Sir, one Saturday I had him helping me rebuild the deck. I was being extra harsh, making him redo boards that were perfectly fine. Around noon, my daughter brought us water. As she walked away, I caught Pete watching her. But it wasn't the way most teenage boys looked at girls. He had this soft.

Her husband's female friend finally crossed the line. My husband's friend Kate always had to be the main character in every situation. When someone else had good news, Kate suddenly had better news. At group dinners, she'd hijack any conversation within five minutes. I couldn't stand her, but I put up with it because she and Zach had been friends since college. After my husband and I announced our pregnancy at 12 weeks, things with Kate got really weird. Suddenly, Kate was everywhere we went sporting a small baby bump. She showed up at our favorite brunch spot rubbing her belly. She enrolled in our exact prenatal yoga class. She even switched to our OB practice. Nobody questioned it because these things happen and women get pregnant. At the same time, she posted weekly bump photos on Instagram and everyone congratulated her just like they did me. Three months in, one of our friends mentioned something strange at a girl's night. She said Kate's belly looked bigger the previous Tuesday at Book Club than it did at Saturday's barbecue. When she brought it up, Kate burst into tears about how cruel it was to comment on a pregnant woman's body. She went on about water retention and bloating and how pregnant women deal with enough judgment without their friends piling on. Our friend felt terrible and apologized profusely while the rest of us comforted Kate. After that night, nobody dared mention anything about her appearance again, even, even though I Started noticing her bump size seemed to fluctuate, too. That's when things got uncomfortable. Kate started making comments about how wild it was that we got pregnant around the same time. She'd joke about our babies being best friends, maybe even more than friends someday. Then the jokes got stranger, like when she said pregnancy brain made her forget exactly when she conceived. And wasn't it funny how close our due dates were? She started showing up at every single appointment Zach and I had. Always in the waiting room when we arrived. Claiming her appointment was right before or after hours during our maternity photo shoot at the park, she appeared with her own photographer, saying what a coincidence that she'd booked the same spot. The.

My girlfriend said, let's just be friends after two years together. So I treated her exactly like I treat my other friends, with boundaries. Tara and I had been together for two years, living together for one. We were talking about future plans, her sister's wedding next summer where I was supposed to be her plus 1. Then on a random Thursday evening, she sat me down for the talk. I love you, but I'm not in love with you anymore. She said, I think we should transition to being friends, get along so well, have the same friend group. We'd make amazing friends but not amazing partners. Here's what killed me, she said. All this while already having packed a bag. Her friend Marissa was picking her up in an hour. She planned this whole thing down to having somewhere to stay already got an exit strategy. I said, we're adults, we're friends. We can make this work. I sat there processing two years living together, talking about kids someday. Now she wants to be buddies. Okay, I said, yeah, let's be friends. She actually smiled, relieved, like I just agreed to her perfect plan where she gets to dump me but keep all the benefits of having me in her life. The next morning, I did exactly what Tara asked, treated her like a friend. That's when I Learned she had a very different definition of friendship than I did. First text came at 7:00am. Could you drop Off my work laptop. Sure. I'll leave it at the front desk of your office Monday. Can't you bring it by Marissa's? I need it for the weekend. I've got plans. Monday works better. She didn't like that.

What did your parents say to you as a kid that still affects you today? I'll go first. My dad always told me, ever since I could remember, sweetheart, never trust a man who butters his toast all the way to the edges. It was so specific, so weird, that it just became a family joke. We never knew where he got it from. He'd just say it with a completely straight face over breakfast. For 20 years. It was just a funny thing my quirky dad said. Then I met Mark. Mark was perfect. I don't mean, oh, he's great perfect. I mean, he seemed like he was built in a lab to be the ideal boyfriend. He remembered the name of my childhood dog after I mentioned it. Once he Learned how to cook my favourite meal from my grandma's recipe. My friends loved him. My mom adored him. We dated for a year, and it was flawless. We decided to move in together, and I felt like the luckiest person alive. The first Saturday we were in our new apartment, I was making coffee and he was making breakfast. I looked over and he was at the counter carefully buttering a piece of toast. He held it with such focus, spreading the butter in smooth, even strokes. And he went all the way to the absolute final millimeter of the crust. Every single edge was perfectly covered. A little alarm. My dad's voice went off in

Scary man walked into our classroom and said, everyone whose parents work downtown, stay after class. He's sweating so bad it's dripping on our test papers and he keeps checking his phone every few seconds. I look for our teacher, but she left to make copies 10 minutes ago and never came back. The man doesn't even say his name, just stares at all of us breathing heavily and then asks really loud whose parents work in the downtown offices, you know, the big buildings. Nobody raises their hand because we all know about stranger danger and this guy seems dangerous. He gets mad and his face goes from red to almost purple. He yells, I know some of you have parents there. This is important. Finally, me and four other kids slowly raise our hands because maybe something happened to our parents and he needs to tell us. He points at us and says, you 5, stay after the bell rings. Everyone else, leave as fast as you can. The girl next to me grabs my wrist and whispers, run with me, but my legs won't move. What if my mom needs me and this man is supposed to take me to her? The bell rings and everyone practically runs out like the rooms on fire. The man locks the door behind them with this loud click and my stomach drops like on a roller coaster. He won't even let us near our backpacks where our phones are. The Quiet girl starts crying and he doesn't even care, just keeps checking the window. Then his watch saying 15 minutes. We wait 15 minutes, which makes no sense because our parents usually pick us up in 5 minutes. The classroom phone rings and he rips it from the wall, like actually rips it out and throws it in the trash. And now I'm really scared because why would he do that unless he's kidnapping us? We hear sirens outside, lots of them getting louder. He stands in front of the door, blocking it with his whole body. The football player kid who's bigger than some teachers rushes the door. The man catches him with one hand. It didn't take him any effort to stop the biggest of us. He keeps saying no calls, not yet. Your parents can't know you're here. And those sirens aren't for us. They're connected. I think maybe he did something bad downtown where our parents work. Maybe we're hostages. The room smells like his sweat now, sour and wrong. The principal's voice crackles on the intercom saying all students proceed to evacuation positions immediately. But the man doesn't move from the door. We hear hundreds of feet running in the hallways, doors slamming, teachers yelling. There were more sirens than I've ever heard before. Like every fire truck and ambulance in the city is coming here. The quiet girl throws up on her desk from being so scared. He tosses her his jacket to clean Up. And when he does, I see he has an empty gum holster under his arm, which makes me almost scream, but I cover my mouth. Teachers are banging on our door, yelling to open up. But he yells back, official emergency protocol, these students are accounted for. And keeps mumbling as he checks the time, 12 minutes, 11 minutes, 10 minutes, like he's counting down to something bad. I can hear my phone in my backpack buzzing with texts, probably from my mom, but he won't let me check. Please, I beg him. Is my mom okay? They don't understand, he keeps saying. Sweat dripping off his chin. If you leave now, you'll walk right into it. But he won't tell us what it is. His phone rings. He fumbles it, accidentally hitting speaker. The person on the phone says chemical cloud has passed the school perimeter. Downtown sector is sealed. We all freeze. He's still blocking the door. Why isn't he letting us go? Another voice cuts in. Confirm, guard.

Happened when a teacher broke the rules. My chemistry teacher, Mr Santiago, had one rule that everyone knew, absolutely no phones during lab experiments, period. He confiscated dozens that semester. So when mine started buzzing non stop during our titration lab, the entire class froze. Everyone watched as Mr Santiago marched across the room, his face set in that familiar owl. Hand it over, Daniel, he said, extending his palm. But when he glanced at my screen, his expression completely changed. His face went white. Dad's in the er. Come now, Mom. 23 missed calls, 12 voicemails. The whole class went dead silent. Mister Santiago stared at the phone, then looked at me with something I'd never seen before, pure understanding. Pack up your stuff right now, he said quietly. But Mister Santiago, you can't leave school during pack your stuff. He grabbed his car keys from his desk drawer, turned to the class, said, read Chapter 12, take notes, I'll be back. Alyssa raised her hand, but what about the lab? Clean up your stations. The lab can wait. We bolted down the empty hallway. In the parking lot, he unlocked his up Honda Civic and we jumped in. The second we hit the main road, he floored it. 60 in a 35, 80 in a 55. My father had a massive heart attack when I was 17, he said, knuckles white on the steering wheel. I was in algebra class, asked to leave three times. He ran a Red light. My teacher said the test was more important than my family. Drama wouldn't let me go. We screeched around a corner. He died while I sat there solving for X. Pulled into the hospital parking lot on two wheels, I ran inside, found my mom sobbing in the waiting room. Dad was stable. Bad fall off a ladder, broken ribs, but alive. How did you get here so fast? Mom asked. I looked back through the glass doors. Mr Santiago was already gone. Monday morning, I walked into chemistry expecting everything to be normal. But Principal Dalton was standing at the front of the classroom, arms crossed. Mr Santiago, he said coldly, my office now. The whole class exchange change glances. We all knew why. 20 minutes later, Mister Santiago returned looking grim. As soon as Principal Dalton left, Alyssa shot up from her seat. Someone snitched, she announced. Dalton knows you left campus. What did you tell him? Ethan asked. Mister Santiago shrugged. The truth that I violated district policy by leaving during class hours. Riley gasped. Are you getting fired? Probably suspended, maybe worse. That's when Alyssa did something incredible. She stood up, cleared her throat and said in a loud voice, Mister Santiago, I need to report a medical emergency. We all stared at her. Friday during lab, half the class got severe food poisoning. You had no choice but to escort us to the nurse's office, remember? Understanding dawned on Ethan's face. Oh, yeah. He said, clutching his stomach dramatically. Worst stomach bug of my life, definitely food poisoning, Riley added. Had to leave immediately. Could barely walk, said Jaden. Life threatening situation, said Madison. One by one, every single student in that class backed up Alyssa's story, even kids who usually hated Mister Santiago, even the ones who'd failed his tests. 28 students, same exact story, straight faces. When Principal Dalton returned an hour later to investigate the incident, he interviewed six random students. Food poisoning, said the first. Emergency situation, said the second. Mister Santiago saved our lives, said the third. Dalton looked increasingly frustrated, so none of you saw Mister Santiago leave campus for any other reason? What other.

Have you ever had to block someone all because your parents said so? My parents were so worried about me dating a skater boy, they couldn't imagine he'd be the reason I'm still alive today. A few nights ago, my parents found out about my skater boyfriend, Greg, when his message popped up on my screen at dinner. I love you, too. Who the heck are you talking to? My mom shouted, glaring at the screen of my phone. You're 14. No dating until you're 30. We were very clear. Dad pulled up Reg's Instagram on his own phone. Skateboarder? Really? This is who you're risking your future for? I tried to reason with them, but they refused to listen and forced me to block him everywhere, right there, over dinner. You'll thank us when you're in college, mom said. While I stopped, my friends tried passing messages between us at school, but my parents found out and threatened to call their parents. Eventually, everyone gave up, except for Greggus. Greggus showed up mysteriously in my valorant lobby. Hey, Mel. It's been a while, he said, his voice breaking. I miss you, Mel. I know we're not supposed to talk, but let's at least play like we used to. We started meeting in the lobbies every day after that, just playing and chatting about normal things. School, old friends, my strict parents. He never once tried to convince me to sneak around or meet up in person. He never complained. About my parents or tried to turn me against them. When I vent about how unfair they were being, he'd actually defend them. Sometimes they're just scared, Once my older sister got mixed up with some bad people in high school. Parents get paranoid. He still cared about me in all the ways that mattered. When I failed my chemistry test because I couldn't focus, he spent three hours teaching me balancing equations over discord. When my grandmother got sick, he stayed up until 3:00am just listening to me cry. You can always reach me here, he promised. I don't care what time it is. Mom almost caught us once when she walked by while discord was open. I clicked my game lobby just in time. Homework break? She asked. I nodded and switched back to my essay, my heart pounding so hard I thought she'd hear it after she left Greg's message. Maybe we should stop. I don't want to get you in trouble. But I couldn't lose him again. He was the only person who I could rely on. And thank god I didn't lose him, because a couple of days later, my friend Sarah and I got caught up in some shady business. It was supposed to be a normal Saturday night sleepover. Her parents went out for their anniversary, leaving us to watch movies and eat junk food. I was on the phone messaging greatest on discord when Sarah's older brother Joshua came home. From college, completely wasted with two other friends, Sarah immediately tensed up. baby sis and baby girl, he winked disgustingly. He and his friends sat beside us on the sofa, placing his arm over my shoulder, constantly whispering things like, I know you're not as innocent as you act, and your parents don't have to know. I pushed his face away and stood up, glaring. Can you stop? Sarah was almost crying, begging me not to make him mad. He gets mean when he's drunk, she whispered. Just ignore him and he'll pass out soon. But when Joshua grabbed my waist and tried to pull me onto his lap, I grabbed Sarah's arm and ran to the bathroom. Quickly locking the door, he started pounding on it, laughing with his friends about how I was playing hard to get and needed to loosen up. Sarah hopped into the tub, hugging her knees to her chest. I patted my pockets, realizing I had left my phone in the living room. Soon the knocks on the door became angrier. Hitting the door harder, jiggling the handle aggressively, Sarah meekly handed me her phone.

Decision I spent my actual birthday doing something I'd never done before. I went shopping alone, bought myself the exact dress I'd shown him, got my nails done, and treated myself to dinner at this fancy Italian place downtown. The waiter even brought me free cake when I mentioned it was my birthday. For the next month, every time Danny mentioned his upcoming birthday, I played dumb. When he showed me golf clubs online and said these would be perfect for my birthday, I just said cool and kept folding laundry. When he asked what restaurant we should book for his birthday dinner, I told him I hadn't really thought about it. When he mentioned taking the day off work to celebrate, I said that sounded nice and changed the subject. March 14th arrived. I woke up early, got dressed for work like any normal day, and started making coffee. Danny came downstairs in his favorite shirt, clearly expecting something special. Morning, I said, not looking up from my phone. It's my birthday, he said, waiting for my reaction. I looked up, pretended to think for a second, then snapped my fingers. Oh yeah! Happy birthday, babe. Have a good day at work. His face went through about five different emotions. Confusion, hurt, anger, then this weird panic. That's it? You're not taking the day off? We don't have dinner plans? I shrugged, grabbing my keys. I've been super busy with work stuff lately. Haven't really had time to plan anything. When I got home that night, he was sitting at the kitchen table looking defeated. You really forgot my birthday, he said quietly. I didn't forget, I replied. I just figured if birthdays aren't important enough to remember without reminders, then maybe we shouldn't make such a big deal about them. The realization hit him like a truck. His mouth opened and closed a few times before he finally said, this is about your birthday, isn't it? What about my birthday? I asked innocently. He put his head in his hands. I've been a complete idiot. Yeah, I said, you have been. The next morning I woke up to rose petals leading from our bedroom to the kitchen, where he'd made my favourite breakfast and had a jewellery box sitting next to my coffee. Inside was a necklace that looked exactly like my mom's missing one. I know I can't undo the past three years, he said, but I swear I will never forget again.

Teacher parents loved because he coached the winning soccer team, the one who high fived kids in the hallway, who'd been teaching for 15 years. I called 9 1 1 that night. The female officer who interviewed Maya was gentle, patient. Maya told her everything, how Mister Garcia took her to the equipment room during class, how he made her play a secret game, how it hurt, how he did it to other girls, too, during their special practice time. The principal called me at 6:00am not to apologize, to scold me. He said I should have come to him first, that calling police was premature, that Mister Garcia was a valued member of their community. I recorded the entire call.
NA
NA

My boyfriend saw my Venmo and asked, why are you getting paid $500 weekly by someone called Sugar Daddy? I nearly choked on my cereal because that was not a conversation I wanted to have at 8:00am on a Tuesday. It's not what it looks like, I said quickly. But Jake was already scrolling through my transaction history with his eyebrows raised. Really? Because it looks like you're getting paid every Friday for the past three months by someone whose contact name is literally Sugar Daddy. Mike with money bag emojis turned his phone toward me showing the evidence. Are you seriously doing that kind of work without telling me? I grabbed my phone back, my face burning red. Jake, I swear to God it's not what you think. Mike is my boss at the pet sitting company. He stared at me like I'd grown a third leg. Your boss pays you through Venmo and you call him Sugar Daddy Mike? I realised how absolutely insane this sounded, but it was the truth. The company payroll system has been broken for months. So Mike pays all the employees through Venmo. And I saved his contact as Sugar Daddy Mike as a joke because he's always buying us coffee and treats for the dogs. Jake was not buying this explanation at all. That's the most ridiculous cover story I've ever heard. Look, I'll prove it. I called Mike right there in our kitchen. He answered on the second ring with his Usual cheerful voice. Hey, kitten, you're not scheduled until this afternoon. Everything okay? I put him on speaker. Mike, my boyfriend, thinks we're having some kind of inappropriate relationship because of how you pay us and how your name shows up in my phone. Mike burst out laughing. Oh, no, not again. This happened with my daughter's boyfriend last month. He thought she was cheating on him with her sugar daddy Mike. He explained to Jake that his payroll company had been hacked six months ago, so he'd been paying everyone through cash apps. Jake still looked skeptical. But why Sugar Daddy Mike? Mike laughed even harder. Because I spoil my employees and the pets rotten. Free coffee every day, premium dog treats, bonuses for good work. The girls started calling me Sugar Daddy Mike because I'm always buying supplies and treating them like family. He invited Jake to come by the office to meet the team. You can meet the other four dog walkers who probably also have me saved as Sugar Daddy Mike in their phones. I could see Jake starting to believe the story, but he was still embarrassed about jumping to conclusions. This is why you should have just told me you had a job, he muttered. After we hung up with Mike, Jake apologized profusely. I should have just asked you directly instead of making assumptions. But then he got curious about other things. Wait, if you're only making $250 twice a month, how are You paying for all those expensive dinner you've been getting delivered? My stomach dropped because I've been hoping he wouldn't notice my Doordash habit. That's a different situation, I said, trying to change the subject. But Jake was already connecting dots. Please tell me you're not actually doing sugar daddy stuff on the side to pay for food. I just waved it off and tried to ignore him for the rest of the day. The next day, I brought Jake to the pet sitting office to meet Mike and prove my story. He was exactly what you'd expect, 50 something guy in dog hair covered clothes who immediately offered us both coffee and dog treats to sample. See, he said to Jake, total sugar daddy behaviour but completely innocent. The other employees confirmed that they all had similar contact names for Mike and that he was basically the most generous boss ever. Last month he paid for my dog's vet Bill when I couldn't afford it, one coworker said. Jake felt terrible for assuming the worst and bought lunch for the whole pet sitting crew as an apology. I watched too much true crime, he explained to Mike. When I saw those payments, my mind immediately went to the darkest possibility. Mike laughed it off and said it happened more often than you'd think. My wife gets suspicious, looks at the bank when she deposits checks made out to Sugar Daddy, Mike's Pet Care. That night, Jake finally relaxed, convinced Everything was fine. But when I checked my phone before bed, another 500 dollar transfer came in. The message read, good job. He bought every word.

This morning, I didn't bring her coffee in bed like I had every weekend for five years. When she came downstairs expecting her usual cup, I was finishing mine. Coffee is in the kitchen, I said without looking up. I saw our marriage clearly for the first time. I was the one planning eight nights she'd complain about. I was the one remembering anniversaries. I was the one keeping romance alive. When I stopped being romantic, I stopped with everything unnecessary. No more good morning kisses. No more asking about her day. No more caring where she went. By day 10, the cracks showed. Are you going to ask me about my presentation? She said, clearly fishing. Do you want to tell me about it? Well, it went well, she said, waiting for follow up questions that never came. Good for you. I went back to my phone. She stood there for a full minute waiting for me to engage. When it became clear I wasn't playing that role anymore, she left without another word. Three weeks in, she was losing her mind. She mentioned male co workers, talked about her ex reaching out, brought up how attentive other husbands were. Each comment was fishing for jealousy, any sign I still cared. My response was always, that's interesting. Then I'd return to whatever I was doing. I'd start. Started hitting the gym, reading books, learning guitar. Something she'd always dismissed as a waste of time. One month in, she cracked She was waiting at the kitchen table when I got home. Papers spread everywhere. We need to talk. You're punishing me because your feelings got hurt?

the friendship is solid when y'all don't even go to the same school. And it doesn't matter. Like, bro, real friends don't need to be in the same classroom or even the same postcode to stay tight. You could be across the city in a different uniform learning completely different subjects, but somehow the bond never fades. Everyone else is like, oh, if you don't go to the same school, you'll drift apart. Nah, bro, not us. I could be sitting in math class stressed out over equations I'll never use in life, and you're across town doing science experiments and we're still texting dumb memes like we saw each other five minutes ago. And when we do link up on the weekend, it's like we never left. No awkward vibes, no weird energy, just straight vibes, bro. We might not be in the same school, but we've got the same mindset, same humour, same jokes, same energy. And the best part, when you meet their school friends and suddenly you feel famous, like, oh, you're that friend they always talk about, yeah, that's me. I don't even go here, but I run this friendship. So if you've got a friend that's in another school but still feels closer than anyone in your class, appreciate that. That's real friendship. Forget proximity. It's about loyalty.

NA

I didn't use my daughter's college fund for my stepson's rehab. My husband came home from work last Tuesday with this look on his face that I knew meant trouble. He'd been on the phone with his ex wife all afternoon about Caleb. His 24 year old son. Caleb had overdosed again. Fourth time this year. And this time they found him passed out in some gas station bathroom with a needle still hanging out of his arm. I was making dinner when my husband sat down at the kitchen table and just stared at me. My daughter Emma was upstairs doing homework. Completely unaware of what was about to happen. He cleared his throat and said they needed $30,000 for an impatient rehab program. 60 days. Some fancy place up in the mountains that supposedly had better success rates. I stopped stirring the pasta sauce and turned around $30,000. We'd already blown through almost $14,000 on outpatient programs that didn't work because Caleb either didn't show up or relapsed the second he got out. I'd personally paid a thousand bucks for his first detox, thinking maybe this time would be different. Then my husband paid 6,005 hundred for another program. Then we split another sixty five hundred when Caleb swore on his dead grandmother's grave that he was ready to get clean. Here's the thing about Caleb. He'd stolen my wedding ring, my mother's jewellery, our T V, Emma's laptop, and even loose change from Emma's piggy bank. The Kid had no problem looking a 15 year old girl in the eye and taking her birthday money. And every time it was the same story. He was sorry, he was gonna change. He just needed one more chance. So when my husband said they wanted to use Emma's college fund, I actually laughed. Not because it was funny, but because I couldn't believe he was serious. That money came from Emma's dad, who died when she was 6. Her grandparents had been putting money in there since she was born. $180,000. That was meant to get her through whatever college she wanted without debt. Emma's crazy smart. Like, scary smart. Her teachers keep telling me she could get into Harvard or Yale if she keeps her grades up. But even with scholarships, those schools cost a fortune. And our incomes too high to qualify for financial aid. That money was supposed to be her safety net, her ticket to whatever future she wanted. I told my husband, absolutely not. The fund was off limit.

Some kids pretend to be sick to skip school. Well, I decided to take things a step further. One night while I was in sixth grade, I decided I really did not want to go to school the following day. Unfortunately, my mom was really strict about missing classes. According to her, I was not allowed to miss any days unless I was on my deathbed. Being a genius 11 year old, I decided to look up how to get a fever. I tried everything from taking a cold bath to standing under the fan. Any of the other regular getting sick ideas I could find, I tried. Nothing seemed to be working. I did more research when I came upon a very promising tutorial. All I had to do was take a bath at the hottest temperature. My bathtub would go in and stay up all night. I figured since I tried so many things already, this last shot in the dark couldn't hurt. Boy, was I wrong. I started the water for a steaming hot bath. It stung to get in it, and my skin was getting red and irritated. However, at that time, I believed it was a normal sensation. In my mind, I convinced myself I just needed to give my body time to acclimate to the temperature. Similar to how a cold bath becomes more bearable the longer you stay in it. Unfortunately, my body never adapted to the heat. Thinking back, it was Definitely way too hot to be in. But for some reason, I was determined to skip school. Miraculously, I survived the piping hot bath for 30 whole minutes.

My neighbor cursed me for using my own yard. Well, I'm going to use it even more. I lived in this townhouse for three years with my husband and our two 60 pound dogs. The weird thing is I hadn't been in my own backyard for like two whole summers cause of what happened before my neighbours moved in about 3 years ago, I got attacked by this random dog while I was walking home from work. The thing just came out of nowhere and went up my leg. I ended up needing stitches and everything. But the worst part was how messed up it left me mentally. I couldn't even look at unfamiliar dogs without having a panic attack. Right after I got attacked, these new neighbours moved in next door. They had 4 dogs, three tiny Chihuahuas and one Australian Shepherd. These weren't normal dogs, though. The second they heard any noise from my side of the fence, they charge over and start barking like they wanted to kill something. It was insane. Every time I tried to go outside with my dogs, their pack would go absolutely nuts. They'd slam against the fence growling and carrying on for like 10 minutes straight. My dogs are super chill and well trained so they just ignore it. But I couldn't handle it. The sound would trigger my panic attacks instantly. For two years, I basically gave up my backyard. My husband thought I was being dramatic, but he Didn't understand what it felt like to have your heart racing every time you heard barking. I spent like $1,000 on therapy sessions trying to work through the trauma. Finally, this spring, my therapist helped me get to a point where I could be around strange dogs again. Was so excited to actually use my yard. The first weekend I went out there, I had this routine worked out. When their dogs came outside, I'd bring mine in for a few minutes until theirs calm down, then let mine back out. It wasn't ideal, but whatever. Last Sunday, I was playing fetch with my dogs when the neighbors let theirs.

Why is the McDonald's ice cream machine always broken? I worked at McDonald's for three years and discovered the real reason the ice cream machine is always broken. It's not broken. It's rarely actually broken. It's a combination of deliberately terrible design, corporate contracts and employees who've given up fighting a system designed to fail. But one summer, I decided to become the ice cream vigilante my store needed and it nearly got me fired. The Taylor C602 ice cream machine is a nightmare. Wrapped in stainless steel, it takes four hours to clean. And if you mess up even one step, it locks you out completely. The cleaning cycle must be done daily. But here's the kicker, it can only be done by someone trained on that specific machine. The training takes eight hours and cost the franchise owner $600 per employee. Most stores train one, maybe two people. So when Jeremy, our only trained ice cream technician, quit to focus on his Soundcloud career, our machine became permanently broken. The owner, Mister Chen, refused to pay for more training. Just tell customers it's broken, he said. Soft serve has the lowest profit margin anyway. For two months, I watched disappointed kids press their faces against the window, watching other people get ice cream at the Dairy Queen across the street. I watched elderly customers who driven specifically for a cone leave empty handed. One regular, Missus Patterson, came every Sunday for a vanilla cone. After church, she stopped Coming all together, I decided to fix this. I found the C602 manual online, all 296 pages of it. I studied it like my life depended on it. I watched YouTube videos of rogue McDonald's employees demonstrating the cleaning cycle. I Learned that Taylor, the manufacturer, had created a monopoly where only their technicians could repair the machines, charging franchises thousands for simple fixes. I started coming in three hours early, unpaid, to practice the cleaning cycle. The machine was like a puzzle designed by someone who hated both.
NA

For my daughter to finish school, a parent turned to me and asked, did your ex husband have a beard? I giggled nervously. Um, yeah. Why? No, no, no, no, no. She suddenly screamed while walking as far away from me as possible. I just laughed because moms can be so weird sometimes. But the next day, my daughter came home from school crying, Mommy! Leah said her mom said she can't talk to me anymore. Leah was her best friend. I immediately took out my phone and texted her mom, asking if everything was okay. No response. I texted Emily's mom, one of the other girls in her trio. Still nothing. I had just managed to calm my baby girl down when the pizza arrived. Usually our delivery guy is the apator 5,000. But tonight he just set the box on my doorstep and practically ran away. George, you forgot your tip! I yelled, waving a 20. He just kept going. The next few days were insane. At my daughter's soccer practice, Helen saw me walking towards her and held her phone to her ear. No one had even called her, Helen, what's going on? She mouth sorry and walked faster. We used to complain about our husbands together. Parents were whispering and showing each other something on their phones. When I walked by, they quickly put them away. By Thursday, my daughter was refusing to go to school. I moved my desk away from everyone else. The teacher, Said it was for space reasons, but there's like 10 feet between me and Leah now. I tried to bring her to the hairdresser to cheer her up, but when the woman saw me coming, she closed early. No apology. Just flipped the sign and pulled the blinds. My phone buzzed. It was my landlord. Heard what happened. So sorry. Rent can wait this month. This was the same man who charged me a fifty dollar inconvenience fee when I paid rent at 12:00am instead of midnight. Then the birthday party. Emily's sleepover. My daughter found out that everyone was invited except her. She was having such a bad panic attack that I had to call a hospital. Mom, what did I do? Emily is my best friend. Enough was enough. I called the school office. Something is happening to my daughter. She's being systematically excluded and I need answers right now. The counselor called back within an hour, but her voice was off, like she was choosing every word carefully. Missus Callahan, we just wanted to check in about your home environment. Is everything safe? Anyone new spending time around your daughter? What? What are you even asking me? I think it's best if we discuss this in person. Can you come in tomorrow morning? No. You'll tell me right now why my daughter is being tortured. Long pause. The principal will explain everything tomorrow. Beep. She hung up. Then at eleven PM, an email from my gym membership. Terminated, effective immediately. I've been going there for five years. The owner knew me by name. I was trying to figure out what to do when my daughter crawled into my bed at 2:00am, sobbing, Mommy, am I ugly? It took everything in me. Not

The school called saying my daughter was dealing pills in the parking lot. I checked my daughter Kate's bank account and saw zeros where $300 should have been. Kate was 16 and worked 20 hours a week at a burger place. But somehow her entire paycheck had vanished. When Kate got home from her shift, I confronted her with the statement. I've been buying stuff for Zoe at school. She has a baby and nobody helps her, she explained. My first thought was that someone was running a sob story scam on my naive daughter. But Kate insisted that Zoe desperately needed help and the baby suffer without it. The next morning, I gave Kate extra cash and told her to give it to Zoe. Thanks, Mom. Zoe's going to cry when I give her this. That afternoon, I got a call from the school. We need to discuss something serious with you about Kate. Immediately, I rushed to the school expecting the worst. Your daughter was seen in the parking lot giving another student prescription bottles and cash and what appeared to be a substance deal. We have zero tolerance for substances on school property and we've already contacted the school resource officer. He turned his computer screen toward me to show the security footage of Kate hand things Zoe two orange prescription bottles and money by her car. I felt sick realizing I've been giving Kate money that might have been funding prescription substance stealing. Mr Hayes said Kate claimed the prescriptions were antibiotics and diaper cream for a baby, but that sounded like a ridiculous lie to cover up selling pills. No teenager carries around multiple prescriptions for a baby they don't have, he said while shaking his head. That's when the school nurse walked in carrying baby who was coughing so hard his tiny body shook with each breath. This is Zoe's son, she said quietly while patting his back. She brought him to my office this morning because he ran out of his breathing medicine and she didn't know what else to do. The principal went completely silent. The nurse explained that Zoe was 16 and had been trying to finish school while raising a six month old baby.

While setting up story time at the library, an eight year old asked, have you ever played The Hunger Games? I smiled like the movie with Katniss Everdeen. No, silly. It's when we see who cries first from being hungry. I never lose anymore, but Millie still does. Her little sister, maybe 5, was sitting in the corner clutching her stomach. How long do you play this game? I asked. Keep in my voice light. My record is three days, Ava beamed with pride. Daddy marks it on the fridge chart. Millie only made it one day before she cried like a baby. My assistant Jackie shot me a glance. That's when I noticed how Ava's dress hung loose on her frame. That's impressive, I said, trying to keep my voice steady. Do you play this game a lot? Every week, sometimes twice. If we've been bad, like when I forgot to clean my room, I had to play for four days. Four days is a really long time without food, I said, watching her stuff crackers in her pockets. What happens when someone loses? They have to wait longer. Daddy says, only we kids need food every day. Millie whimpered from her corner. My tummy hurts all the time. Ava whipped around. Shut up. What's wrong with you? You'll lose points. Do you want to wait another week? My hands stilled on the book I was preparing to read. That seems like a long time for the game, not Really? Theo went nine days once, but then he faint at school and the nurse got all weird about it. Now he's not allowed to play anymore. She said it was pity for Theo. Theo's your brother, foster brother. He went to live somewhere else. Daddy said he was too weak for our family. Ava, when did you eat last? I asked casually, like we were discussing the weather. She counted on her fingers. Tuesday, daddy says, I'm getting stronger. It was Saturday. This child hadn't eaten in four days and was proud of it. I noticed Millie's.

My dog saved my daughter's life. Now I have to choose between them. I'm at the vet's office with king, my 14 year old golden retriever. And the vet's showing me X rays on her computer screen. There's a tumor pressing on his spine, dark mass, size of a golf ball. Without surgery, he has maybe two weeks. With surgery, maybe three more years. The vet points at the X ray and all I can see is a countdown clock. The surgery costs $15,000. I look at my phone, my bank account shows barely 16 thousand. That's all my emergency money. Here's the thing, my daughter Lizzie is in a wheelchair. Two years ago a neighbor's dog broke its chain and went after her. King jumped between them. The other dog bit king's shoulder and neck bad, but he didn't stop protecting Lizzie until hell came. She lived because of him, but the attack hurt her spine. She can't walk anymore. Last month we found a doctor who does a special surgery, growth plate surgery. It could help her walk again, really walk. But it only works while kids bones are still growing. Lizzie turns 14 in three months after for that, her growth plates close and it's too late forever. The surgery costs $15,000. Insurance says no, won't pay anything. The vets waiting for an answer about king. My hands won't stop shaking. I'm looking at this dog who saved my daughter's life who still has scars on his Neck from protecting. Now he's dying. And I have exactly enough money to save him or exactly enough money to help my daughter walk. Not both, the vet says quality of life. But all I hear is choose between the one who saved her and saving her future. Lizzie's at school right now in her wheelchair. She carries around a picture of king to show anyone she meets and calls him my hero. She doesn't know we're here at the vet. Doesn't.

My brother said, if you're too broke to dress properly for my wedding, maybe you shouldn't be my best man. I said, you're right, I shouldn't, and pulled out my phone to cancel the 18 thousand dollar wire transfer I'd scheduled for tomorrow morning. Let me rewind. My younger brother ash is getting married next month to Leah, this pharmaceutical sales rep who thinks anyone without a master's degree is beneath her. Three nights ago, I'd gone to the bank and arranged to pay off the remaining $18,000 on Ash's truck as a wedding gift. I was going to surprise him at the wedding, make this whole speech about new beginnings, no debt holding them back. I should have just known better, especially when Leah insisted on this intimate groomsman dinner at some pretentious fusion place where they serve foam instead of actual food. The other groomsmen were all Leah's picks. Winston, an investment banker who wouldn't shut up about his portfolio. Joshua, a medical resident who kept reminding everyone he was almost a doctor. And Markie, who allegedly ran a startup but seemed to just spend daddy's money. The judgment started before the appetizers arrived. So cold, Winston smirked. Looking at my calloused hands, ash says, you work construction. It must be nice having such simple work. No spreadsheets, no thinking, just lifting heavy things. Joshua chimed in next. Didn't you drop out of community college? How do you even read blueprints without an education? The table chuckled. I Tried explaining. Actually, I own the company now. We just landed a municipal contract. Markey cut me off laughing. Right, you own it. Reconstruction guy claims they run their own business when they're really just picking up day labor. Leah wrinkled her nose. Is that why you smell like that? I thought something was off. It's like sweat and tar. The insults kept getting sharper as I watched my brother just sit there, not even trying to stop them. You know what's pathetic, Joshua said after wine had loosened his tongue. You're 32 doing a job the teenagers do for summer cash. My 16 year old nephew could do what you do probably better, too. Winston piled on. How much could you possibly make, 30 grand a year? I make that in a month, man. It's actually sad. My brother ash finally decided to speak up, but not to defend me. He just.

My boyfriend keeps laughing with my female co worker and teaching her his language. She still thinks she's learning how to flirt. Trish started working at my waitressing job five months ago and from the moment she saw my boyfriend Kao, she set her eyes on him like he was the last Infinity Stone. He was half Japanese like me, meaning we related on a deep level. And for some reason, Trish hated this the most. The first time she saw us having lunch, she made herself comfortable in my seat next to his. When I got up to use the bathroom, she pressed her hips against his and flashed a flirty smile before saying konichiwa. When he awkwardly set it back, she grabbed a pair of chopsticks and started eating noodles unsuccessfully complaining about whitewashed girls appropriating his beautiful culture, very obviously referring to me. When I came back from the bathroom, she told me to grab a chair, telling me I was welcome to join in on their conversation. It definitely struck a nerve, but I was so secure in kaido and his relationship, I didn't even mind until Trish started trying to implode us. She'd corner him when I wasn't looking and tell him innuendo style phrases in Japanese that she got off Google Translate. Whenever we were talking, he always squeeze past us very slowly, sometimes making sure to rub her behind against Kaido and other times facing him directly and giving him the F me Eyes. The thing that really made me mad was when she asked Kaido to come teach her Japanese at her house after work. I was going to confront her there and then, but we were in the middle of a very busy service and I told myself, I do it right after big mistake. You see, at some point during service, these important Japanese business men came in for food. They were at my section, but Trish practically shoved me aside to serve them. Please speak Japanese. I understand everything, she told them. They looked pleasantly surprised and started rattling off their order with specific modifications and allergies. Trish just kept saying, hi, hi, while scribbling nonsense. 45 minutes later, it was chaos. One guy got served the wrong starter. Another received two sushi orders instead of his chicken chow Mein. And the third guy actually started having an allergic reaction to shellfish, which he asked to exclude. That's when Trish.

I didn't use my daughter's college fund for my stepson's rehab. My husband came home from work last Tuesday with this look on his face that I knew meant trouble. He'd been on the phone with his ex wife all afternoon about Caleb, his 24 year old son. Caleb had overdosed again, fourth time this year. And this time they found him passed out in some gas station bathroom with a needle still hanging out of his arm. I was making dinner when my husband sat down at the kitchen table and just stared at me. My daughter Emma was upstairs doing homework, completely unaware of what was about to happen. He cleared his throat and said they needed $30,000 for an impatient rehab program, 60 days, some fancy place up in the mountains that supposedly had better success rates. I stopped stirring the pasta sauce and turned around $30,000. We'd already blown through almost $14,000 on outpatient programs that didn't work because Caleb either didn't show up or relapsed the second he got out. I'd personally paid a thousand bucks for his first detox thinking maybe this time would be different. Then my husband paid 6,500 for another program. Then we split another sixty five hundred when Caleb swore on his dead grandmother's grave that he was ready to get clean. But here's the thing about Caleb. He stolen my wedding ring, my mother's jewelry, our TV, Emma's laptop and even loose change from Emma's piggy bank. The kid Had no problem looking a 15 year old girl in the eye and taking her birthday money. And every time it was the same story. He was sorry. He was gonna change. He just needed one more chance. So when my husband said they wanted to use Emma's college fund, I actually laughed, not because it was funny, but because I couldn't believe he was serious. That money came from Emma's dad, who died when she was 6. Her grandparents had been putting money in there since she was born, 180,000.

I told my sister in law no one cares that she's pregnant. My cousin Rachel just buried her husband and two kids last week. Car accident took them all at once. She's left with just her 5 year old daughter Emma. And honestly, watching them at the funeral was the most heartbreaking thing I've ever seen in my life. So my brother Jake and his wife Kelly show up to our house that morning before we head to the church. First thing Kelly does is announce she's pregnant. We're all getting ready for a funeral. And she's like, guess what, everyone, we have news. My mom congratulated her but told her to keep it quiet for today out of respect. Did Kelly listen? Of course not. The second we get to the church, Kelly starts making these loud gagging noises and rubbing her completely flat stomach. Every time someone looked at her, she'd go, oh, sorry, morning sickness, I'm pregnant. You know, she kept saying stuff like, as a mom, I just can't imagine what Rachel's going through, which was ridiculous because Kelly doesn't have any kids yet. At the cemetery, she literally asked Rachel's sister to give up her seat so the pregnant lady could rest her feet. She'd been standing for like 10 minutes total. I was getting so annoyed, but I kept my mouth shut because it's a funeral. After the service, we went back to my aunt's house. Kelly kept making everything about herself. Someone would Mention how hard this must be for Rachel. And Kelly would jump in with, oh, I know. Now that I'm pregnant, I understand maternal instincts so much better. When people were talking about the babies who died, Kelly would rub her stomach and talk about how excited she was to be a mom. The bathroom thing was what really got me. Every time Kelly needed to use the bathroom, she'd announce pregnant lady coming through or baby on board needs to pee. There were like 30 people there grieving and she's treating it like her personal.

I didn't cancel long standing plans for a barbecue that I just found out about. My wife and I had made these plans back in January with our friend group for a beer festival up in the mountains. We're talking about three families plus some other friends. About nine people total. My father in law owns this rental property up there, so we booked it for Labor Day weekend and got all our tickets sorted come August. My grandparents text me about a family barbecue they're having that same weekend. I shoot back a quick message saying we can't make it because we've already got plans. Grandpa's totally cool about it, says he understands, no big deal. But then my mom gets involved. She texts me asking why we can't come to the barbecue. I explain the whole beer festival situation again. That's when she completely loses it. Starts going off about how disappointed she is, how I need to make the barbecue a priority, how I should cancel our plans for the festival. Then comes the guilt trip. She starts hitting me with the whole your grandparents are in their 80s speed, saying we won't have many more opportunities to get together, which is complete bullshit because we live in the same city and see them like two or three times a month minimum. She tells me a beer festival isn't a good reason to blow off my grandparents and that I need to reconsider my priorities. I'm sitting there Thinking, are you kidding me right now? I try explaining that I can't just cancel. The house is already booked. Tickets are paid for. If it was just me and my wife going, sure, we'd probably skip the festival and hit up the barbecue. But we've got eight other people counting on this trip. It's not

I called my mother in law ill mannered for going through my suitcase and criticizing my bikini. So here's what happened. Me and my husband Jake just got married two months ago, and we were finally going on our honeymoon to Mexico. His parents live like 30 minutes away, and they came over the night before to wish us goodbye and all that. Everything was going fine until his mom started being way too helpful. She kept asking if I packed vitamins and sunscreen and all this stuff. Then she offered to put some vitamin tablets in my suitcase for me. At first I was like, thanks, I'll do it myself. But then she was all insistent like, oh, no, it's fine. I can just put them in there. So I was like, okay, fine, just put them in the inner zipper pocket. Big mistake. I was in the bathroom getting ready for bed when I heard her rummaging around in our bedroom. When I came out, she was literally going through all my clothes in the suitcase. She had this bright pink bikini in her hands that I bought specifically for the trip. It was kind of revealing, but like, it's a honeymoon, right? She held it up and was like, are you really planning on wearing this in public? With this disgusted look on her face, I was so embarrassed and caught off guard that I just lost it. Told her to please not go through our private Stuff because it was rude and ill mannered. That's when she got all defensive and started lecturing me about how a honeymoon doesn't mean I need to wear revealing clothes on public beaches. She kept going on about modesty and how people would stare. Then she said our relationship and honeymoon wasn't for her to comment on, but she was literally commenting on it. I was getting more and more mad because, like, we're married.
