In my room, my sister busted down my door and asked, did you eat my candy? Yeah, I'm sorry. You had a bunch in that pack. I thought it wouldn't be bad if I ate a couple. Cecilia rushed over and grabbed my face, forcing my mouth open. She stared inside like she was looking for something specific and her face went white. We have to make you throw up right now. Why? I thought it was just candy. My voice came out muffled because she was still holding my jaw. She dragged me to the bathroom and started shoving her fingers toward my throat. I pulled away, disgusted and confused, but she kept trying. When that didn't work, she ran to the kitchen and came back with a glass of lemon juice mixed with baking soda. The smell alone made me gag, but she forced me to drink it. Nothing happened except my stomach felt weird and bubbly. Cecilia then tried making me spin in circles. She said motion sickness might help. I spun until I was dizzy, but still nothing. She made me drink salt water next, which tasted horrible and made me cough, but I still didn't throw up. She was getting more desperate by the second. Celia, what's wrong? Just tell me what I ate. I was scared now because she was acting insane. She ignored me and ran to get IPAC syrup from the medicine cabinet, but the bottle was expired and empty. He started Crying actual tears and pulling at her hair. I'd never seen my sister this freaked out about anything. She grabbed my shoulders and shook me, asking exactly where I found the candy and how many I ate. I told her it was in the small round container in her backpack, the one that looked like an Altoid's tin but fancier. She asked what color the pills were and if I was sure I ate them all. I said they were different colors, like some were white and some were pink and maybe one was green. I, I've eaten at least 6 or 7 while gaming because they tasted kind of sweet. My mom heard all the chaos and came upstairs to find Cecilia kneeling next to me by the toilet. What's going on here? Cecilia whispered something in Mom's ear and I watched my mother's expression change from annoyed to terrified in about two seconds. She grabbed her car keys and told me to put on shoes immediately because we were going to the hospital. No explanation, just pure panic on both their faces. The car ride was the scariest 15 minutes of my life. Cecilia was crying in the passenger seat and kept saying, I'm so sorry, mom, I'm so, so sorry. I didn't think he'd find them. Mom was gripping the steering wheel so tight her knuckles were white. She kept checking on me in the rearview mirror, asking if I felt dizzy or hot or if my Heart was racing. I said I felt fine, just scared. And she told me to tell her immediately if anything changed. What's going to happen to me, I asked from the back seat, starting to really freak out. I don't know, honey. Try to remain calm. We're almost there. Mom's voice was shaking and she was driving way over the speed limit. We ran two red lights and mom didn't even care. Cecilia kept looking back at me with tears streaming down her face. She reached back and grabbed my hand, squeezing it tight. That's when I knew something was really wrong because Cecelia never held my hand, not since I was like 5 years old. At the emergency room, mom rushed to the front desk, dragging me along. She whispered to the nurse who looked at me with this shocked expression, he ate them was all she could say, before calling for a doctor immediately. Nurse asked my weight and age while another nurse took my blood pressure. They kept exchanging looks like they'd never seen anything like this before. One nurse asked Cecilia why the pills weren't in a childproof container and Cecilia just sobbed harder. They put us in a room right away, which never happens at our hospital unless someone is dying. Cecilia was still crying and mom kept pacing back and forth. A doctor came in looking very serious with a clipboard and started asking questions. How many did I eat? When did I eat? Them. Did I feel anything strange? I told him I'd eaten maybe six or seven of the small, round pills, thinking they were candy. They were in a little compact case in Cecilia's backpack that looked like mints. The doctor examined me and checked my vitals, then left to talk to someone else. The waiting was killing me, and nobody would tell me what was wrong. A nurse came in and drew blood. Then another doctor came to examine me. They checked my reflexes and shined lights in my eyes and asked if I felt nauseous or different in any way. I saying I felt normal, just scared. They hooked me up to a heart monitor just in case, and the beeping made everything feel more serious. Finally, the head doctor came in and sat down. He had gray hair and kind eyes, but looked concerned. He asked Cecilia to explain exactly what kind of pills I'd taken. You could barely get the words out between sobs. You should be fine. Birth control pills aren't toxic and the dose you took won't cause serious harm. But he's a boy. Boys can't take birth control pills. Cecilia practically screamed. Worst scenario is your brother can't get pregnant.

The funniest takedown a teenager delivered in divorce court. I'm a family court clerk, and last week the medinas were divorcing and fighting over who gets to keep the house, claiming the other was too financially reckless to own property. Both kept presenting evidence. She bought a year supply of healing crystals for our cat. He bought a boat. We live in Arizona. She hired a life coach for her succulent plants. Mediator Betty looked like she needed a drink at 9:00am. I'd like to hear from your daughter, since she's listed as a witness. Lola walks in dressed like a tiny accountant, dragging two suitcases and a filing cabinet. She looked like she was moving in permanently. Mediator Betty stares at the luggage mountain. Lola, we're just having a conversation. With all due respect, ma'am, you haven't met my parents. You're going to need evidence. Can you tell us about your parents money habits? Lola opens the first suitcase and pulls out a binder. I brought three years of receipts. Receipts? Yes, ma'am. Filed under evidence. My parents shouldn't have credit cards. Betty almost spits out her coffee. Excuse me. Lola opens to a page with colorful charts. I've been tracking their spending since I was 11, ma'am. What kind of spending? Let's start with exhibit A. Lola holds up a bank statement. This is Mom's fourth treadmill. She buys a new one every year because this one will be different. They're all in the garage. We call it The treadmill graveyard. Exhibit B. Dad bought a three thousand dollar espresso machine. He only drinks instant coffee, ma'am. He thought it would inspire him to upgrade. Exhibit C. Mom orders Doordash from the restaurant that's literally next door. Last month she paid forty seven dollars for a twelve dollar sandwich. The restaurant is 40 feet away. An exhibit Dio. Dad belongs to three different gyms because each one has that special machine. He pays $120 a month total. He goes twice a month. That's $60 per workout. Betty is covering her mouth. Lola, how did you start handling the money? Someone had to pay the electric Bill, ma'am. They kept forgetting it wasn't on auto pay. Lola opens the second suit. This is Mom's online boutique phase. She bought wholesale designer handbags from sketchy websites. Our garage looks like a knockoff purse museum. She sold exactly three bags. How much did she spend? $8,000. Made $75 back. The mediator turns to the mom. Mrs. Medina. They looked real in the pictures. Lola continues. Dad's no better. He bought a truck to flip it. He put $5,000 of modifications on it. Damaged LED lights underneath that only light pink. And an attached disco ball inside. It's now worth less than before he bought it. May I present exhibit E. Lola pulls out two jars from the filing cabinet. This jar contains all the warranties dad bought that we've actually used. It's empty. This jar contains receipts for every warranty he's Purchased 83 warranties totaling $4,200. You never know when you'll need them, dad protests. Dad, you bought a three year warranty on a 12 dollar phone case. The warranty cost fifteen dollars. Lola pulls out a credit card Bill. Mom has a storage unit for her Amazon returns she never returned. She's paying one hundred fifty dollars a month to store things she doesn't want. I'll return them eventually. Mom, some of these boxes are from 2,018. What about your father? Betty asks. Dad bought a fishing boat. He gets seasick. He's used it once and threw up. He had to be towed back by a teenager in a kayak. Betty is taking notes quickly. Lola, who manages the household budget now? I do. I changed all the passwords after mom tried to invest in her psychic's nephew's food truck. What kind of food truck? Hot dog sushi, ma'am. Hot dogs wrapped in rice. And dad? Dad bought rental property in another state. He's never seen it. He's not even sure what state it's in. How is that possible? Betty asks. He was pretty sure it was Iowa or Idaho, one of the I states. Lola opens another section from the filing cabinet. This is their joint meal delivery subscription. They spend eight thousand dollars a month on fully catered dinners every night from a service that delivers restaurant meals. They have a 50 thousand dollar kitchen they've never used. The. The oven still has the manual inside. Cooking is Dangerous, both parents say together. Betty shakes her head. Lola, did you prepare all this yourself? Yes, ma'am. What do you think should happen with the money? Lola thinks carefully. They should each get a one hundred dollar weekly allowance. Manage the rest until college. Betty looks at the parents. Your daughter makes excellent points. I'm recommending she control the finances. Lola quietly celebrates. Finally, as we're packing up, I hear Lola tell her parents, I still love you both. You're just really bad at money. Like, historically bad. This kid's gonna run a big company someday.

I came back from work. I saw my six year old daughter standing outside, freezing in the snow. I slammed on the brakes and jumped out of my car. Nora, baby, what are you doing out here? She was shivering violently in just her school clothes, no coat. Tears frozen on her little cheeks. Daddy locked me out. He said, I can't come back until you get home from work. My heart dropped. It was nine PM on a Friday. Jonathan knew I always worked late on Fridays. This wasn't an accident. How long have you been out here? Since you left this morning, she whispered. I scooped her up, feeling how ice cold her little body was, and carried her toward our front door. It was locked. I used my key. Fury building with every step, I. I found Jonathan exactly where I expected. Sprawled on the couch in his boxers and T-shirt, controller in hand, playing call of duty. The heat was cranked up to 75 degrees. Empty beer cans littered the coffee table. Why was our daughter outside for 12 hours? I tried to keep my voice calm. He didn't even pause his game. She spilled grape juice on my new controller this morning, I told her. Actions have consequences. I stared at him in disbelief. She's 6 years old, Jonathan. She spilled juice accidentally and you left her outside to freeze? Maybe next time she'll be more careful around my stuff. That's when I noticed Nora's Pink backpack sitting by the front door. It was stuffed full, bulging at the seams. Her favorite stuffed bunny was sticking out the top. What's this? I pointed at the bag. Jonathan finally paused his game and turned to look at me. There was something cold in his eyes I'd never seen before. I've been doing a lot of thinking today. While she was outside, he said slowly. This whole family thing isn't working out for me. Nor is too much work, too expensive, too loud. And honestly, I never wanted kids in the first place. The room started spinning. What are you talking about? I'm talking about you taking her and leaving tonight. I already had the locks changed while you were at work. You just got lucky I hadn't switched them out yet. I felt like I was in a nightmare. You. You're abandoning your own daughter? Nora was still clinging to me, her wet clothes soaking through my work blazer. She was listening to every word, her big brown eyes darting between us. Here's the thing. Jonathan stood up, stretching like this was all perfectly normal. She's not really mine anyway. I mean, yeah, biologically, whatever. But I never signed up for this dad life. You can have her. The casual cruelty in his voice made me sick. This was the man I've been married to for eight years. The man who used to read Nora bedtime stories. Jonathan, she's your daughter. You can't just watch me. He picked up his phone. I already talked to my buddy Steven, who's a lawyer. Apparently, if I just voluntarily give up my parental rights, I don't have to pay child support either. Win, win. My hands started shaking, but not from fear. From rage. I pulled out my phone and speed dialled a number I'd hoped I'd never have to use. Hi, Christine, it's Caroline. Remember that emergency custody documentation we

Why do teenagers feel they can't tell their parents most things? When I was 14, my dad surprised me with a laptop for Christmas. I thought it was the coolest thing ever. Finally, I could do school projects, watch shows, and even start writing the little stories I loved. But right after handing it to me, he said, oh, I've installed parental software on it just so you're safe. I didn't think much of it at first. I wasn't doing anything bad anyway. I was googling how to survive algebra and binge watching old TV shows. My dad would casually check my browsing history every now and then, and honestly, it made me feel like he cared, like he wanted to protect me. But then, as high school went on, my world started to get heavier. I made friends who weren't the popular kids, but felt like my people. There was Sarah, who struggled with eating and hated how she looked. Jason, who was terrified of admitting he liked guys, and Lily, who was constantly caught between her parents screaming matches. We weren't reckless. We were just surviving. And the group chat we made became our lifeline. It was the only place we could be raw and real about everything. I remember one night after another anxiety spiral, I typed out, I feel like I'm drowning in school, and I don't know how to tell anyone. My friends responded instantly with love, advice, and stupid memes to make me Laugh. For once, I didn't feel broken. I felt understood. But one evening, I left my laptop open after finishing an essay. My dad went in to make sure it was running okay, and instead, he found our chat. He didn't skim it. He screenshotted page after page. I found out he spent hours reading through months of our conversations. Every confession, every event, every secret. The next day, he sat me down with this grave look on his face and said, I'm worried about your friends. Some of these things sound dangerous. And then, without asking me, he forwarded the screenshots to Lily's mom and even called Sarah's dad. By Monday, the fallout hit. Sarah showed up to school furious, saying her parents were now watching her every bite of food. Jason stopped replying to any of us because he thought someone would out him next. Lily. She wouldn't even look at me. Our group chat was dead. Within days. The safe place we built was gone. My dad told me he did the right thing, that he might have prevented something terrible. And maybe he did. But all I could feel was betrayal. Because he didn't just protect us. He exposed us. After that, I stopped sharing with him. When I cried myself to sleep because of panic attacks, I made sure he never heard. When I felt like I couldn't breathe in class, I pretended I was fine. He could check my laptop, my history, even My texts. But he'd never find the real me again. And that's the thing about teenagers. It's not that we don't want to tell our parents. It's that the moment we feel like we can't trust them with our truth, we learn to keep everything locked away. Even the parts that matter most.

What's the most redneck thing your family has done? My uncle owned a junkyard in Alabama that had been in our family for 60 years. Then a crypto billionaire bought the land next door and offered us $50,000 to shut down because we were destroying his Zen. Uncle Jim, a Vietnam vet just laughed. Son, I've survived worse than you. The billionaire called Code Enforcement Daily. They found nothing. So we hired a PR firm to tank our Google reviews. Uncle Jim's response, he legally registered the junkyard as a heavy metal concert venue and hosted death metal shows every Friday night. The billionaire built a giant LED wall with nature scenes. Uncle Jim parked 47 junk cars in formation. That spell called out K, a, R, E, N, visible from Google Earth. Next, the billionaire tried bribing our customers not to come. Uncle Jim launched Exotic Pet Fridays. People brought peacocks, miniature horses, even 30 emotional support chickens. Totally legal. The breaking point, when the billionaire's supermodel girlfriend visited, Uncle Jim tested the car crusher for eight hours straight. She left him that weekend. But Uncle Jim had one last card. The Billionaire's mansion was built on a flood plain. First Hurricane season, the whole first floor went under. He sold it at a 3 million dollar loss to a local contractor who turned it into low income housing. Now Uncle Jim host three BBQs for the new families every 4th of July. The billionaire last we heard, he's trying. To buy land in Montana. Good luck with that.

As a Powerpoint presentation printed on construction paper, the title page says, why Ava should date my brother Jake in glitter glue. Ava's trying not to laugh. Other students are starting to stare. Lily, no, please. We need to go home right now. But Lily's already flipping to page 2. First, Jake is very clean. He showers every day and brushes his teeth twice, sometimes three times. When he knows he's going to see you, Ava raises an eyebrow at me. I'm dying. Second, he's really good at video games. So if you ever need someone to beat a hard level, he can help. Page 3, he knows how to make really good grilled cheese sandwiches, and he always shares his snacks. I'm trying to grab the presentation, but Lily keeps dodging me. Oh, and this is the best part. She flips to a page that's just a drawing of me and Ava holding hands with hearts around us. He drew this picture of you guys together. Well, I drew it, but he told me what you look like. Ava is full on laughing now. He described me to you. Oh, yes. He said you have pretty hair and you're really smart and you smell like vanilla. I have never said she smells like vanilla, but apparently my sister has a creative imagination. Lily, we're leaving now, but Ava stops me. Wait, I wanna hear the rest of this presentation. This is the most thorough dating resume I've ever received. Lily beams and continues. Jake also writes your name on his notebook sometimes, but he scribbles it out when he thinks people are looking. This is true. And I'm mortified that my sister noticed. He practices asking you to dances in the mirror. I heard him through the bathroom door. Also true. I'm going to die. Ava is crying, laughing at this point. Lily, this is amazing. Did Jake know you were making this? No. It was supposed to be a surprise. I wanted to help because he talks about you all the time, but he too scared to tell you he likes you. The entire library is now watching this disaster unfold. Ava looks at me with this huge smile. Is all of this true? I'm bright red, but I figure I have nothing left to lose. Unfortunately, yes, all of it. She grinned. Well, for the record, I think you're pretty great too, and I'd love to go to homecoming with you. Lily jumps up and down. My presentation worked. I'm the best wing woman ever. Ava leans over and whispers, your sister is adorable, but next time maybe just ask me yourself. We've been dating for 3 months now. Lily takes full credit and introduces herself to Ava's friends as the reason they're together.

How did my dad's no cooking rule almost kill him at his own promotion dinner? My dad banned all cooking in our house after his chef brother humiliated him at Thanksgiving. And I mean all cooking. No stove, no microwave, nothing. He literally removed the power cord from our oven and took it to his office like some kind of kitchen dictate. When my uncle called Dad's attempt to make Turkey shoe leather, his face turned purple. He threw his apron on the floor and said our family would never cook again. Mom tried to reason with him, but he went full butthurt and spent three hours removing every cooking appliance from the kitchen. We were only allowed pre packaged, ready to eat foods. Cold cuts, protein bars, bagged salads with those little dressing packets. Even boiling water was forbidden because that counted as food preparation. For months, I watched my friends eat normal hot meals while I unwrapped another sad sandwich. Kids at school thought I was lying when I said we couldn't even make ramen. The embarrassment was pretty bad. I started getting these dizzy spells during basketball practice, and my legs would cramp up so bad, I'd have to sit out. That's when I realized this wasn't just about Dad's stupid pride. This diet was literally making me sick. I went to the library after school and started researching nutrition. Turns out I discovered my exact symptoms matched severe magnesium deficiency, which made perfect sense. Since processed foods have basically zero magnesium. So I started my own secret operation using lawn mowing money to buy supplements. Within two weeks of taking them, my cramps disappeared, and I could actually finish practice again. I became obsessed with reading ingredient labels, memorizing which preservatives were in everything we ate, because I needed to know what was poisoning me. Slowly, I turned into this weird ingredient encyclopedia. Yeah, knowing every chemical in our entire kitchen, because survival literally depended on it. Then came the dinner that changed everything. Dad's boss was coming over. And this wasn't just any dinner. Dad's entire promotion depended on impressing this man. Plus, if he got the job, he'd travel three weeks out of the month, and I could finally go back to cooking normal, hot food. Dad spent hours arranging fancy the sad cold cuts on our good China, explaining his efficient eating philosophy, while Mr. Keller man looked increasingly uncomfortable. Mom just sat there, silent, dying inside, watching dad serve lunch meat for the most important dinner of

I called the police on my husband. So I'm in medical school, right, cramming for my biggest exam of the semester. Been studying for like a month straight, barely sleeping. My husband Jake's car has been dead in our garage for 3 months now. Every month him and his buddies do this road trip thing. And this time it was his turn to drive. He kept bugging me about taking my car. I told him no way because I have this weak immune system and can't risk getting sick on public transport, especially right before exams. We went back and forth for days. He was all stressed saying his friends would think he ruined their tradition. The morning of my exam, I left at 8:00am sharp. Had to stop at this coffee shop first because our internet at home sucks and I needed to print something. Got to campus around 8:30, went straight to the exam hall. Three hour exam. Felt like I bombed it, but whatever. Afterwards, I hung out with my study group for maybe 20 minutes, then headed to the parking lot. My car wasn't there, just an empty space where I left it. I'm standing there looking around like an idiot thinking maybe I parked somewhere else. But no, I always park in the same spot. My friend Emma was like, dude, your car got stolen. And my stomach just dropped. Called Jake, but it went straight to voicemail. Called again, still nothing Emma. And this Other girl convinced me to call the cops because what else was I supposed to do? The officer who showed up was this older guy, looked like he'd seen everything. He asked me all these questions. When did I last see the car? Did I lock it? Any enemies, that kind of stuff. Then he said I needed to come to the station to file a proper report. So there I am sitting in the sterile police station for four hours filling out paperwork and answering the same questions over and over. My phone's dying. I'm exhausted from the exam and I'm thinking about how I'm gonna afford a new car on a student budget. Around two PM, the same officer comes back with this weird look on his face. He's like, we found your vehicle. I'm thinking, great, some joy riders dumped it somewhere. But then he goes, your husband was driving it. We picked him up about 60 miles out of town. I swear my brain stopped working for a second. Like, what, Jake? I, Jake took my car. The officer explained they pulled him over for speeding and when they ran the plates, it came back as stolen. Jake apparently tried to explain, but they didn't buy it until they called me. I drove to the station to get him in the car. He was sitting in this waiting area looking all defeated, still wearing his stupid road trip T-shirt. His friends were there, too, looking embarrassed. As hell. When Jake saw me, he couldn't even make eye contact, didn't talk the whole drive home. Soon as we got in the house, he exploded, started yelling about how I embarrassed him in front of his friends, how I should have known he took the car, how calling the police was way too much. That's when he admitted he made a copy of my key weeks ago, said he watched me leave for my exam through the window, waited 10 minutes then and took the car. He was gonna text me but forgot because he was having so much fun with his boys. I lost it. Told him he stole my car, literally stole it, made me think I was going crazy in that parking lot, made me sit in a police station for 4 hours thinking my life was falling apart. And his response, it's not that serious. I was gonna bring it back.

My fiance said her ex was just a friend and I was being insecure, so I invited him to family dinner. My fiance Rebecca really picked the worst time to call me paranoid about her ex, Nate. We were literally sitting there tasting wedding cakes when she brought it up. She kept insisting they were just friends now and I was being controlling. The thing was, I'd come home early from a work trip last week and saw his car leaving our apartment complex at 2 a m. She had no idea I'd seen it. Every time his name popped up on her phone, she'd flip it face down real quick. When she called me insecure again, I decided to call her bluff. You're right. I'm being unfair. Let's invite Nate to your parents anniversary dinner next week, I said. I watched all the color drain from her face. She tried to backtrack, saying her family wouldn't want extra guests their special dinner, but I pushed harder. I'll call him myself to show I trust you. She was trapped, and we both knew it. She agreed, but her hands were literally shaking. That night. I called Nate and made sure to put him on speaker so Rebecca could hear everything. I told him I wanted to apologize for being the jealous boyfriend and invited him to the family dinner. Rebecca just sat there watching me, completely stuck. Tried to turn me down, said it wasn't a good idea. But I Kept pushing, telling him Rebecca really wanted him there. I even offered to pick him up myself, you know, to show there were no hard feelings. When I picked him up that night, the guy was sweating through his dress shirt. During the drive, he mentioned Rebecca's parents hated him, but wouldn't tell me why. We walked into that dinner together, and I swear, the whole room just froze. Rebecca's mom dropped her wine glass, and it shattered all over the floor. Her dad's face went from normal to purple in about two seconds. What is he doing here? He practically growled. I played innocent and explained I'd invited Rebecca's friend to make peace. Her sister actually laughed out loud.

My wife insisted her work husband be her plus one at weddings because he knows all her work friends. So I became everyone's plus one. My wife Angela walked into the living room holding two wedding invitations while I was watching TV. I need to bring grant to these weddings, she said. Grant was her twenty year old assistant at work. Why grant? I asked, genuinely confused. My whole department will be there if I bring you. Everyone gossips about me playing favorites with him since I'm his boss, but if we go together as co workers, it looks better. She said it like she'd been practicing this speech. Plus, my annual review is next month. My boss will be at both weddings watching everything. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. You're taking grant as your date instead of your husband? It's for my promotion. She waved the invitations at me. You hate weddings anyway. You always complain about the small talk. That was true, but this felt wrong. Fine, I said. Take Grant. Angela smiled like she'd won the lottery. I knew you'd be logical about this. First wedding came around and Angela spent two hours getting ready, trying on three different dresses before leaving with grant at noon. I was sitting on the couch feeling pretty weird about the whole thing, when my phone rang at 2. It was Ryan from my gym. Hey man, you coming to my wedding today? I nearly dropped my phone. Your Wedding is today? Yeah. Didn't Angela tell you? She works with my dad. You're on the list. I looked at the invitation stuck on our fridge, and my heart started racing. She said she was bringing someone else. I told him. So what? I invited you separately. We play basketball three times a week. An hour later, I walked into that wedding feeling like I was about to cause chaos. Angela's face went completely white when she spotted me at the bar, and I'm not gonna lie, it felt pretty good. She basically sprinted over with grant trailing behind, looking confused. What are you doing here? Ryan invited me from basketball. You didn't tell me Ryan was getting married. You didn't ask whose wedding it was. Her boss appeared beside.

What's the dumbest decision your boyfriend ever made? My boyfriend Avery told me I was at his apartment too much and needed to give him space, so I stopped going over except for planned date nights twice a week. What he didn't realize was that my constant presence meant I was naturally tidying up while we watched movies, buying groceries when I noticed the fridge was empty, and taking out trash bags that were piling up because I couldn't stand the smell while I was trying to study on his couch. Within three days, his roommate Bart texted me asking if Avery was okay because there were fruit flies swarming the kitchen and something died in the sink. I told him Avery wanted space, and Bart just sent back 17 question marks followed by a photo of their bathroom that looked like a biohazard site with what appeared to be sentient mold growing on towels that had and wet for so long, they'd formed their own ecosystem. Avery's other roommate, Chris, started a group chat without Avery called Eviction Planning Committee and added me to explain the situation. Apparently, Avery had been leaving plates of food under his bed that were attracting roaches, and not the normal kind, but those massive ones that fly directly at your face when threatened. Chris sent a video of him opening Avery's door and literally dozens of roaches scattering while he screamed so loud, the neighbors called campus security, thinking someone was being murdered. The smell from Avery's room started seeping through the walls, and Bart discovered Avery had been throwing dirty clothes behind his dresser instead of doing laundry for two months straight. The pile had gotten so high it was pressing against the heating vent and creating what Bart described as biological warfare through the ventilation system. That probably violates the Geneva Convention. They had to wear masks just to walk past his door, and one of their friends refused to come over after throwing up in their hallway from the stench. I suggested to Avery that maybe I could come over more often again, but he said he was enjoying his independence and finally feeling like his own person. You are making me codependent, and I need to learn to adult on my own, he explained, while I could literally see a pizza box moving in the background of our video call from whatever was living inside it. Chris discovered Avery had been pouring old milk down the bathroom sink instead of the kitchen because he was too lazy to walk the extra 10 feet.

What made your teacher give up on a stupid rule? My teacher, Mister Ramsey, stopped his lecture and stared at me. Is that G U M? Everyone held their breath as he marched over to me. Are you eating in my class? Um, it's just chewing gum, sir. Just gum. He took the packet from me and stuffed it into his pocket. If you're going to eat in class, you must bring enough for everyone to share. We are all about Equality here. Now, please spit out the gum you have into the trash can so we may continue our wonderful lecture on the great industrial revolution. The whole class laughed because everyone knows that line. It's what teachers say when they want you to stop eating. It always works. Because nobody was insane enough to actually bring enough to share. So of course, I had to do it. The next day, I showed up with a giant box of chewing gum. 30 packs of Trident Spearmint. Before Mister Ramsey arrived, I placed a pack on each desk, while each person grinned at me with the same oh, you crazy ogre kind of look. When he walked in, all 30 of us were chewing gum, smacking annoyingly all at once. What's going on, sir? You said we could eat in class if I brought enough to share, so I'm sharing. This isn't what I meant. But it's what you said. He couldn't argue with that. And with that, the entire Class became inspired to use the rule to their advantage. My. My classmate Rosemary, whose dad had a food truck, brought in 30 tiny burgers. The smell filled the room, and I swear I heard Mister Ramsey's stomach grumble, no! No burgers, no sandwiches. This is a place of learning. Since we weren't allowed finger food anymore, Benedict brought his mom's rice cooker and thirty pieces of fried chicken legs, all packed in rectangular containers. The smell made students from other classes peek through the door window. Mr. Ramsey looked annoyed. This has gone on long enough. Do not bring any more food.
NA
NA
NA

The new babysitter asked me, your parents never come home early, right? I told her they usually stayed out until midnight on their anniversary. And she asked if they ever came home early to check on me, which no babysitter had ever asked before. I said, no, never. And she typed something into her phone with this satisfied look on her face. My regular babysitter had gotten sick that morning, so my parents found this girl, Tara, through some neighborhood app who looked normal enough when she showed up wearing ripped jeans and carrying a purple backpack that seemed weirdly heavy when she set it by the door. She kept checking her phone while making me dinner. And when I asked if she was texting her boyfriend, she laughed and said something about how her boyfriend was actually working tonight, which didn't really answer my question. But adults are weird like that sometimes. After dinner, she suggested I play video games with the volume up because she had to make some important calls for her college classes and didn't want to bother me, which should have been my first warning sign. While I played my game, she paced around the living room having a conversation that definitely wasn't about college, unless her professor wanted to know about window locks and whether we had a security system and what time the neighbors usually went to bed. She disappeared upstairs for a while, and I figured she was using the bathroom, but Then I heard footsteps above me in my parents room where nobody was supposed to go. And when she came back down, she had this overly satisfied look on her face. Around 9:30, she stood by the front window texting frantically. And every few seconds she'd peek through the curtains at the street like she was waiting for pizza delivery, except we'd already eaten. Then she turned to me with this fake sweet smile and asked if I wanted to learn a fun new game where I had to stay in the basement for 20 minutes without making any sound, and if I won, she'd give me $20. I pretended to think about it, but my stomach was doing that twisty thing it does when something bad is about to happen. So I said I needed to use the bathroom first and ran upstairs instead. My parents bedroom door was wide open. Their closet light was on. And when I looked inside, I saw she'd moved things around and pulled out my dad's safe from behind his suits and left it sitting on the bed with some kind of electronic device attached to it that was making quiet beeping sounds. There were photos spread out on my mom's dresser that I've never seen before, showing our family at restaurants and parks and even one of me walking home from school, which meant someone had been watching us for who knows how long. I heard footsteps coming up the stairs fast. Barely managed to duck into the hallway closet before she rushed past, muttering something about timing being critical and how they needed to stick to the plan, whatever that meant. Through the crack under the closet door, I watched her feet stop right outside and heard her whisper, listen, you psychopath, I don't care what he promised you. If you hurt that kid, the deal is off and I'm calling the whole thing right now. Whatever she heard next and all the confidence from her voice and she answered, fine, but you get 15 minutes max and then we're gone before the parents suspect anything. She walked back toward the stairs and I realized with this cold, crushing feeling that she wasn't just robbing us, but that someone else was coming and that person wanted to do something to me. And the only reason they hadn't already was because she was apparently the reasonable one in whatever sick plan this was. I waited until I heard her go back downstairs, then crawled to my room on my hands and knees to get my phone from under my pillow where I always hit it during dinner. My fingers were shaking so hard I could barely dial 9, 1 1. But somehow I managed to whisper that someone was in my house and more people were coming. And the operator kept asking questions, but all I could get out with.

What's the most satisfying way you've exposed your parents favouritism? My mom clinked her fork against her glass and stood up. Before we sing Happy Birthday to my daughter, I want everyone to know we're also celebrating Moira's half birthday today. My 16 year old sister Moira bounced up from her chair and rushed to stand behind my birthday cake, giggling. Another birthday stolen right in front of me. It's my 18th birthday, I said. Can I have just this one birthday for myself? Mom stared daggers at me. Don't be selfish. Birthdays are meant for sharing and we do this every year. Dad added. Why are you suddenly making it a problem? But that was exactly the problem. Every year I had to deal with my parents putting Moira first. And sure, it was cute back when Moira was three and I was five. I mean, who wouldn't say all when you're top toddler sister helps blow out your candles for the first time. But that was the thing. We were kids. But that cute incident didn't stop there. During Christmas, my parents let her tear open her gifts first before turning around and opening mine too. You're too old to be excited with opening presents anyway, mom said. I was 8. My 10th birthday dinner was at Chuck E. Cheese instead of the Japanese restaurant I wanted. All because Moira threw a tantrum about wanting pizza. My 12th birthday got canceled when Moira woke up with a really Bad tummy ache which happened to suddenly disappear an hour after telling everyone to show up. And on my 16th birthday, my parents forgot all about it. So this year was really it. I was an adult and didn't have to put up with their crap any longer. I looked down at my birthday cake with Moira's name written beautifully and mine squeezed into the bottom corner in sloppy letters, completely misspelled, and just lost it. Happy birthday to you! Happy birthday, dear! I blew out the candles right there. Every single one. Before Moira could make her move, the singing instantly fell apart. Every person in the room went completely silent. What the heck? Moira shrieked. Why did you blow out my cake? Our cake! I said with a smile. I grabbed the presents my parents neatly wrapped on the side for my sister and ripped open the first box. AirPods! Wow! I've been asking for this for four years! Those are Moira's half birthday presents. Mom stood up so fast her chair scraped against the floor. Exactly! I can't wait to share it. I opened another box. Ooh, a Lululemon gift card! Thanks so much! I carefully opened the rest of my gifts, making snarky comments like, oh, Moira, this isn't the color Moira likes. Guess I'll just keep it for myself. You don't mind, right, Moira? All the guests stared at her. Moira started crying, real tears streaming down her face. She's ruining everything! Make her stop! This is what we always do, I said, staying perfectly calm. I don't understand why you're upset. Dad's face turned red. You're going too far. This is cruel. Too far? I looked at him. This. This is exactly what happens at every birthday of mine. The only difference is I'm not allowed to cry about it. Mom's voice cracked, horrified by the sudden public exposure. You're older. You should know better. So when I was five and she was three, I should have known better? You're ruining her special moment, dad said, grabbing the AirPods out of my hands. Her special moment. I burst out into laughter, pointing to the cake. This is my birthday. Moira's is quite literally four months away. Funny how all this sharing stuff only applies when it's my birthday. I mean, go ahead. Name one time Moira had to share her party. Nothing. Complete silence. Yeah, that's what I thought. Last year, her sweet 16 had a professional photographer.

Awkward favor someone has ever called in. My phone buzzed at 2:00am with a text that made me sit straight up in bed. Remember that favor you owe me? I need you to be my boyfriend at my sister's wedding this Saturday. Pick me up at four PM wear navy. It was from Poppy, the girl who saved my entire college career three years ago. I hadn't spoken to her since graduation when I drunkenly promised her anything, anytime after she spent an entire semester tutoring me through chemistry for without her, I would have lost my scholarship and dropped out. Now she was calling in that favor and honestly, being someone's fake boyfriend for a day seemed like a small price to pay. Plus, if I was being honest with myself, I'd always wondered what it would have been like to actually date her. When I picked her up that Saturday, Poppy answered the door looking absolutely stunning in an emerald dress that made her green eyes even brighter. But her expression was all business. She handed me a typed sheet of paper titled Our Relationship Details with bullet points about our first date, how long we've been together and my supposed favorite things about her. Eight months, she said, adjusting my tie without making eye contact. We've been dating eight months. You call me pop sometimes. We met at a coffee shop. Her voice was mechanical like she was reading a grocery list. During the drive, she explained The situation, my parents keep trying to set me up with their business partner son at every family event. He's perfectly nice, but I'm just not interested. This will shut them up for a while. The whole ride, she was silent. Then when we arrived at the venue, she took a deep breath, grabbed my hand and suddenly transformed into a completely different person. Ready, babe, she said with a bright smile that didn't quite reach her eyes. The ceremony was beautiful. I caught Poppy wiping her eyes during the vows and without thinking, I handed her my pocket square. She looked surprised but took it, whispering thanks so quietly I almost miss it. During the reception, I found myself forgetting this was an act. Her uncle made a toast. I instinctively put my arm around her shoulders. When the music was too loud to hear her cousin's story, I leaned down so she could whisper it in my ear, her breath warm against my neck. Her grandmother cornered us by the dessert table, pinching my cheeks and telling Poppy in a stage whisper, this one's much better than Adrian. Poppy went rigid at the name, but I squeezed her hand and smoothly changed the subject to Grandma's famous apple pie recipe. Couple's dance was when everything shifted. Poppy was stiff in my arms, counting steps under her breath like she was solving an equation. Hey, I whispered, pulling her closer. Just follow me. Stop thinking so hard. She looked Up at me and for a moment, her guard completely dropped. She melted into me, her head finding that perfect spot against my shoulder. We swayed together as the song played and I found myself hoping it would never end. Then during the bouquet toss, she caught it by accident when it bounced off another girl's hands. The crowd cheered, but Poppy immediately handed it to the girl beside her, laughing it off. Just superstition anyway, she said. But I noticed her looking at the flowers longingly as the other girl walked away. Her sister pulled me aside while Poppy was in the bathroom. Thank you, she said, squeezing my arm for making her happy, even if it's just for tonight. The words stuck with me. As the night wound down, I realized I wasn't acting anymore. When I looked at her laughing with her cousins, I felt a pull in my chest that had nothing to do with owing her a favor, driving her home. I couldn't keep it in anymore. Poppy, I know this was just repaying a debt, but tonight felt real to me, really real. She went completely still in the passenger seat when I pulled up to her apartment. She practically jumped out of the car. You did great. Perfect. Fake boyfriend. We're even now. The words came out rushed and cold. She was already at her building's door before I could respond. I sat there for 5 minutes feeling like an idiot before driving. Home. The next morning, Poppy's sister texted me. You left your.

What's the kindest thing you've ever done that was met with cruelty? I was always the second choice in my family. My older sister Maya was everything I wasn't. Prom queen, valedictorian, mom and Dad's little angel who could do no wrong. She got designer clothes and a car for her 16th birthday. I got hand me downs and a lecture about being grateful. But I never held it against her. That's just how things were. When Maya turned 25, she got really sick, kidney failure. The doctor said she needed a transplant fast or she wasn't gonna make it. Without even thinking, I volunteered to get tested. I mean, she's my sister, right? Blood is thicker than water and all that. Turns out I was a perfect match, like scary perfect. The doctors kept saying how rare it was, how lucky Maya was to have a sister like me. I didn't feel lucky. I felt terrified. But Maya was lying in that hospital bed looking so small and pale and my parents were crying every single day. So I did it. I gave her my kidney. The surgery was rough, way rougher than anyone told me it would be. I spent two weeks feeling like I got hit by a truck while Maya bounced back like nothing happened. But seeing her smile again, seeing my parents stop crying, it felt worth it. For a few months, I was the golden child. Mom would brag to everyone about how brave I was how I saved Maya's life. Dad actually hugged me for the first time in years. Maya kept saying she owed me everything. I thought maybe things would be different now. But then life went back to normal. Maya got her job back, started dating this rich guy from her college, and suddenly I was invisible again. When she graduated with her master's degree, they threw her this huge party. When I graduated nursing school the same year, they sent a card. Last month, I overheard them planning a family trip to Greece. Maya was talking about some resort she'd seen on Instagram and mom was looking up flights. I got excited thinking about our first real family vacation in years. Then Maya said something that made my blood freeze. Just the three of us, though, right? Like Lena doesn't need to come. She's always been more of a homebody anyway. Mom laughed and agreed. Dad just grunted like he always does when he doesn't want to deal with conflict. We were planning to spend $10,000 on a trip and didn't even consider inviting me, the girl who literally gave up a piece of herself to save their precious daughter. I confronted them the next day. Mom got all defensive, saying I was being dramatic. It's nothing personal, honey. We just need some bonding time. Maya's been through so much. I wanted to scream that I've been through stuff, too. But I just swallowed it like I always do. They left for Greece last week. I saw the pictures on Maya's Instagram, fancy dinners, beach photos, the three of them looking like the perfect happy family. But then something weird happened. My doctor called saying he'd gotten a request for my.

What is an example of a dirty trick that a thief tried but backfired when they saw your dog? My house is pretty basic, but I got this massive Rottweiler named bear on my front porch. Thing is, people always think he's fake, like a statue or something. Bears, 10 years old and has really bad arthritis. During the day, he literally doesn't move. He'll sit in the exact same spot for like six hours straight. Delivery guys walk right past him. Kids pet him thinking he's some decoration. My neighbor Jake even tried to move him once because he thought I bought some weird lawn ornament. About three weeks ago, this sketchy dude in a hoodie started walking by my house every night around 11. He'd slow down and stare at my windows. I noticed because I work night shifts and I'd see him from my bedroom. He'd count my cars, check if lights were on, the whole deal. What this idiot didn't know was that I used to visit my mom every weekend. We live two hours away and I'd leave Friday night, come back Sunday. But last month, she moved into this care facility nearby. So now I'm home every weekend. Friday night comes around and I'm upstairs watching Netflix when I hear this scraping sound like metal on metal. I mute my laptop and listen. Nothing. Then more scraping. Peek out my window and see this guy with a crowbar trying to Jimmy open my kitchen. Window. He's wearing gloves and everything. Real professional. Bear sitting on the porch like always, completely still. The guy walks right past him twice. So this moron gets the window open and climbs inside. I can hear him downstairs moving around with a flashlight. He's being quiet, but not that quiet. I grab my phone and start recording everything. Spends like 10 minutes in my living room probably looking for my laptop and stuff. Then I hear him in the hallway where I keep my coin collection. My grandfather left me these old silver dollars worth probably five grand. The guys picking the lock on my cabinet can hear the clicks. Bear must have heard it too, because suddenly I see the shadow moving on the porch slowly, like really slowly. Bear stands up, joints cracking, loud enough that I can hear it upstairs. But the thief doesn't notice because he's focused on the lock. Finally gets it open. I hear him whisper Jackpot or something like that. That's when bear moves. He gets up and walks inside through the back door that I always leave cracked open for him. His nails are clicking on the kitchen.
NA

Police officers. What criminal actually impressed you with their criminal skills? Working night patrol in Seattle, I kept getting calls about a woman stealing from rich people's homes. But this wasn't your typical burglar. She only took one item from each house. Always something the owners didn't even notice was missing for weeks. The really weird part? She'd leave behind expensive jewelry and electronics, taking things like old photo albums or baby blankets instead. It drove me crazy trying to figure out her pattern. And one night, we got lucky. A security camera caught her face as she walked out of a mansion carrying what looks like a teddy bear. When I saw the footage, my coffee nearly fell out of my hand. The thief was Andrea Walsh, one of our city's most respected foster care social workers. I'd met her several times at charity events. She was this quiet woman in her 50s who fostered over 30 kids herself. Everyone knew her as the angel who took in the hardest cases, the kids nobody else would touch. We brought her in for questioning at 3 a m. She sat across from me in the interrogation room, still wearing her cardigan and sensible shoes, looking more like someone's grandmother than a criminal mastermind. Wanna tell me about the bear? I asked. She smiled sadly. That bear belonged to Tommy Jenkins. He 6, now living with his fifth foster family. His birth mom promised to give it back when she got Clean. But she sold it instead. My partner pulled up Tommy's file. Sure enough, there was a note about a missing teddy bear he'd cry about every night. The photo album from the Martinez house, I asked. That belonged to Rosa, didn't it? The teenager who aged out of the system last year. Andrea nodded. Her birth father sold everything when he went to prison. That album had the only pictures of her mother. One by one, we went through every item she'd stolen. Each one belonged to a foster kid she'd worked with, sold off by birth parents for drug money or lost in the shuffle between homes. She'd spent months tracking down these items, studying security systems and planning her break ins. She knew exactly when each family would be away, which windows would be unlocked, where every motion sensor was placed. I tried doing it legally at first, she explained, offering to buy the items back. But most of these families wouldn't even talk to me. So I found another way. She pulled out a worn notebook filled with addresses, schedules, and detailed maps of wealthy neighborhoods. I've got 43 more items to find. Kids shouldn't have to lose their memories just because the system failed them. I looked at my partner. We both knew what we had to do. The evidence against her. With solid security footage, documented break ins, even her own confession, she'd serve serious time. But then I thought about Tommy getting his Bear back. Rosa seeing pictures of her mom again? I accidentally knocked my coffee all over her notebook. Oops. Looks like your list of targets is ruined. Guess we'll never know where you were planning to hit next. My partner caught on quick. Shame about that security footage, too. System must have glitched. It's all corrupted now. We let her go with a warning. Every few months after that, I'd hear about another missing teddy bear or baby blanket. But somehow the security cameras always seem to malfunction on those nights. Last week, I ran into Andrea at the grocery store. She smiled and handed me a small package. Inside was a baseball mitt with my name scratched into the leather. The same one my dad sold for drugs when I was 8. Found this at a pawn shop in Portland, she whispered. Figured you might want it back. I still keep that mitt on my desk.

You realize you weren't raised right. My son came into my room fully dressed for school and just stood there in the doorway like he was waiting to be punished. I asked what was wrong and he said, can I stay home today? I feel really sad. I don't know why. I just don't wanna go. At first I almost gave him the response I was raised on. Life doesn't stop just because you're in a mood. But the way he said it, it didn't sound like a kid trying to skip class. It sounded like a kid trying not to cry from something much worse. I told him to go sit down while I got ready, then walked into the bathroom and locked the door. I needed a second to breathe because something about it hit too hard. Not the sadness, the fact that he asked. As a kid, I was taught to hide feelings like that, to bury them deep, never speak them out loud, and especially never expect kindness afterward. So I took a breath, came out and told him, alright, you're staying home, but you're not in trouble. And I'm not mad. He kept looking at me like he was waiting for the butt. There wasn't one. We spent the day doing nothing worth posting about. We didn't talk about why he felt sad. I didn't try to fix it. I just let him exist. We made lunch, watched something stupid, and sat on the couch. Like the world wasn't pressing down on either of us. At one point, he looked over and asked, do you ever feel sad for no reason? I nodded more times than I can count. He didn't say anything else, just leaned against me and closed his eyes. That night, while he brushed his teeth, he looked at me in the mirror and said, I thought you'd be mad. Last time I cried, you told me to act my age. I. I didn't even remember saying that, but apparently he did. After he went to bed, I stayed up cleaning the living room. I found his backpack under the blanket he had curled up in, and when I unzipped it to pull out his lunch box, I saw a folded sheet of paper tucked between two math work sheets. It wasn't a school assignment. It was a note written in pencil, erased and rewritten more than once. It said, I don't want to feel this way anymore, but if I tell someone, they'll make me feel worse for not wanting to be alive.

I didn't go out to eat to celebrate my brother's wedding when I wasn't even invited to his wedding. So my brother Jake got married, like, three weeks ago, and the whole thing was basically a slap in the face. His wife Megan, decided nobody under 21 could come because they were serving alcohol and didn't want any minors getting drunk. I was 19 at the time, which apparently made me some kind of liability. The excuse was complete bullshit, and everyone knew it. I don't even drink that much. Maybe a beer here and there with friends, but I'm not some alcoholic teenager who's gonna embarrass their precious wedding. But whatever. That's what they decided, and my parents just went along with it, like always. I asked them to reconsider a few times because, honestly, it hurt. Jake and I used to be close growing up. We shared a room until I was 14, played video games together, the whole thing. But ever since he started dating Megan two years ago, she's basically been calling all the shots. She thinks she's better than everyone because her dad owns some car dealership and she went to private school. After they kept saying no, I just stopped caring. If I wasn't good enough for their wedding, then fine. I wasn't gonna beg anymore. Then last Saturday rolls around, and Jake texts our family group chat saying he wants everyone to go to some fancy steakhouse to celebrate the wedding. My parents Were all excited, talking about how nice it would be to finally celebrate as a family, but I just replied that I wasn't going. My mom called me right away asking why not? I told her the same thing I told everyone else. I didn't see the point in celebrating something I wasn't even invited to. She tried to guilt trip me, saying it would mean a lot to Jake and that my cousins Becca and Tyler were going even though they didn't get invited either. But here's the thing. Becca is 13 and Tyler is 15. Their parents literally forced them to go. They didn't have a choice. I'm 19, I pay my own phone Bill, I work at Best Buy part time, and I'm starting community college in the fall. I can make my own decisions about where I spend my Saturday night. My parents kept trying to convince me all week. My dad even offered to pay for my meal, which honestly just made it worse. Like, you couldn't fight for me to be at the actual wedding, but now you wanna throw money at me to show up to the Celebration dinner? The night of the dinner, I. I stayed home and ordered pizza. I was playing call of duty with my friends when my phone started blowing up. First it was Jake texting me asking where I was. Then Megan sent me this long paragraph about how disappointed she was that I couldn't be mature enough. To support my brother's happiness. Funniest part is they acted all surprised that I didn't show up. I literally told them I wasn't going. What did they expect? After they got home from dinner, Jake came to my room and tried to have some.

People who have ordered a bar's safe word drink to get out of a bad situation. What was your date like, and how did the staff help? I'd never used a dating app before, but my friends kept pushing me to try it. Finally downloaded one and matched with this guy. Jason, software engineer. Had a golden retriever named Max. Said he loved hiking. We talked for three weeks straight. He sent voice messages, selfies, even videos of him making coffee in the morning. Seemed normal enough. We agreed to meet at this trendy bar downtown called Murphy's. I'd been there once with co workers. Got there at 7 sharp wearing this blue dress I'd bought specifically for the date. Jason was already at a table in the corner. He looked similar to his photos, but something felt off immediately. No glasses like in his pictures. His voice sounded different too. Deeper than the voice messages. Maybe I was just nervous. He stood up and hugged me like we'd known each other forever. Started talking about things. I swear I'd never told him. How my apartment had hardwood floors, how I always put extra sugar in my coffee. Stuff that felt way too specific. I brushed it off, thinking maybe I'd mentioned it and forgot. Then he ordered for both of us without asking. 2 whiskey sours. I hate whiskey. I'd literally told him in our text that I only drink wine or beer. When I mentioned it, he laughed. And said he remembered me saying whiskey was my favorite. The bartender brought our drinks, and Jason immediately started asking about my job. Normal first date stuff. But then he mentioned my boss, Rebecca, by name. I'd never told him my boss's name. Ever. I excused myself to use the bathroom and checked our text messages. Nowhere did I mention Rebecca. My heart started racing. When I came back, he was scrolling through his phone. He looked up and grinned. Said he loved the photos I'd sent him of my childhood bedroom. This stuffed elephant on my dresser was adorable. I froze. I never sent him photos of my room. Never even mentioned a stuffed elephant. That elephant had been sitting on my dresser since I was 7. Nobody knew about it except my family. That's when it hit me. This wasn't the Jason I've been texting. Someone had either hacked his account or been impersonating him the whole time. Worse, they'd somehow been watching me, following me, taking photos of my apartment. Jason caught me staring, and his smile got wider. Ask if I was thinking about ditching already. His tone was too calm, too knowing. I forced a laugh. Said I was just checking the drink menu. My friend Emma had told me about this bar's safety system once. You could order some special drink name, and they'd help you get out. But I couldn't remember what it was called. I excused myself again and walked to the Bar! The bartender

I said no to my girlfriend's tradition. I lost my younger brother to cancer when I was 22. Ever since, I've created a personal tradition to honor him. On the anniversary of his passing, I take the day off work, visit his grave, donate blood as he needed many transfusions during his treatment, and then come home to watch his favorite movie. It's simple, but deeply meaningful to me. My girlfriend of nine months, Anna, asked me to join her and her mom for lunch yesterday. Her mom visits often, so this wasn't a meet the parents situation. I reminded her about my tradition and said I wouldn't be able to make it, got upset and said, well, it's my tradition to have lunch with my mom every time she's in town, and she really wanted to see you. You can do your stupid blood donation tradition any day. I was taken aback, but calmly explained it wasn't just about the blood donation. It was an entire day I set aside to remember my brother. Later that evening, while I was watching my brother's favorite movie, Anna texted again asking me to join them. I reiterated that I couldn't and said I'd gladly hang out with her mom another time. She responded that I'd embarrassed her in front of her mom and accused me of being selfish and lazy. Since then, she's been distant and giving me the cold shoulder. I can't help but feel frustrated because this tradition is One of the few ways I've found to cope with my loss. I've always been supportive of her relationship with her mom, so her reaction caught me off guard.

What's the pettiest rule your school ever tried to enforce? My school installed 5 minute bathroom timers because they thought kids were vaping in there. I'm Ella and I was a junior when our principal announced this genius plan. Every bathroom stall got these little digital timers that started counting down the second you lock the door. 5 minutes and 1 second, boom. Automatic email to your parents and the principal saying you were misusing school facilities. He claimed it was about vaping, but honestly, half the girls in my grade have stomach problems or heavy periods. Imagine trying to explain to your mom why you got flagged for taking 6 minutes to change a pad. Pure humiliation. The first week was chaos. Kids were literally running out of bathrooms with their pants half up because they heard the timer beeping. My friend Jessica got detention because she had food poisoning and couldn't finish in time. The email to her parents said she was loitering with intent to engage in prohibited activities. Her mom thought she was doing drugs. That's when I decided this was war. I grabbed my old walkie talkie from when I was obsessed with spy movies and called up my friends Maya and Zoe. We met at lunch and I laid out the plan. Bathroom relay team. I explained drawing diagrams on a napkin. One person goes in, starts the timer, hands off the walkie at 4 minutes 30 seconds. Next person walks in and takes Over timer resets. Bathroom never gets empty. Nobody goes over five minutes. Maya thought I was insane. Zoe was immediately in. We started small, just the three of us rotating through the second floor girls bathroom. During lunch, I made us a little notebook titled Bathroom Attendance Team, Clean cheeks. We logged every shift change. We felt like secret agents. Day 1 worked perfectly. Day 2, the sophomore named Brianna noticed us whispering by the bathroom door and asked what was up. I figured, what the hell and explained the plan. She was so excited she literally clapped. By day 3, we had seven girls. By the end of the week, it was like 20 kids rotating through bathroom duty. Kids were doing homework by the sinks during their shifts. This freshman named Tyler brought a camping chair and set up a whole study station by the.

Police officers. What criminal actually impressed you with their criminal skills? Working night patrol in Seattle, I kept getting calls about a woman stealing from rich people's homes. But this wasn't your typical burglar. She only took one item from each house. Always something the owners didn't even notice was missing for weeks. The really weird part? She'd leave behind expensive jewelry and electronics, taking things like old photo albums or baby blankets instead. It drove me crazy trying to figure out her pattern. Then one night, we got lucky. A security camera caught her face as she walked out of a mansion carrying what looks like a teddy bear. When I saw the footage, my coffee nearly fell out of my hand. The thief was Andrea Walsh, one of our city's most respected foster care social workers. I'd met her several times at charity events. She was this quiet woman in her 50s who'd fostered over 30 kids herself. Everyone knew her as the angel who took in the hardest cases, the kids nobody else would touch. We brought her in for questioning at 3 a m. She sat across from me in the interrogation room, still wearing her cardigan and sensible shoes, looking more like someone's grandmother than a criminal mastermind. Wanna tell me about the bear? I asked. She smiled sadly. That bear belonged to Tommy Jenkins. He 6, now living with his fifth foster family. His birth mom promised to give it back when she got Clean. But she sold it instead. My partner pulled up Tommy's file. Sure enough, there was a note about a missing teddy bear he'd cry about every night. The photo album from the Martinez house, I asked, belonged to Rosa, didn't it? The teenager who aged out of the system last year. Andrea nodded. Her birth father sold everything when he went to prison. That album had the only pictures of her mother. One by one, we went through every item she'd stolen. Each one belonged to a foster kid she'd worked with, sold off by birth parents for drug money or lost in the shuffle between homes. She'd spent months tracking down these items, studying security systems and planning her break ins. She knew exactly when each family would be away, which windows would be unlocked, every motion sensor was placed. I tried doing it legally at first, she explained, offering to buy the items back. But most of these families wouldn't even talk to me. So I found another way. She pulled out a worn notebook filled with addresses, schedules, and detailed maps of wealthy neighborhoods. I've got 43 more items to find. Kid shouldn't have to lose their memories just because the system failed them. I looked at my partner. We both knew what we had to do. The evidence against her was solid. Security footage, documented break ins, even her own confession. She'd serve serious time. But then I thought about Tommy getting his bear back. Rosa seeing pictures of her mom again? I accidentally knocked my coffee all over her notebook. Oops. Looks like your list of targets is ruined. Guess we'll never know where you were planning to hit next. My partner caught on quick. Shame about that security footage, too. System must have glitched. It's all corrupted now. We let her go with a warning. Every few months after that, I'd hear about another missing teddy bear or baby blanket. But somehow the security cameras always seem to malfunction on those nights. Last week, I ran into Andrea at the grocery store. She smiled and handed me a small package. Inside was a baseball mitt with my name scratched into the leather. The same one my dad sold for drugs when I was 8. Found this at a pawn shop in Portland, she whispered. Figured you might want it back. I still keep that mitt on my desk.

When did faking it actually work out for you? For me, it was pretending to be fluent in Spanish at my first corporate job. I had taken four years of it in high school and two semesters in college, but I was far from fluent. However, on my resume, I confidently marked bilingual English slash Spanish. It's a tech support role at a software company, and during the interview, they never tested my Spanish skills. I figured the language requirement was just a nice to have that would rarely come up. My first week went smoothly. Then Friday afternoon happened. Hey, Rachel. My manager, Dave, poked his head over my cubicle. We've got an escalated case with a client in Mexico City. Their entire system is down, and they only speak Spanish. Can you jump on a call with them? My stomach dropped. Right now? Yeah, they've been waiting for someone who speaks Spanish. It's pretty urgent. I felt like I was going to throw up. I had two choices confess my exaggeration or fake my way through it. Sure. I heard myself say, send me the details. As I waited for the conference call to connect, I frantically opened Google Translate and typed out some technical phrases I might need. My palms were sweating so badly I could barely use my mouse. The call connected. Hola, departamento de soporte tecnico. A man's voice came through. See? Hola! Me llamo Rachel, I responded, my voice shaking slightly. Cual es el problema What followed was the most stressful hour of my professional life. The client, Miguel, spoke rapidly using technical terms I never Learned in school, caught maybe 60% of what he was saying and pieced together the rest from context. Mastifacio, por favor! I kept saying. Slower, please. I explained that the connection was bad to buy myself time to look up words. When I couldn't find the right technical term, I'd say un momento and pretend to check something in our system while frantically searching translations. Somehow I managed to understand that their server was rejecting authentication requests. Walked Miguel through basic trouble, shooting steps, relying heavily on my technical knowledge while struggling with a language barrier. After about 45 minutes, Miguel exclaimed, funsiona! Es que funsiona LA ora! It worked! I had somehow fixed their problem. Muchas Gracias, Rachel, Miguel said, relief evident in his voice. Tu espanol no es perfecto. What's your problem? I froze. He had just said my Spanish wasn't perfect, but I solved their problem. Gracias, I replied, mortified but relieved. Estoy still learning technical terms after? For hanging up, I expected to feel ashamed, but instead I felt oddly accomplished. I had managed to help someone despite my limitation. Dave stopped by my desk later. Great job with that call. The client emailed saying you were extremely helpful. They've been with us for years, but complained about language barriers before. I nodded, unsure what to say. They mentioned your Spanish needs some technical vocabulary. Work. But they appreciated your effort. Many people would push through a language barrier like that. I smiled weakly. I should probably brush up on my technical Spanish. Definitely. In fact, the company will pay for classes if you're interested. That Monday, I signed up for specialized Spanish courses. Six months later, I was handling all our Latin American support calls with genuine confidence. I still work with Miguel's company. They're now our biggest client in Mexico. And he still teases me about that first call.

While doing dishes, my landlord asked, did you unplug the extension cord in the basement? I dried my hands. Yeah, last night around eleven PM why? I responded my landlord. Casper's knees buckled and he started hitting his head against the wall repeatedly. Whoa, what's wrong? It's just an extension cord. I reached out to stop him from hurting himself, but he shoved me back with surprising force. He fumbled for his phone with shaking hands. She's gone. Eleven twenty three PM, exactly like they warned me. Tears were streaming down his face as he spoke to someone. Yes, the power was cut. 12 minutes. That's all it took before I could process what was happening. The basement door flew open and Missus Delacqua from the unit below mine came charging up. She took one look at me and screamed murderer so loud my ears rang. What are you talking about? I backed against the kitchen counter, completely lost. She collapsed next to Casper, both of them sobbing. 47 days, she wailed. We kept her alive for 47 days and you killed her in 12 minutes. Kept who alive? What's happening? My phone started blowing up with texts from other tenants. Monster. How could you, we all heard what you did. Cops are coming. The buildings maintenance guy, Tiago burst through my door without knocking. You sick bastard. I told Casper not to rent to outsiders. He had a wrench in his hand like he was considering using it. The Orange cord, he shook his head and just leaf the one that runs up through the PVC pipe that we all check three times a day. It was just an extension cord. My voice cracked with panic. Just an extension cord. Missus Deliqua laughed hysterically. That cord was the only thing between her and death. Casper finally looked at me, his eyes red and swollen. Two weeks you've been here two weeks and you've destroyed everything. I explained the basement rules when you moved in. He was shaking with rage. I showed you the locked cabinet, the medical equipment, showed me where the laundry was. That's it. There was no locked cabinet. I was desperate now. More people started flooding into my apartment. The couple from 3C, the old man from the first floor, even the food delivery drivers who serviced our building regularly. They all looked at me with pure hatred. I delivered her medications just yesterday, the pharmacy tech said quietly. $12,000 worth, all useless now. She trusted us, someone said. She trusted us to keep her safe. We had shifts. Another tenant sobbed, 24 7 monitoring until you came. Missus Delacqua pulled out her phone showing a schedule. Look, your name isn't even on the care rotation because you refused to help. When we asked what care rotation? Nobody asked me anything. Sirens wailed outside. Through my window, I could see three police cars and an ambulance pulling up. But the ambulance didn't rush. The emts moved Slowly, like they already knew it was too late. 11:23, Casper kept repeating, the machines would have alarmed at 11:11 when the power cut. She had 12 minutes of battery backup, 12 minutes of oxygen left. My stomach turned to ice. The humming, someone whispered. He must have heard the machines humming through the ceiling. How could he not know we were so close? Missus Delilah wept. The lung transplant was next week. She just needed one more week. Two police officers entered my apartment. One of them already had handcuffs out. Ma'am, we need you to come with us. I didn't know, I pleaded. There was no sign on the cord, no explanation. How was I supposed to know someone's life support was plugged into a random orange extension cord? Casper's face turned dark. That extension cord ran up through the ceiling to Missus Antoff's apartment. Her granddaughter, Vera, 7, 7 years old with cystic fibrosis. Her ventilator, her oxygen concentrator, her feeding pump, everything that kept her alive was plugged into that cord. The power went out at 11:11 when you unplugged it, Missus Delacour said. The backup battery only lasts 12 minutes. Eleven twenty three PM, her ventilator stopped. She suffocated in her sleep while her grandmother was in the bathroom. A little girl is dead because you unplugged an extension cord to do your laundry, Tiago spat. But there was no sign, nothing saying it was medical equipment. I was sobbing now, too. The officer stepped Forward with the handcuffs. You're under arrest for involuntary manslaughter. Full story on channel link below.

When did you have to choose between your job and your life? My manager locked my Epipen in a glass cabinet while I was having an allergic reaction and told me, if you can talk, you can work. I've been serving the dinner rush at this upscale steakhouse when my throat started closing after someone in the kitchen switched almond oil for olive oil in the staff meal without telling anyone. The moment my lips began tingling and my throat tightened, I ran to my manager, Craig, and explained I was going into anaphylactic shock and needed my Epipen from the first aid cabinet. Immediately, he looked at me from behind the host stand and said, the policy about accessing the medical cabinet during dinner service.
