Three men are now in custody as police desperately try to find 15 year old Alisa Petrov. Are you guys keeping up with this story? Alisa is a 15 year old at Utah girl who vanished on April 21st after her mom dropped her off at school or so she thought. Alisa then left the school headed to a gas station and then went to a track station and took a train to Provo. But that's where the cops lost her. So police go to her social media and they start snooping around and see that she's been speaking with a 38 year old man named William Taylor Grinds. And the conversation between the two is very, very sexually charged. So Glynns tells police that yes, he had been speaking to her but no, he's never actually met up with her. And the last time he heard from her was when she sent him a text message from some stranger's phone at a random bus stop in Utah. But then last week police arrest another man 35 year old Matthew Nichols Manard who was also talking to Lisa in a very sexual way. Alisa's iPad shows the conversation between her and Menard are talking about her running away. And Menard says that he'd fly to Vegas to meet up with her but work wouldn't allow him to until late may or early June. Here's where it gets even crazier. Now police have arrested a third man 41 year old Samuel Mitchell And again, conversations are very sexual in nature. Alisa told him that she wanted to run away to Vegas, and he told her that he would help kidnap her if that's what she wanted. Here's what's so scary to me. All three of these men have been charged, but none of them have been charged with anything related to Alisa's disappearance. They're facing charges related to the conversation. So, uh, enticing a minor and sexual exploitation. So if they didn't kidnap her, where is she? Police have also said that these men didn't know each other. It wasn't part of like, a ring. These were all separate conversations with Alyssa.

Charge them the same family rate they charged me. So my kids daycare had some family emergency and shut down for the day. They sent this email at like 3 in the morning, which was real helpful when I'm already asleep and have to work the next day. I'm scrambling around trying to find someone to watch my kid because I literally could not miss work that day. Had this huge presentation that would basically make or break my job. So I'm calling everyone I know at like 6:00am. The only person who picks up is my step brother's girlfriend, Ashley. Doesn't work, just sits around all day while my step brother pays for everything. I mean everything. Her daily Starbucks runs, weekly nail appointments, the whole designer purse collection. been trying to get her to do literally anything productive for years, but whatever, I'm desperate. I call her up and she's like, oh, sure, I can totally watch him for you. I'm thinking, finally, someone's actually gonna help me out. Then she hits me with it. My family rate is $200 for six hours. I literally had to ask her to repeat that because I thought I heard wrong. $200, six hours to watch one kid who mostly just plays with his tablet anyway? Are you being serious right now? I asked. She goes on this whole speech about how this is her livelihood and she takes childcare very seriously and that she's already giving me a family Discount. I'm thinking, what livelihood? You haven't worked a day since you moved in with my stepbrother three years ago. But I'm stuck. If I don't show up to work that day, I'm literally getting fired. So I agree to her insane price, and she demands the money up front. Before I even drop my kid off. I hand over $200 cash, drive to work fuming, and end up working barely four hours after you factor in traffic. So I basically paid 50 bucks an hour for her to sit on her couch and make sure my kid didn't burn the house down. Fast forward two years. Ashley and my step brother break up, but somehow she ends up living rent free in his dad's extra house and driving my dad's old car. My step brother still pays all her bills because they have a kid together. Now. She finally gets a job at some retail place because he stopped funding her weekly spa days. Then last month, I get this panicked text in our family group chat. Emergency. My babysitter bailed and I have to work today or I'll get fired. Can anyone watch my daughter, please? I'm desperate. I'm reading this text, and I can't help but smile a little. I text her back super fast, I can totally help you out. I'll watch her. She's so relieved and grateful, sending me heart emojis and everything. Then I hit her with the kicker. My family rate is $200. For the day. The typing bubbles appear and disappear, like, five times. Then my phone starts blowing up. Are you kidding me right now? That's way too much. I thought we were family. You're being ridiculous. Just screenshot our old conversation from two years ago and send it back to her. This is the exact same rate you charged me. You said it was the family rate, remember? You said you took this very seriously. She completely lost it. Started calling me every name in the book, saying I was petty and vindictive and that she was in a real emergency. I told her that's exactly what I said to her two years ago. The best part? She ended up having to call out of work anyway because nobody else would watch her kid for free on such short notice. And apparently, her manager was not happy about it.

What are some things you'd only know by growing up poor? I Learned how to make a full meal out of whatever was in the back of our kitchen cabinets. My mom called it creative cooking, but really it was just survival. Like when we'd run out of real food by the third week of every month, I got really good at making spaghetti using ramen noodles and ketchup packets from McDonald's. My little brother Jake thought it was a special recipe until he went to his friend's house and saw what actual spaghetti looked like. The worst part was pretending everything was normal at school. When kids talked about going out to eat, I'd nod along like I knew what they meant. Honestly, the only restaurant I've been to was the Soup Kitchen downtown, and that didn't really count. I remember this one time in 4th grade when our teacher asked us to write about our favorite family tradition. Everyone wrote about Christmas morning or birthday parties. I wrote about Cabinet Day, the day every month when mom would dump out all our kitchen cabinets and we'd get creative with whatever expired cans and random ingredients we found. My teacher, Mrs. Rodriguez, kept me after class. She asked if everything was okay at home. I told her Cabinet Day was fun, like a cooking game show. She didn't look convinced, but she let me go. The thing is, you get really good at making stuff work. Like when my Shoes got holes in them. I Learned to put duct tape inside so my socks wouldn't get wet. When our heat got shut off, I figured out that if you left the oven door open, it could warm up the kitchen pretty good. I also got really good at math because I was always counting money. Not like homework math, but real math. Like if milk costs three dollars and we only have two, 50, how many days can we make cereal with water instead? Or if electricity costs sixty dollars and we only have 40, which appliances can we unplug to make it last longer? But the weirdest thing I Learned was how to be invisible at school. Poor kids develop the superpower where we can blend into the background. Like when they were collecting money for field trips, I'd suddenly need to use the bathroom. When they passed out the free lunch forms, pretend to be really interested in my textbook. The free lunch thing was the worst. They'd call out names over the intercom every morning for kids who qualified for free meals. They might as well have announced, here are all the poor kids in school. I started bringing empty lunch bags and pretending to eat air sandwiches just to avoid that walk of shame to the lunch counter. Then something crazy happened. In 6th grade, this new kid, Austin, moved to our school. His family was even worse off than mine. On his second day, When they called the free lunch names, I stood up and said, finally, I'm starving, really loud. Everyone laughed, but not in a mean way. That's when I realized something. I was spending so much energy hiding being poor that I was missing out on actually living. Austin became my best friend because he didn't care who knew his family struggled. He traded his free lunch pizza for my free lunch hamburger without any shame. We started this thing where we have poverty competitions, see who could come up with the most creative poor kids solutions. Like Austin figured out that if you filled up water bottles at school, you could take free drinks home. I discovered that if you ask nicely, the cafeteria ladies would sometimes give you extra rolls to take with you. The best part was when Austin's mom got a new job and they moved to a better apartment. Instead of forgetting about being poor, he invited me over to show me their new place. They had a full refrigerator for the first time in years. His mom made us sandwiches with actual lunch meat instead of government cheese. And Austin looked at me and said, we made it.

The police officer who shoved the pacifier down his baby's throat so forcefully that it caused a brain bleed has been fired from the Portage Police Department. Thirty two year old Cameron Coronado's wife told police their six month old baby was fussy early in the morning. So Cameron got up and took him into the kitchen. The mom said she then heard Cameron shout out, oh my god, shut the F up and then heard the baby's cry change. So mom walks into the kitchen to see what's going on and sees her husband Cameron wiping blood away from the baby's mouth with a baby wipe. She asked Cameron what the hell happened and he says he got frustrated with the baby crying and forced the pacifier down his throat. So Cameron decides to take the baby on a car ride to calm him down. But when they got back 15 minutes later, the baby was still screaming in pain. He wouldn't swallow and he refused to eat. So Cameron's wife asked if they should take the baby to the hospital and Cameron apparently said, quote, I know what will happen to me if we take him. So they end up taking him to the er and the doctor confirms the pacifier was pushed so forcefully down his throat that the first layer of skin had been torn off and the baby had a brain bleed. Mom then told police that things like this have happened before, but she Was afraid to tell anyone because he's a cop. She said once when he was frustrated with their daughter, he squeezed her super tight and then punched a hole in the wall. He also said that on the evening of July 9th, both the kids were fussy and Cameron threatened to, quote, kill these effing kids if they didn't stop crying. Coronato has been fired from his job and charged with child abuse. Bond is set at 10 k.

First red flag. This is the pastor's home. If your pastor lives in a house like this, they were not blessed by god. They are scamming you. This lunatic pastor was just arrested for holding 70, some people hostage, forced labor, and laundering millions of dollars. Last week, the FBI arrested the pastor and executive director of the Kingdom of God Global Church out of North Tampa, Florida. The federal indictment says Pastor David Taylor and Executive Director Michelle Brannon recruited these people to work at call centers and referred to them as armor bearers. They were forced to these locations, were not paid, were not allowed to leave, could not speak with their families, and were forced to take contraceptives. And if these people didn't meet their financial quotas, food was withheld. They were physically beaten and forced to stay awake for long periods of time. Very Christian like. And he was able to recruit these people by claiming to be an apostle and quote, Jesus's best friend. He would then tell his followers if they didn't obey and donate massive amounts of money, they would suffer in hell. The indictment says these two scammed people out of more than $50 million and use nearly every penny of the money to fund their own lavish lifestyles. This reminds me of that pastor who told his ushers to close the door, the church doors and wouldn't let the congregation leave until they raised $40,000. Do you remember that?

What's the most insane coincidence that's happened to you? I was 32 when my kidneys basically gave up on me. Just like that. One day I'm fine, next day I'm peeing blood and my face looks like a balloon. Doctor told me I had maybe six months before I'd need a machine to keep me alive, or I wouldn't see Christmas. The dialysis treatments were hell. Three times a week, four hours each time, hooked up to this machine that cleaned my blood because my body couldn't do it anymore. I'd sit there watching Netflix on my phone, listening to other patients talk about their families coming to visit. Meanwhile, I'm sitting alone because my only family disappeared when I was 8. My mom, Karen, literally vanished one Tuesday morning. Left me sleeping and never came back. Foster care, group homes, the whole deal. I used to wonder if she was dead or alive. But after 24 years of nothing, I figured she was probably gone. So when Doctor Martinez told me I needed a kidney transplant and asked about family donors, I just shrugged. It's just me, I said. He put me on the national donor list, but warned me the wait could be years. People my age with my blood type, we weren't exactly priority. Crazy thing is, while I'm sitting in that dialysis chair every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday slowly dying, Karen was doing the exact same thing. Three states over. Liver failure from years of drinking. And god knows what else. She'd been in and out of jail, living under fake names. Basically destroyed her body completely.

What's the most messed up thing you've seen on a zoom class? Okay, so this happened during 7th grade history when we had this substitute teacher, Mister Ramos. He. He was only supposed to be there for like a week while our regular teacher was sick. Nothing crazy, just some boring guy clicking through slides about the Civil War or whatever. But on Wednesday, something really weird happened that still makes me cringe thinking about it. So class had just ended. Everyone was saying bye and closing their laptops. I was still on the call, though, because me and my friends Aria and Josh always stayed on after to mess around and share TikToks. We'd screen share funny videos and just talk about random stuff. That's when Mister Ramos's camera suddenly came back on. At first we thought maybe he forgot to leave the call, but then we realized he had no idea we were still there. He couldn't see us because our cameras were off. He got up from his desk, took his button down shirt completely off, and lit up a cigarette right there in what looked like his bedroom. Then he opened another laptop next to him and pulled up what looked like a live stream of himself teaching our class from earlier that day. We all just froze like what the hell was happening? He started clicking through this folder on his computer called Zoom Class Recordings and began laughing to himself while watching clips of Us from previous classes. That's when he started talking to himself and saying really messed up stuff about all of us kids. Look at this little girl. Always pretending to care about history. What happened when your teacher made you tutor the star basketball player? My teacher called me to his office and said, you're tutoring Fiona Cove. She needs to pass or she's benched for the season. My first thought, I don't have time for this. Before I could respond, he showed me her test scores on his computer. All C's and D's with the occasional F. She needs someone patient who won't give up on her. You're going to get extra credit, plus a recommendation letter for grad school if you do this. The bribery was working. Fiona was campus royalty. Always surrounded by teammates, always rushing between practice and game. She's desperate to stay on the team. One semester. That's all I'm asking. The offer was too tempting, so I agreed to meet her. Finding her waiting outside the library was surprising. I walked over with my chemistry books. Hey, Fiona. Ready to tackle some chemistry? She looked up, relieved, her practice bag dropping. You actually showed when I nodded. Confused, she explained three tutors had stood her up. They probably figured I was hopeless. The first session, Fiona kept writing down everything I said frantically. Slow down. I need to get this exactly right. I watched her rewrite the same equation four times. It doesn't need to be perfect. She shook her head stubbornly. Yes, it does. I can't lose basketball. We spent three hours on basic periodic table memorization. Fiona made flashcards for every single element. Hydrogen, atomic, Number one, she recited while pacing. Her determination was unexpected. Most people think I'm just here for basketball. She. But I actually want to learn this. The third week we met after her practice at ten PM. Fiona showed up, exhausted but focused. Sorry coach kept us late. Did you eat? She pulled out two sandwiches from her bag. I grabbed extra from the dining hall. We worked through molecular structures while eating. Fiona kept asking questions that showed she was really thinking. Why does oxygen form two bonds but nitrogen forms three? I explained electron shells and watched understanding dawn on her face. That actually makes sense. She high fived me impulsively, then pulled back, embarrassed. Sorry. I get excited. I tried to focus.
